column1: Binary R packages for Linux
column45:
*Description:*

The CRAN in Artifactory supports binary R packages for macOS and Windows, but not for Linux. Binary packages are much faster to install and for R in Docker images we need Linux packages. 

R package archives come in three flavors: "tar.gz" for source and binary Linux; "zip" for Windows; ".tgz" for macOS. When uploading a package archive with the UI it detects that zip and .tgz files are binary and suggests putting them in the "bin" part of the CRAN. It does not detect if a tar.gz is the source or binary Linux. The DESCRIPTION file in the archive reveals if it is binary or source.

When using the REST API it is possible to POST a tar.gz archive to the "bin" part of the CRAN, but the location mirrors that of Windows/macOS: "bin/<distro>/contrib/<r version>" (e.g. "bin/ubuntu/focal/contrib/4.0.1").

However, for R on Linux to "just work" with the binary packages, we need an extra "src/contrib" in the path. (The current intermediate "contrib" is not needed.)

*Expected Beahvior:*

As an example, packages compiled with R version 4.0.1 on Ubuntu 20.04 (Focal) should be located in "bin/ubuntu/focal/4.0.1/src/contrib" and in R the "repos" option should be "<JFrog Artifactory URL>/bin/ubuntu/focal/4.0.1". In this case, R will automatically detect that the packages are binary when they are downloaded.

As long as "src/contrib" is the last part of the folder, you can include additional folders in between.

column1: Support basic authentication as SSO method in Artifactory 7
column45:
We are still using Artifactory 6 and are testing an upgrade to Artifactory 7.12.5, but it seems that SSO via basic authentication has been dropped in Artifactory 7. Would it be possible to bring this feature back?

In our current Artifactory 6 deployment, users are first authenticated on a company-internal proxy. When an authenticated user clicks on the 'Artifactory' link, the user credentials are sent to Artifactory using basic authentication and the user is transparently logged into Artifactory.

However, with Artifactory 7 this no longer works! Consider the following test to the /ui/auth/current endpoint, which returns details about the current user, such as the username. 

With Artifactory 6, the following command returns as JSON structure with my user details (and it returns "Bad credentials" if I enter the wrong password):
{noformat}
curl -u myLDAPuser --verbose --noproxy \* http://localhost:8081/artifactory/ui/auth/current
{noformat}
However, with Artifactory 7, the same command (this time to port 8082) always returns details for the 'anonymous' user (no matter if I provide correct or invalid credentials):
{noformat}
curl -u myLDAPuser --verbose --noproxy \* http://localhost:8082/ui/api/v1/ui/auth/current
{noformat}
Why was basic authenticaion dropped as a means to provide SSO to Artifactory and why is this nowhere documented?
 Would it be possible to bring back basic authentication as a SSO method?

Regards,
 Dominik

column1: API endpoint to monitor overall health of replication on the service
column45:
Currently there is the ability to determine basic information about replication associated with a specific repository with the /api/replication/repository-name endpoint (ref [https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-ScheduledReplicationStatus] ). 

https://www.jfrog.com/jira/browse/RTFACT-13977 already exists to request more information on the state of a particular repository's replication but what I'm requesting here is a holistic view of replication health across a service - i.e. information such as:
- The number (and list when more details requested) of repositories that successfully replicated data in the last (given time, e.g. 24 hours)
- The number (and list when more details requested) of repositories that successfully connected to their replication targets but didn't have to move any data as they were already up to date
- The number (and list when more details requested) of repositories that failed to connect to to their replication targets or move data

It would be very useful to also get a more detailed view generating a report showing the number of bytes each repository is behind / ahead of their target, though I wouldn't want this feature to delay the overall implementation.

column1: Request to support gpg signing keys propagation
column45:
In order to sign RPM and Deb repositories you need to deploy gpg key pair.

However, if you are working with Edge nodes, you will need to upload these keys to each Edge separately.
This request is to support centralised  management of the gpg keys == support key propagation

column1: Global replication feature
column45:
*Current Behaviour:*

Currently, in order to configure replications for an Artifactory instance with a large number of repositories, you'll need to either:
 # Configure it manually going repo by repo
 # Create a bash script that loops through all the repos in the source and destination instances and applies the configuration using REST API calls

 

*Suggestion:*

A global replication feature can ease this process by offering the following:
 # Configure the source Artifactory instance(s)
 # Offer to automatically replicate to all repos in the destination instance on a same-name basis
 # Have an overall "drag list" of the configured replications/repos for an easier and quicker configuration & management

column1: Expose Internal APIs for Manipulating Compliance Licenses
column45:
I co-lead the OSPO at Progressive Insurance. We need to automate a few business processes which require API endpoints that exist (as seen by Chrome dev tools) but are not formally exposed to end users. A summary of the endpoints and the use cases justifying their needs are below:
 * Ability to assign a custom license to an artifact

We make extensive use of watches and policies to ensure that no artifact is consumed that either a) contains an unknown license or b) does not contain a license. Some of these situations are expected for our use cases, and we’d like to automate the resolution of these violations so they do not pollute our alarming or reporting. The ability to assign a license to an artifact - including a custom license - via an API call would allow us to programmatically identify these situations and resolve them ourselves via automation. This assignment can already been done via the UI, but the volume of artifacts we consume (hundreds to thousands a day) makes manual resolution of these issues prohibitive.
 * Ability to fetch all known compliance licenses

We maintain an external repository of different licenses and our legal stance on their use (e.g., allowed for use, never allowed for use, discuss with legal, etc). This information is published to an internal developer website so they have a handy, developer-friendly way to determine if a component they wish to use is likely to be approved or denied. We populate this external repository from a variety of sources (e.g., spdx, osi), but are currently unable to reflect all configurable licenses in Artifactory because the API endpoint is currently private.

Adding these two endpoints would go along way in easing the operational burden of consuming your product. Right now, these are very challenging gaps from our end and we don’t yet have good line of site as to how we might address these needs.

column1: Add support for sending Basic Authorization header with OpenID Connect
column45: Currently, when adding integration with Open ID connect, we do not have support for handling Basic Authorization header. From the open ID spec the option to send this is a valid one: https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1_0.html#TokenEndpoint

column1: Exclude specific upstream python module version
column45:
We have a remote repo "upstream-pypi", pointing to upstream python 
 [url:https://files.pythonhosted.org|https://support.jfrog.com/s/tickets/5001r00002tvxh5AAA/how-to-exclude-specific-upstream-python-module-version]
 We want to block a *specific version of module* and do not want it to appear in the pip search. We added this in the exclude pattern still that does not help.

E.g. say to block setuptools ver 50.0.0,  added  the following in the exclude path  "excludesPattern:**/setuptools-50.0.0*" 
 still it shows the blocked version  in 
 [http://<base_url>/artifactory/api/pypi/upstream-pypi/simple/setuptools/
|Can you please enhance it to honor exclude pattern for pip search.
 Thanks,
 Suresh|

column1: Allow uploading plugins using Rest-API
column45:
Currently Artifactory doesn't support updating plugins using Rest-API. This makes it hard to administrate it in an environment where duties are segregated and Artifactory operators do not have access to underlying infrastructure.

While there's a chance that plugin could cause the instance to fail and recovery would require action by a person that has access to infra, it should be up to artifactory users to make the decision on how they want to manage plugins. e.g. Such failures can be mitigated using staging instances of Artifactory to verify the change.

column1: Combining multiple repositories under a single folder in artifactory
column45:
*Requirement Statement*:

-----------------------------

Our requirement is related to the clubbing of different repositories under a single folder in the artifactory.

E.g.; we have unique Gradle repositories (A, B, and C). We want to club them together under a single folder/repository for the ease of user's readability.

Like:

*Group-Kronos*
 * A
 * B
 * C

If we are using a virtual repository concept, then it will pick the artifacts under the repositories but not the repository names. We would like to refrain from copying all the content from A/ to A/A/ that will allow the packages to be visible under the Repository name.

Can you please consider this feature to provide a generic folder level clubbing? It will of big help to arrange repositories in artifactory group wise.

An analogy to this feature is the Jenkins Folder plugin that provides a unique namespace to the pipelines under it yet clubs them under the same folder.

 

Best regards

Nishant

column1: Callbacks and actions for Artifactory events
column45:
We have the requirement to keep artifacts in sync between smart remote repos on Edge servers and an Artifactory backend.

This is not the case currently, as the smart remote repos are not aware of overwrite / delete events on the backend, and still continue serving the original cached version of the artifact.

We are requesting the following feature to work around this:

Implement callbacks / triggers for "actions", like the upload, deletion or overwrite of an artifact.

These automatically triggered "actions" could be user scripts, or even predefined actions like "delete cached artifact on a list of Edge servers".

Although we have a specific use case for it (refreshing smart remote repos on Edges), this would also be useful for other tasks and situations.

column1: Add support on NuGet Content Hash via REST API
column45:
In case that we have multiple copies of the same NuGet package in the same virtual repository (in different local repositories) to avoid conflicts some of the users verify that all copies of a NuGet package have the same content by comparing the package hashes.

However, with the introduction of package signing, [nuget.org|http://nuget.org/] started signing packages with a repository certificate and on a regular basis seems to be re-signing the packages with a new certificate. That means, that two copies of the same package downloaded from nuget.org at different points in time, might have a different hash even though they contain the same content (only the signature embedded in the package has changed).

Therefore we can't check easily if two packages are the same.

NuGet introduced the concept of a “[content hash|https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/Nupkg-Metadata-File]” as a hash value over the contents of a package (excluding the signature file) This content hash will not change when the package is resigned but only if the actual content changes.

column1: Docker client error message misleading
column45:
When a user doesn't have DELETE/OVERWRITE permissions and if that user uploads a Docker image with a name and tag that already exists in the docker repository then the user will get the below error which is confusing and the error message is not related to the actual problem.

Error Message:-

[DEPRECATION NOTICE] registry v2 schema1 support will be removed in an upcoming release. Please contact admins of the divija-docker-local.jfrog.io registry NOW to avoid future disruption. More information at https://docs.docker.com/registry/spec/deprecated-schema-v1/

*unauthorized*: Pushing Docker images with manifest v2 schema 1 to this repository is blocked. For more information visit [https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Advanced+Topics#AdvancedTopics-DockerManifestV2Schema1Deprecation]


Solution:-
The issue is related to the permissions of the user for the docker repository. So once we give "DELETE/OVERWRITE" permissions for the user who is uploading then he can upload the docker image successfully.

column1: Container image builds need remote input caching and dependency tracking
column45:
We deliver containers that we build to our customers.

Nearly all our Dockerfiles depend on numerous external artifacts:
 * Well-know OS containers through the FROM line in the Dockerfile
 * *apt-get install* or *upgrade* commands for Ubuntu in the RUN lines in the Dockerfile
 * *wget* commands in the RUN lines in the Dockerfile
 * *curl* GET commands in the RUN lines in the Dockerfile
 * *pip* commands in the RUN lines in the Dockerfile
 * and potentially others

We want to record these external artifacts that are being used to create our containers.
 * for reproducibility
 * to shield our build process from network hiccups
 * to isolate our build machines from direct external access
 * to allow these inputs to be scanned using Xray

As well, much as one can record an artifact dependency tree in, say, npm over the course of a build, we want to be able to record in the metadata of build 100 of container X the fact that it depended on dpkg DD version 900 and https fetch HH version 920.

We do not want to have specify specific versions of external artifacts in the Dockerfile source: if we pull the latest version of some artifact, we want to automatically record which version was chosen, but be able to return to that specific version in a future rebuild.

If needed, we want to be able to rebuild a container pulling from the original dependencies, potentially with a handful of adjustments.

Because our containers are delivered to customers, we want to avoid embedding our local infrastructure into our Dockerfiles.  The Dockerfiles we publish should be buildable by a customer and not fail because they do not see our infrastructure.  A nosy customer should not be able to paw through our images and see what the names of our servers are.

column1: Artifactory Configuration API : baseUrl field validation incomplete
column45:
We believe we've found a subtle bug while trying to automate the configuration of Artifactory CE server.  This may or may not apply to all Artifactory editions. It took several days to isolate, so warrants raising this issue. 

We start with the following base image:
{code:java}
FROM docker.bintray.io/jfrog/artifactory-cpp-ce:7.6.2{code}
We then bootstrap our custom docker image with this simple .sh script to set the `urlBase` setting:
{code:java}
#!/bin/bash
set -eo pipefailcurl -m 5 -f -X PATCH \
-u ${DEMO_ART_CREDS_USR}:${DEMO_ART_CREDS_PSW} \
-H 'Content-Type: application/yaml' \
http://localhost:8082/artifactory/api/system/configuration \
-d '
urlBase: http://artifactory-training:8082
'
{code}
The REST API call is successful, but when we start a container from the image, it presents this error, which we believe is completely misleading since there is obviously no HA configuration made anywhere:

 

Of note, this example uses the `yaml` API, but the results are the same when calling the REST API endpoint:

http://localhost:8082/artifactory/api/system/configuration/baseUrl

 
{code:java}
artifactory-training    | 2020-10-12T06:34:01.261Z [jfrt ] [ERROR] [b41cf493e3dd3f2f] [ctoryContextConfigListener:116] [art-init            ] - Application could not be initialized: Found active HA servers in DB, Community Edition for C/C++ is not supported in by active HA environment. Shutting down Artifactory.
artifactory-training    | 2020-10-12T06:36:46.303Z [jffe ] [ERROR] [                ] [                              ] [main                ] - Error: Error starting application Failed pinging artifactory for 180Request failed with status code 404
{code}
 

 

Through testing, we found that the Artifactory first-run wizard rejects the URL shown earlier with an error, stating that the string `/artifactory` is invalid/illegal in the URL.  To workaround the issue, we changed the URL in the script and the HA-related error has gone away. 

It seems that the REST API does not perform the same data validation as the GUI. If this is expected behavior, that is understandable, however there's more. 

We were also allowed to set the invalid/illegal set the Base URL field via the GUI under the main Artifactory Settings area. The field validation should definitely be applied there. 

So, in summary, it seems likely that the only improvement that can be made here is to add the same `baseURL` field validation in main settings which exists under the first-run wizard.

column1: Artifactory Configuration API yaml : First-run wizard not being suppressed
column45:
The following issue applies to Artifactory CE for C/C++.  I don't know if the same symptom applies to other distro's of artifactory. 

We use the following script to bootstrap a docker image:
#!/bin/bash
set -eo pipefailcurl -m 5 -f -X PATCH \
-u ${DEMO_ART_CREDS_USR}:${DEMO_ART_CREDS_PSW} \
-H 'Content-Type: application/yaml' \
http://localhost:8082/artifactory/api/system/configuration \-d '
urlBase: http://artifactory-training:8082'
 

As you can see, we're using the yaml configuration API which is supposed to suppress the first-run wizard, but it doesn't. 

 

If we add the following yaml snippet to the body, it DOES suppress the first-run wizard properly:

 
{code:java}
localRepositories: #Local repositories configuration     
    conan-tmp: #The local repository name
        type: conan #The package type
{code}
In summary, it's super weird and seems to be a bug that we have to create a repo in order for the first-run-wizard suppression to take place.  In theory, calling the configuration API with any valid yaml configuration should do it.

column1: Access gitlab private/internal projects
column45:
Security concerns are pushing our projects, in our instance of gitlab, towards internal/private settings.

To be able to setup thoose projects as remotes in artifactory we must be able to authenticate using Bearer token. Artifactory only supports Basic authentication today which is a growing concern as we can not provide access to the code in thoose project thru artifactory.

Thus we request this feature.

column1: Group auto-association for OAuth SSO
column45:
I would like to be able to automatically map users logged in with OAuth SSO to Artifactory groups corresponding to group permission in an AD. This is possible using SAML SSO so I'm hoping it'll be possible to implement with OAuth as well.
Having this feature would reduce the amount of manual work needed to be done significantly. We have multiple teams that need access to the Artifactory instance that will have different access depending on what team they are a part of. This is also reflected in what groups they are a part of in the AD. Currently we would need to have them log on once and only after that have an admin change their group memberships.

column1: REST API to list artifacts in a smart remote that aren't currently cached
column45:
It would be very useful to be able to query via the REST API which artifacts in a smart remote repository are not currently present in the local cache. Perhaps some options on the "File List" REST API call.

The particular use case we are looking to implement is to create a script which populates the local cache on a smart remote on an Artifactory edge node by seeing which artefacts are not currently in the case and downloading those one by one.

column1: JFrog SaaS repository creation via REST API Issue
column45:
Hi Team,

 

I am having issue while creating repositories via REST API. I am following json format given by JFrog - [https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Repository+Configuration+JSON]

 

The default repository layout when created by REST API and no values passed for "repoLayoutRef". It creates the repo layout as "maven-2-default"

 

But when we create it from JFrog GUI, we don't require to select the layout and it choose by itself as per the repository type e.g.

nuget repo type has nuget-default layout

gradle repo type has gradle-default layout

maven repo type has maven-2-default

 

I can change script logic and pass static values, but concern is if JFrog release new repository layout like maven-3-default, we still be keep using maven-2-default without notifying.

 

Is there any way or parameter which works the way we create repositories from JFrog GUI, where we don't select any layout and pick by itself the latest available layout like maven has 2 versions but it picks by defauld maven-2.

 

I am in middle of creating script to onboard JFrog repo, permissions, your early response will help.

 

Thanks,

DK

column1: Access Artifactory via Azure SPN
column45:
Hi,

 

Currently artifactory has a authorisation mechanism that uses Username and Password or Username and API key or Username and Accesstoken.

All the authorisation mechanisms are dependent of a User. Access tokens has a transient user feature but that is only available for Admin users. When a user leaves the project or organisation, the automation that the user handled may start to fail as user might have used his/her credentials of Jfrog.

Can we have access to Artifactory via Azure SPN. We can assign users to a single SPN. So instead of using User dependent credentials, a team can use the SPN in common for all the common activities done on automation and other stuffs.

Is it possible to have this feature in Artifactory? It would be really good if we have this !

 

Regards

Pari

column1: Request to add repository level export via REST or PAPI
column45:
It seem that there is no way to programatically export a repository from Artifactory.
This is not available through REST, JFrog CLI, nor through the PAPI.

This is a very important feature for completely segregated network air-gap use-case.

A possible workaround is to use the backup functionality which allow to define a backup of a repository or a set of repositories.
One can configure backup (via ui or updating the config descriptor), and trigger the backup by pushing a new config descriptor. However, this is not synchronic.

column1: Locking down Artifact promotion
column45:
Hi Team,

we are currently implementing artifact promotion into out development pipeline to improve reliability and security of what artifacts are going into prod.

To that end we wanted to lock down from where an artifact is promoted from, for example any artifact can be promoted from it default repo into *lockdown-dev* only artifact in lockdown-dev can be promoted into *lockdown-test*, and finally only artifacts from lockdown-test can promoted *lockdown-prod*.


we would request a feature be made available to achieve this for example, having a setting on the repo which you can tick to enable then add repos to a list of "acceptable promotions repo"

Having the above setup, we could then run  "{{build-promote" with the optionally tag "}}{{--source-repo=$SOURCE_REPOSITORY"}}
{{}}

with "{{$SOURCE_REPOSITORY" }}Equalling one of the approve repos.

We've confirmed with ticket 141612 that there is currently no way to do this in artifactory.
column46:
on Prem Environment.

promotion access has been limited to service accounts that have been implemented into CI/CD process.

This stop promotions outside of the CI/CD process but unfortunately does not stop someone doing something dodgy inside the CI/CD process.

Creating this feature would stop someone doing something dodgy inside the CI/CD process.

column1: prevent internal package squatting on public registries
column45:
After emailing support I was told to raise a feature request here.

I've recently been made aware of a problem where it's possible for an attacker to make a new version of an internal artifact on a public registry, which users or CI systems could download when looking for the latest version.
  
 I am vulnerable to this because I use virtual repositories which have a local repository for internal artifacts, and a remote repository for public artifacts. Previously I interpreted the docs at [https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Virtual+Repositories] to mean that local repositories were always preferred. I now understand that remote repositories can be used to get a new version of an artifact which is in a local repository. I see the section in the docs about using Excludes Patterns to make sure internal artifacts aren't fetched from remotes, but this would require constantly updating the patterns with new internal artifacts.
  
 Can I ask for a feature where if any version of an artifact exists in a local repository in a virtual repository, the remote repositories in the virtual repository are not used to find new versions. It could be a checkbox when configuring a virtual repository. This would prevent the entire class of vulnerability without further configuration, and would work in a way which is easy to explain to end users.

Thank you.

column249:
13/Aug/20 5:13 PM;evgenyka;The ability to define *Includes Pattern* and an *Excludes Pattern* for virtual repositories provides a powerful tool you can use to manage artifact requests in your organization.

For example, your organization may have its own artifacts which are hosted both internally in a local repository, but also in a remote repository. For any reason (for example, optimal performance or security concerns), you would want these artifacts to be accessed from the local repository rather than from the remote one. To enforce this policy, you can define a virtual repository called "remote-repos" which includes the full set of remote repositories accessed by your organization, and then specify an Excludes Pattern with your organization's groupID. in this way, any attempt to access your internal artifact from a remote repository would be rejected.

You can fully automate the process of adding Exclude Pattern for specific artifact/s.

[https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Virtual+Repositories]
column250: 11/Feb/21 7:20 AM;pbaenziger;This issue was also covered by Alex Birsan in the [Medium Article "Dependency Confusion"|https://medium.com/@alex.birsan/dependency-confusion-4a5d60fec610] in which he used similar issues for a possible supply chain attack (bug bounty).
column251: 11/Feb/21 10:40 AM;fergal;If you would like to ask me about my user experience handling this using the existing options, I'm available. It was a fairly long project. Reading [Azure's white paper|https://azure.microsoft.com/en-gb/resources/3-ways-to-mitigate-risk-using-private-package-feeds/], it sounds like Azure Artifacts has added the default option to block remote versions of local packages. Reading [Azure's new docs page|https://docs.microsoft.com/en-gb/azure/devops/artifacts/concepts/upstream-behavior], it is exactly what I am asking for in this feature request.

column1: Support foreign layer caching for local docker repositories
column45:
With https://www.jfrog.com/jira/browse/RTFACT-13394, foreign layer caching was supported for remote repositories. This means that if an image from a remote registry contains foreign layers, artifactory with fetch and cache those foreign layers.

If, however, I build a custom image from a base image that has foreign layers and push it to a local registry, artifactory will not fetch and cache those foreign layers in response to a request to pull the custom image. Interestingly, if those layers have already been cached as a result of pulling the base image through the remote registry, Artifactory will server the cached layers in response to a request to pull the custom image.

The problem with the workaround of pulling the images through the remote registry first is that it is very brittle. It is only good as long as the layers stay cached, so you can't enable any type of cache cleanup, which can lead to space concerns in the long run

Can support be added for local registries to directly fetch and cache foreign layers if they are not already cached?

column1: Add support for Maven GitHub Packages
column45:
When attempting to set a GitHub Maven repository as a Remote repository in Artifactory, the Maven/Gradle clients are not able to retrieve packages from this Remote repository in Artifactory.

However, configuring the GitHub Maven repository straight against the Maven/Gradle clients works correctly and we are able to resolve the packages, which are located in the GitHub Maven repository.

For more context on GitHub Maven repositories configuration - [https://docs.github.com/en/packages/using-github-packages-with-your-projects-ecosystem/configuring-apache-maven-for-use-with-github-packages]

As we introduced support for GitHub PAT in the Jira ticket below, we should be able to achieve this, as we already did for NPM and NuGet.
 Jira Ticket - https://www.jfrog.com/jira/browse/RTFACT-20951

column1: Support shared repository
column45:
User Story:

So far we are using Artifactory to provide many shared repositories for many technologies. everyone can use their own account to deploy and only admin can delete the package. 

Our concerns:

Base on the current permission design, there is a security risk about anyone can override any released packages by released a new version. 

 

The feature we need:

we want the artifactory to enhance the permission management within the repository level. 

Such as:

an ownership feature on artifactory : people should register a package name before being able to upload it, with user/team permissions, as it is done for upstream servers (pypi / npm / ...). , 

allow the user to deleted his own packages.

column1: Develop OSTree deploy capability on JFrog CLI
column45:
Story:

Users should be able to deploy an OSTree repository to Artifactory. The functionality should be a part of the JFrog CLI. We would ideally want to develop a smart mechanism that pushes OSTree object deltas to an Artifactory repository. 

Some guidelines:

[IoT team's upload protocol flow|https://drive.google.com/file/d/1qRUU11ZOuECY157U1XIrImKgNM0Aj2pC/view?usp=sharing]

We should aim to migrate as much as we can from this IoT PoC project: 

[https://git.jfrog.info/projects/IOT/repos/ostree-service/browse/ostree-client-go]

column1: Create virtual OSTree repository
column45:
Story
As an Artifactory admin user, I would like to be able to create a virtual OSTree repository, so that I can later make the repository available for users in my organization to be able to deploy and download packages from the repository so they will be able to use it for their projects. 

Scope 
Ability to create a virtual OSTree repository from:

UI 
REST API 
Artifactory YAML Configuration File
Artifactory Bootstrap YAML File
Acceptance Criteria
An Artifactory admin user should be able to create a virtual OSTree repository using one of the methods specified under the Scope section.
The admin user should be able to aggregate one or more local/remote/virtual OSTree repositories in the virtual repository. 
The admin user should be able to configure a Default Deployment Repository which will be used as the local repository for which users with Deploy permission will be able to deploy packages when working against the virtual repository. 
An Artifactory admin user should be able to get the created virtual OSTree repository should in the Get Repositories API endpoint. 
An Artifactory admin user should be able to view the created virtual OSTree repository in the UI.

column1: Deploy OSTree package to a virtual repository
column45:
Story
As an Artifactory user with Deploy/Cache permission to a local OSTree repository that is configured as the Default Deployment Repository for a virtual OSTree repository, I would like to be able to deploy an OSTree package through the virtual repository so I can use it in my projects for future use and so other users will be able to download the package for their own projects.

Scope 
Ability to deploy an OSTree package to a virtual repository to Artifactory using the following methods:

curl 
UI download button
Acceptance Criteria
An Artifactory user with Deploy/Cache permission to a local OSTree repository that is configured as the Default Deployment Repository for a virtual OSTree repository should be able to deploy an OSTree package (apk) via the:
curl
UI download button
An Artifactory users with a Read permission to the Default Deployment Repository from step 1 is able to download the package deployed in step 1 using the following methods: 
OSTree package manager
curl
UI download button

 # UI

An Artifactory user with Read permission to an OSTree local repository and/or remote repositories that are aggregated in a virtual OSTree repositories should be able to download an OSTree repository via the:
 # OSTree package manager
 # curl
 # UI

As an admin user or Artifactory user with Delete/Overwrite permission to an OSTree remote repository, I would like to be able to delete an OSTree repository that exists in the remote repository so I can free space up in the repository or delete a repository that has an issue so other users will not download it and use it in their project.

 # curl

 # curl
 # UI

column1: Set Me Up wizard for local OSTree repository
column45:
h3. Story

As an Artifactory user with Read permission to a local OSTree repository, I would like to get a Set Me Up wizard that will help me with understanding how to add the repository as the default OSTree registry and with instructions on how to deploy and download packages from the repository. 
h3. Scope 

Add a Set Me Up wizard for local OSTree repositories with the following sections: 
 # *General:* How to configure the repository as the default repository for OSTree packages download 
 # *Deploy:* How to deploy packages
 # *Resolve:* How to download packages using the OSTree package manager 

h3. Acceptance Criteria

An Artifactory user with Read permission to a certain local OSTree repository can get to the Artifacts page in the UI, select a repository and get instructions in the Set Me Up wizard.

afaik Alex has some flag for that, to be run on any test.

FYI [~asafz]

column1: Adding max versions functionality for Maven releases repositories
column45:
After a while, there are artifact versions that are no longer usable (obsolete technology, breaking changes in the database, application decommissioned, etc.). It may justify cleaning up very old releases of an artifact, for exemple, to limit disk space.

Artifactory already has the capability to limit the number of SNAPSHOT versions of Maven repositories.

So It would be really useful to be able to run that same housekeeping on-demand on Maven releases version in the repository.

column1: Pull replication for remote OSTree repository
column45:
h3. Story

As an Artifactory admin user, I would like to be able to configure pull replication to a remote OSTree repository, so that I can pull OSTree repositories from a distant JPD to different JPDs in different data centers and make the repositories available to multiple teams spread globally. 
h3. Scope 

Ability to configure pull replication to a remote OSTree repository using the following methods: 
 # APIs:
 ## [Set Repository Replication Configuration|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-SetRepositoryReplicationConfiguration]
 ## [Update Repository Replication Configuration|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-UpdateRepositoryReplicationConfiguration]
 # UI 

h3. Acceptance Criteria
 # An Artifactory admin user can configure pull replication on a remote OSTree repository using one of the methods described in the Scope section.
 # Cron and event-based replication work properly and replicate the files properly upon events that happen in the repository.

column1: Push replication for local OSTree repository
column45:
h3. Story

As an Artifactory admin user, I would like to be able to configure push replication to a local OSTree local repository, so that I can sync the OSTree repository in one JPD with other JPDs in different data centers and make the packages available to multiple teams spread globally. 
h3. Scope 

Ability to configure push/multi-push replication to a local OSTree repository using the following methods: 
 # APIs:
 ## [Set Repository Replication Configuration|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-SetRepositoryReplicationConfiguration]
 ## [Update Repository Replication Configuration|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-UpdateRepositoryReplicationConfiguration]
 ## [Create Or Replace Local Multi-push Replication|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-CreateorReplaceLocalMulti-pushReplication]
 ## [Update Local Multi-push Replication|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-UpdateLocalMulti-pushReplication]
 # UI 

h3. Acceptance Criteria
 # An Artifactory admin user can configure push/multi-push replication on a local OSTree repository using one of the methods described in the Scope section.
 # Cron and event-based replication work properly and replicate the files properly upon events that happen in the repository.

column1: Search OSTree repositories and data in Artifactory - Remote repository
column45:
# 
h3. Story

An Artifactory user with Read permission to a Remote OSTree repository, should be able to search for "OSTree repositories" through the different artifact search APIs so I can get the different metadata for a certain package and use it to decide which package to use for my project. Moreover, I will be able to parse the API output and use the search results for my automation scripts. 
h3. Scope 

Add an ability to search for OSTree repositories from the different artifact search APIs and get details about each artifact, including its path in the repository. 

It should be possible for OSTree repositories by using the following APIs:  

 ## [Artifactory Query Language (AQL)|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-ArtifactoryQueryLanguage(AQL)]
 ## [Artifact Search (Quick Search)|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-ArtifactSearch(QuickSearch)]
 ## [Archive Entries Search (Class Search)|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-ArchiveEntriesSearch(ClassSearch)]
 ## [Property Search|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-PropertySearch]
 ## [Checksum Search|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-ChecksumSearch]
 ## [Pattern Search|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-PatternSearch]
 ## [Artifact Latest Version Search Based on Layout|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-ArtifactLatestVersionSearchBasedonLayout]
 ## [Artifact Latest Version Search Based on Properties|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-ArtifactLatestVersionSearchBasedonProperties]

column1: PHP local repository to create versions after parsing GitHub similar to packagist.org
column45:
*Problem description:* Currently, to deploy a composer package into an Artifactory repository you need to use Artifactory's REST API or the Web UI. This becomes a time-consuming task if there are hundreds of packages with hundreds of versions each.

*What is the expected behaviour:*
The packagist.org registry scans the GitHub repository and creates a version for tags that are present in GitHub. Eg: All tags from *[https://github.com/hybridauth/hybridauth.git]* in GitHub there is a version in *[https://packagist.org/packages/hybridauth/hybridauth.|https://packagist.org/packages/hybridauth/hybridauth]*
Can there be any automation like the above in Artifactory such that it creates package versions in Artifactory for each tag in Github in PHP repositories?
GitHub tags as shown below:

!image-2020-07-06-13-52-38-930.png|width=332,height=283!

has versions in packagist.org as shown below:

!image-2020-07-06-13-53-55-891.png|width=332,height=209!

column1: Allow to set lenientLimit at the zone level
column45:
Currently you can use Cross-Zone sharding:

"""

Sharding across multiple zones in an HA Artifactory cluster allows you to create zones or regions of sharded data to provide additional redundancy in case one of your zones becomes unavailable. You can determine the order in which the data is written between the zones and you can set the method for establishing the free space when writing to the mounts in the neighboring zones. 

"""

The problem is that when we set lenientLimit value, it applies to how many shards are down, not to how many zones are down. 

The goal is to be able to set a value for how many zones are "OK" to be down and still allow writes. This comes from the main purpose of cross-zone sharding, which is to maintain redundancy in different zones, while still allowing some of them to be down.

column1: Feature Request (php) PEAR and Pyrus Repositories
column45:
Artifactory does not support PEAR and Pyrus (Pear2) PHP Repositories (pear.php.net). It would be possible to use Artifactory repositories as local and remote pear channels by using 
{code:java}
# Look for a pear channel.xml at the specified url.
$ pear channel-discover artifactoryurl.com/pear
# Get packages using the /rest/ url specified in channel.xml and suggestedalias
$ pear install arti-pear/package
# Command would be received similar to artifactoryurl.com/pear/get/package{code}
For remote repos, the channel.xml URLs would need to be stored, but rewritten when served.

column1: Azure access token renewal
column45: We would like to request a new product feature to allow access tokens to be easily renewed from inside Azure service connections. In the absence of a proper SSO solution it seems we have only two options for service connections in azure basic auth or token based.    Assuming we wanted to use token based access with expiring tokens we need an easy way for developers to refresh or renew their tokens that exceeds a basic API call [https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Access+Tokens#AccessTokens-GeneratingRefreshableTokens].    Would it be possible to add a refresh button to the azure service connection in addition to bubbling up the expiration time for a given token?     If we wanted to expire tokens now for example, there is no indication on the service connection that the token has expired nor does it offer a way to easily regenerate or renew a token.     Can you please help to prioritize either a renew button in addition to the current verify button or some other semantics that would enable azure workflows to continue working seamlessly while supporting short lived token access without requiring manual intervention?

column1: remove encryption of values in system.yaml based on master.key
column45:
We run Artifactory on EC2 with Puppet as the Configuration Management tool.

When upgrading from 6.10.x to 7.x, a system.yaml is created in the migration process. The database password is inserted, along with many other values. When we capture that file and its values in Puppet the first time, it was a surprise to find that when the artifactory service was restarted that the DB password was then encrypted, which required recapturing the values again. Not only that, since we have an HA setup, the password is now different on each node. This is totally unhelpful for us. If someone is able to compromise access to Artifactory, we have other major issues. Operationally with Puppet it is more difficult to sustain the management of n passwords where n is the number of HA nodes in our cluster. We already have systems in place to keep the DB passwords encrypted and placed on the EC2 with Puppet. We don't need it obfuscated and different on each separate HA node. We would have a similar system in place in k8s if we were ever to migrate our Artifactory implementation there as well.

Please allow a configurable option for the password to be stored in plaintext in the system.yaml.

Hello 

We are raising this improvment/feature request in order to have a way or a plugin  to sync github teams with artifactory groups.

Actually we do not want to manage local groups with github users because it will be very difficult and time consuming).

 

 

Thanks in advance

 

Regaeds

column1: Signed URL Download: Validate HTTP method
column45:
h3. Story
* As JFrog, when a customer performs download using an RTF signed URL, I'd like to be able to validate they are using the GET HTTP method, so that they are not able to perform a security exploit by using the POST method 

h3. Scope
* Serve signed URL download only if method is GET

h3. Background
* Artifactory supports generating a signed URL using the api/signed/url end point. the following story refers to the scenario where the customer had already generated a signed URL using this API, and now calls the signed URL to download the content. While the API for *generating* a signed URL is used using the POST method,  the *download* itself should occur using the GET method (i.e. call the signed URL with a GET). In case the customer is able to use the signed URL using POST (i.e. if we don't validate the method when the signed URL is called), this may be exploited by attackers. 

h3. Acceptance Criteria 
* In case a customer attempts to perform a download using a JFrog signed URL, while using an HTTP method other than GET, the download should fail.

column1: Allow to change LDAP referrals strategy and socket timeout through the UI

Currently, the only way to change the LDAP referrals strategy or the socket timeout is by adding and adjusting the below properties in artifactory.system.yaml

artifactory.security.ldap.referralStrategy (The value can be either 'follow', 'ignore' or 'throw'. The default value is ‘follow’.)
artifactory.security.ldap.socket.timeoutMillis

It would be more accessible and easier to change the above properties in the UI, LDAP web page.

column1: Garbage Collector for Inactive High Availability Nodes
column45:
We're running Artifactory as a high availability cluster inside of our EKS-hosted Kubernetes cluster. While doing some routine maintenance we discovered that Artifactory does not ever clear out HA nodes that have failed their heartbeats, even after long periods of time.

I assume this behavior is because Artifactory was originally designed to run on bare metal/VMs that were expected to be durable, but on Kubernetes our nodes are containers that are constantly getting restarted, shifted around, terminated, etc and so there is a large buildup of nodes that have failed their heartbeats and are never going to come back, which leaves us with a large amount of cruft.

Speaking with JFrog support, it appears that the only way to clean these up is by manually deleting the old nodes via the UI, which is not an enjoyable experience (I'm currently staring at 19 pages worth of these dead nodes on our production cluster, for reference). Furthermore the documentation I found regarding deleting HA nodes mentions the possibility of these old nodes causing problems in the cluster overall: https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF6X/Managing+the+HA+Cluster#ManagingtheHACluster-RemovinganUnusedNode

My ask is to have a garbage collector added to Artifactory that can be configured to clean up nodes that have failed their heartbeat over a certain threshold. As an example, I could enable this new garbage collector on our Artifactory cluster to clean up any HA nodes that have failed their heartbeats for more than 24 hours and have the collector run once per day on a schedule.

column1: Active monitoring for replication
column45:
Hi Team,

I work for Hitachivantara and we have 6 artifactories, spread around different locations (4 in the US, 1 in Portugal and 1 AWS).

This artifactories have multiple repositories that are replicated between the artifactories, so that development teams located on those regions can access faster the necessary repositories.

Besides the window in Mission Control (for each artifactory configured there) to see how the replications are doing there is no other way to know about them all. Or to see if something failed we will need to go trough each individual artifactory log to see if an error has occurred.

It would be nice the have a way to configure sending warnings (via email for example) each time a replication fails to execute. And also to have them displayed in Mission control next to each replication.

column1: Use Crowd for group membership sync while using SAML for login
column45: We use Atlassian Crowd as a central component for a bunch of tools to store group memberships for users. So we used Crowd for logging in into Artifactory. We then switched to a SAML login because our IDP provides MFA. But when logging in using SAML group memberships aren't synced anymore for the user. Even worse, when logging in for the first time a user doesn't have any group membership. Problem is: our IDP can't pass the group memberships in the SAML response since it isn't connected to the Crowd. What we need is a simple sync (periodically) of all users - no matter of what realm, even SAML - with Crowd, thus receiving group memberships. Just like Jira and Confluence are doing when using SAML.

column1: Add option for Generic Virtuals to always host the latest file by timestamp
column45:
Currently, most virtual repos can automatically host the latest artifact from its child repos. This is not the case for Generic repos.

If a file with the same name has been uploaded to multiple generics within a virtual, then the virtual will always host the file from the first one in the list, regardless of the file's timestamp.

This is preventing us from using a mesh replication topology, since the virtuals are always hosting the first file in their repo lists rather than the latest file. Storing files under different names or folders for each version is not an option, because we still have metadata files that need to be in pre-defined locations.

Please add an advanced option to Generic Virtuals to always host the latest files by timestamp.

column1: Ent X on AWS MP: Upgrade from package to package
column45:
h3. Story 
* As an Enterprise X customer on AWS MP, I'd like to be able to upgrade my package to higher tier package, so I can enjoy the benefits of the new subscription 

h3. Guidelines
* AWS MP allows upgrading from a lower tier package to a higher tier package (e.g. Ent X Silver to Ent X Gold)

h3. Scope
* In case an AWS MP Enterprise X customer subscribed to package A, and then upgrades to package B (which is a higher tier package), then:
** When looking into MyJFrog the customer should see the label of the new package
** JFrog should begin reporting overage based on the new subscription's threshold . {color:#d04437}TBD - how to handle this if overage already reached in old subscription {color}

column1: Enterprise on AWS MP: ability to select package
column45:
h3. Story
* As a JFrog marketplace customer, I'd like to be able to select from several Enterprise X packages no AWS MP, so that I can choose the one that best fits my use case. 

h3. Scope
* When subscribing to Enterprise X on AWS MP, ability to select one of several packages
* In MyJFrog, display the package type selected by the customer  
* Report overage to AWS MP based on the selected package 

h3. Guidelines
* We're going to use a new type of SaaS product listing called SaaS Contract with consumption 
* We're going to support several Ent.X packages, each with its own base fee, pre-included amount of usage, and price for overage usage. The customer will be able to support one of those packages upon registration.  

h3. Out of scope
* Upgrade scenario - handled in separate story

h3. Acceptance Criteria
* Assuming the customer subscribes to JFrog Enterprise X on the AWS MP, and selects one out of several packages, THEN once they are redirected to the JFrog side and complete registration: 
** In MyJFrog, the customer should be able to see indication of the package they selected (e.g. in case the package is named 'JFrog Enterprise X Silver' then this text should be visible in MyJFrog ([~hagitd] to provide UI guidelines 
** In case the customer selected package A, and the amount of usage included in package A is X, then once the customer's usage crosses X, they should start getting charged for their overage (i.e. start reporting overage per the package's pre-included usage threshold)

19/Mar/20 9:57 AM;BalzGuenat;Not sure about that. Seems like Artifactory should support SHA-256 since v5.5: [https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/Checksum-Based+Storage#Checksum-BasedStorage-SHA-256Support]

And in my testing (with v6.10.9), .sha256 file haven been handled correctly, i.e. like .md5 or .sha1 files.
column251:
01/Apr/20 10:00 AM;evgenyka;From [https://docs.gradle.org/6.0/release-notes.html]:
Since 6.0.1, if your external repository doesn’t support SHA256 and/or SHA512 checksums, it is possible to disable upload of those checksums: * add {{-Dorg.gradle.internal.publish.checksums.insecure=true}} to the CLI or
 * add {{[systemProp.org|http://systemprop.org/]}}{{.gradle.internal.publish.checksums.insecure=true}} to your {{gradle.properties}} file

Since Artifactory not yet supports SHA512 checksum, please use this workaround as suggested by Gradle.
column252: 21/Jul/20 4:47 PM;goargo;Is there an ETA for this ? The workaround allows us to unblock them but we need this to be supported in the near future.
column253:
05/Oct/20 12:03 PM;mfriedenhagen;Possible workaround:
 * You may "easily" extend the list of {{application/x-checksum}} extensions in the {{/etc/opt/jfrog/artifactory/mimetype.xml}} file.
 * Then to my understanding of the Artifactory sourcecode it should be possible to *upload* SHA512 files.
 * Artifactory will not be able to synthesize {{sha512}} checksums for aggregated {{maven-metadata.xml}} files in virtual repositories, though.

column1: Allow to change response to 404 instead of 500 when binary is not found
column45:
A severe incident caused a number of blobs to not make it to S3.

That's a recoverable event for us, we can simply rebuild those artifacts, however Artifactory's behavior on a missing blob is to return a 500, which lead to unexpected downstream effects that took hours to remediate:

"errors" : [ {
 "status" : 500,
 "message" : "Could not process download request: sharding-cluster-eventual-s3 can't locate 1dabcdef1e in any of it's sub providers "
 } ]

 

That hard failure causes build tools to fail for cases where we'd be able to tolerate a missing artifact, for instance an Ivy xml file. A 404 would be more appropriate here given it's an unrecoverable failure and the binary is missing.

column1: Support of Artifactory cocoapods-remote repo connecting Alibaba mPaas Public repo
column45:
There is an urgent demand to connect to *Alibaba mPaas Public repo* in JFrog Artifactory. The source of the repo is _[https://code.aliyun.com/mpaas-public/podspecs.git]_.

The feature request is that  JFrog Artifactory cocoapods remote repo could support Alibaba mPaaS Public repo registry.

Following is the description of how to reproduce the issue regarding the failure of  JFrog Artifactory cocoapods remote repo supporting the Alibaba public repo registry.

We followed JFrog Artifactory wikipage to add and edit the remote repo. The _Repository Key_ is correctly set and the URL* option is filled. Clicking _Test_ button returns message telling us "Successfully connected to server". CocoaPods Settings is set as below while other options are filled with default values. Until now everything works well.

The above setting are saved and finished.

When we followed the *Set Me Up* procedures to add the Artifactory Specs repo:
{quote}pod repo-art add mPaaS-remote "[http://localhost:8081/artifactory/api/pods/mPaaS-remote]" --verbose
{quote}
the repo can' t be added succcessfully. According the info printed, Artifactory seems fail to cache the index of *Alibaba mPaas Public repo*.

!image-2020-02-03-12-11-47-507.png|width=533,height=360!
column46:
Artifactory-pro 6.17.0

Ruby 2.4.0p0

gem 2.7.10

pod 1.2.1

cocoapods-art plugin 1.0.2

The issue can be reproduced not limited to the the env above.  JFrog Support Team has also reproduced the issue and suggested me to open a feature request.

column1: Improve replication socket timeout
column45:
The socket timeout for replication appears to be a timeout on the whole of an individual artifact push. Even if data is being sent the timeout can trigger.

Preferably there would be two timeouts in the least. A timeout regarding the whole of the transfer and one based on the activity of that socket (IE... whether or not the data is flowing).

The problem is the lack of visibility into replication in general. If the timeout is too low and the data size too high relative to the network throughput then an artifact can never successfully replicate. Better to to allow slow replication than none at all.

column1: PHP Composer should add "composer.version" for remote artifacts
column45:
Currently, PHP remote repositories function by passing the remote metadata directly to the PHP client. This works well, but there is a fundamental difference between the remote PHP repository and a local PHP repository.

 

For local PHP repositories, Artifactory requires that a "composer.version" Artifactory Property be present. Without it, local PHP metadata will not be calculated. This metadata property needs to be set to the correct package version.

 

The problem is that PHP artifacts copied from a remote repository to a local repository will be missing this critical property. It cannot be filled in with a constant value, as the property is tied to the package's version.

 

For example, composer.version=1.0 means the package will always be "1.0" and will cause version mismatch issues.

 

Artifactory needs to be able to automatically calculate this metadata property on cached remote artifacts, otherwise User Plugins such as the remoteBackup plugin will not work.

 

A similar problem was solved for Debian packages as a part of RTFACT-21114.

column1: Support Ballerina Repositories
column45:
[Ballerina|https://ballerina.io/] is an open source programming language and platform. It is a network-distributed programming language, and its general syntax is based on C, Java, and JavaScript style. Ballerina is centered around a sequence diagram model and built upon unique abstractions that bring the network aspect into the programming language itself.

Ballerina is using [repositories|https://ballerina.io/learn/how-to-structure-ballerina-code/] to manage modules. The central Ballerina repository is https://central.ballerina.io

column1: OAuth integration PKCE challenge support
column45:
We are trying to integrate the Artifactory instance version with our corporate Open ID Connect Provider. The Artifactory instance does not support the PKCE challenge which is a requirement of the standard and of our OAuth provider.

We would like to have this implemented.

More information:
 * *Proof Key for Code Exchange* by OAuth Public Clients: [https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7636]

 
 * *OAuth 2.0 Security Best Current Practice*: [https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-oauth-security-topics-13]

 
h4. [3.1.1|https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-oauth-security-topics-13#section-3.1.1].  Authorization Code Grant

   Clients utilizing the authorization grant type *MUST use PKCE*   [[RFC7636|https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7636]] in order to (with the help of the authorization server)   detect and prevent attempts to inject (replay) authorization codes   into the authorization response.  The PKCE challenges must be   transaction-specific and securely bound to the user agent in which   the transaction was started and the respective client.     Note: although PKCE so far was recommended as a mechanism to protect   native apps, this advice *applies to all kinds of OAuth clients,*   *including web applications*.    Clients SHOULD use PKCE code challenge methods that do not expose the   PKCE verifier in the authorization request.  (Otherwise, the attacker   A4 can trivially break the security provided by PKCE.)  Currently,   "S256" is the only such method.

column1: Make SAML AuthnRequest namespace configurable
column45:
Currently, Artifactory uses org.opensaml.saml library to generate SAML auth request and the AuthnRequest namespace is hardcoded to be saml2p.

Example:

<saml2p:AuthnRequest
        xmlns:saml2p="urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:2.0:protocol"
        AssertionConsumerServiceURL="BLOCKEDbusiness[.]jfrog[.]org:8080/artifactory/webapp/saml/loginResponse"BLOCKED;
        ID="gjkllppmjpgaahhbgkjajmopcjnnmecpbdddhoda"
        IssueInstant="2012-12-04T14:13:06.021Z"
        ProviderName="business.jfrog.org"
        Version="2.0"
        >
    <saml2:Issuer
            xmlns:saml2="urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:2.0:assertion"
            >business.jfrog.org
    </saml2:Issuer>
</saml2p:AuthnRequest>

This will cause issue if the IDP is an ADFS 3.0 server as it is expecting a samlp namespace. 

When artifactory send this authnrequest to ADFS server, the request redirects to the IDP and an error message is given with no details.

If we directly login on the IDP server and redirect to Artifactory, the SAML SSO is working. The result is that the user can not use the SAML login icon on Artifactory to do the saml login.

The "saml2p" namespace is hardcoded right now and we should make this property configurable.

column1: API for write locker or move item with replacement
column45:
Our build script deploys artifacts to the same path of Artifactory in parallel build case. To avoid other build downloads the inconsistent artifacts from the path, we need a write locker for the specific path. Only the build getting the locker can deploy artifacts to the path, and release the locker after deploying. (workaround: file system locker, e.g. pylocker)

The alternative solution is moving the source path of the artifacts to the destination path. (please let me know if this is not atomic operation) The problem is "move" API will place the source path to the destination path if the destination path exists. User has to delete the destination path before moving, but in parallel build mode, other build may move artifacts after my build deletes the destination path. The problem can be solved by supporting replacement option in "move" API, which deletes all in destination path before moving. (workaround: one level destination path, e.g. /\{targetRepoKey}/targetPath instead of /\{targetRepoKey}/targetPath-1/targetPath-2/...)

column1: Replication cancel button and bandwidth limitation
column45:
Hello Team,

 

We would like to be able to pause and cancel an ongoing push or pull replication.

For example, the link gets congested and it negatively affects the overall performance of the organization. 

 

In addition to that, it would be nice to limit the bandwidth of a replication.

For example, there is a huge repository that needs to be replicated. We would like to be able to configure the max speed for that repository, in order to preserve the bandwidth. 

 

Thanks.

column249:
12/Feb/20 10:59 PM;mcarlton;I disagree with this. Any user with write/deploy permissions shouldn't be able to just go change things in the repository settings. If you want to give someone permissions to manage the repos they have manage permissions on, then the permissions for "manage" need to be separated out into user permissions and repo admin access. Making someone an admin over their repo just because they use it seems odd.

However, I do agree that the permissions for repos are a bit strange. I'm going to throw in another ticket. For example, if you have manage permissions you can change users and groups that have access to the repo. This seems a bit much permissions if you want to give someone the ability to just recalculate the metadata. I believe the recalculate permission should be part of annotate as it is already billed as: "Allows annotating artifacts and folders with metadata and properties." For instance: https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-CalculateNuGetRepositoryMetadata this should be under annotate or a new permission level, not manage.

column1: Fetch Properties for all artifacts in particular remote repos
column45:
Right now our deployments use *Property Search downloads* for non-unique SNAPSHOT artifacts.

We switched 1 Artifactory instance (6.14) to *Edge* and it's not possible to benefit from remote repos having the caching feature, cause it's not possible to resolve artifacts...

E.g. we use URL like:

_'http://URL:8081/artifactory/repo/com/inq/etl/+4.0-SNAPSHOT+/etl-+4.0-SNAPSHOT+.jar;+build.number++=6780;+build.name++=RT - C-RT - develop;+bamboo.timestamp+=1572635502'_

Requesting fetching props (meta-data) for all artifacts for a particular remote repo.

Client: Nuance

column1: separate queues and worker pool for _add and _delete operations
column45:
currently Artifactory lumps cluster-s3 adds and deletes into a single queue. If users delete alot of files, during a GC run, the queue will be filled with delete operations, which will backlog the adds until deletes are complete. Artifactory should:

1. prioritize adds over deletes - this may in include just letting the delete operations be temporarily suspended if the system is busy, like running low on available connections, db pool etc

2. allow for separate worker pools.

column1: Support custom sourceCategory when integrating Artifactory with sumo logic
column45:
The customer wants to have a custom _sourceCategory when querying for the logs in sumo logic after the integration.
At the moment we get the logs in sumo when querying _sourceCategory="/artifactory/request/" but the customer wants to have it modified as  _sourceCategory=" XXX/XXX/XXX/artifactory/request/".

Currently, we take "category" from the logback.xml and prepend "Artifactory" to it, but also require that the category in logback.xml be one of four values reflecting the log in question.

column1: Cocoapods CDN support
column45:
The Cocoapods has a CDN (as of a few months ago) is extremely fast for updates and package installations. For time comparison:

 

+Using Artifactory Cocoapods remote+

$ pod repo-art cocoapod-remote update

*43m 12s*

$ pod install (2 small packages)

*5.790s*

 

+Using Cocoapods CDN+

$ pod repo update

*1.212s*

$ pod install

*1.014s*

 

More info on the Cocoapods CDN: [http://blog.cocoapods.org/CocoaPods-1.7.2/]

 

Whatever Cocoapods implemented for their CDN is blazingly fast compared to the way Cocoapods used to be. Do you currently have any plans to implement some features to take advantage of the Cocoapods CDN for remote packages?

column249:
02/Jan/20 9:08 AM;pschneider_;Hi, as this is now the default since CocoaPods 1.8: 

Any news on supporting this CDN via Artifactory?
column250:
01/Oct/20 1:31 PM;eugene_dudnyk;Upvoting for this feature request.

Additional context from my side:

With CDN feature request, it is expected that with CocoaPods CDN Artifactory also does the proxying of both internal (from the intranet) and external (from CocoaPods CDN) dependencies, and performs caching (in the same way like it does now for Android with Maven repository layout).

In the Artifactory [documentation|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/CocoaPods+Repositories] on currently supported CocoaPods repository layout it is mentioned that the layout does caching for pods that are served by the author in the format of `tar.gz` archive, while with vanilla CocoaPods the most of the libraries are actually just cloned via git, and rarely are distributed as `tar.gz` archives. So, with the request to introduce CDN, it would be expected also to solve the issue of caching of libraries that are served from git repos in the corporate intranet.

column249:
07/Nov/19 11:46 AM;arielk;A possible approach to handle massive move/copy between repositories is:
1. get via AQL/CLI list of all artifacts you wish to move.
2. Run a script to move/copy, such as:
{code:java}
#!/bin/sh 

FILE=list.txt 
TOTAL=`cat $FILE | wc -l`

while read LINE
 do  
   echo $TOTAL left
   jfrog rt mv $LINE npm-promote-local
   sleep 0.1
   TOTAL=`expr $TOTAL - 1`
done < $FILE
{code}

column1: Deny Permission - On repositories
column45:
Hi

 

I would like to request the ability to Deny specific users / groups access to specific repositories.

This would allow for global permissions to be applied, but then restricted down if needed on a repo by repo basis with minimal changes to the global perms.

 

Eg I need to stop anonymous access to 2 out of 100 repo's , it would be simpler to just deny access to the specific repos for that user. Otherwise we need to change the default Anything permissions group, when adding a repo remember to add it to that group etc etc.

 

THis would also cater for abuse scenarios when a specific user could be locked out from that specific repo for  a period of time

 

Thanks

column1: Docker Image Fails to start with Oracle DB
column45:
The entrypoint-artifactory.sh file does a waitForDB check to access the database by parsing DB_URL.

 
{noformat}
jdbc:oracle:thin:@<tns_entry>?TNS_ADMIN=<directory of the wallet> 
{noformat}
For a URL that uses a TNS entry this doesn't work, presumably because the hostname is in the tnsnames.ora and not the URL. To get around this one has to modify the entry point and remove the check.

Artifactory standalone in fact works fine with this DB configuration.

A possible solution would be to include a property that tells the startup to ignore this check (DB_CHECK_IGNORE) or find some other way to verify the DB is up.

column1: Add option to change the username Artifactory takes from SAML SSO (NameID)
column45:
Currently, Artifactory is designed to use the SAML SSO NameID parameter for a user's username. There should be a way to update this behavior so another field can be used instead.

Artifactory already supports a custom field for the user's email, another block can be used for the username format.

By default, the NameID is the correct SAML field to use for a username. Some organizations have other use cases:
 * They have an AD service, and want to use the AD username that isn't passed as a nameID
 * A "unique" string is used instead of a human-readable username

column249: 18/Jun/20 1:37 PM;PatG;We have the same issue (we're using an AD).
column250:
18/Jun/20 3:56 PM;jcmartin;Hi @Patrick Russell,

We've the same feature request.

You used (Artifactory) :
{code:java}
<ns2:NameIDFormat>urn:oasis:names:tc:SAML:1.1:nameid-format:unspecified</ns2:NameIDFormat> {code}
In my case, I can overide this NameID, with a relying party profile for Artifactory SP in my IDP configuration. (@Patrick, if you've the control of the idp configuration, you can do like this)
{code:java}
bean parent="SAML2.SSO"
      p:nameIDFormatPrecedence="urn:oid:1.1.1.1.1" /> {code}
where urn:oid:1.1.1.1.1 is your custom employeeID attribute.

But, in order to simplify most SAML IDP admin, and all organizations

i think you could considered to introduce like you do with the user's email attribute in the Saml configuration panel, all standard fields and associate saml mapping field :
 * username
 * firstname
 * lastname

Best regards.

JC

column1: Artifactory AQL/REST Get Artifacts and Versions
column45:
Currently it is possible to retrieve artifacts per AQL or REST-Api.
* Retrieving it per AQL allows to retrieve the meta-artifacts, within which the Artifact+Version information is available, or retrieve the information from properties (e.g. as it is the case for docker-images)
* Retrieving it per REST returns the actual artifacts path, which may not contain the meta-information (artifact-name, version, all versions, etc) or be usable to retrieve version information

All versions for an artifact can be retrieved through the meta-artifacts (e.g. maven-metadata.xml) or REST (the artifact-name is required, which is not returned through REST artifact search).
* This search returns the version associated with an artifact, but does not include the path to the artifacts behind this version.

Because of all this, should you have a use-case that requires a list of all artifacts, their versions and paths towards these versions, then you may have to use a combination of multiple AQL and REST calls - only becoming even more should a DELETE based on artifact+version be added.

Therefore it is better to query the meta-artifacts of all artifacts within a repository and parse these to build your context. Be warned that this can be tedious if you use many different package-types, as some have XML-files, some require properties-querying and some use JSON.


----
Instead of all of this it would be better if there were a REST endpoint that returns the following meta-information of all artifacts (or artifacts beneath a certain path) within a repository:
* Artifact-Name
* Path to meta-artifact
* Artifact-Versions
* For each version
** The path to the version-folder / version-artifact

With this it would be easy to get an overview of the artifacts and versions and easily run additional GET queries or a DELETE.

25/Sep/19 3:52 PM;ken.martindale;One potential command-line workaround might look something like:

export URL=https://artifactory.domain.com/artifactory/myrepo/folder/
curl -s $URL|sed 's/<[^>]*>//g;/:[0-9]/!d'|sort -k2.8b,2.11bnr -k2.4b,2.6Mbr -k2b,2bnr -k3br

However, a command like the above is somewhat fragile and may not work in all cases.  Users have become accustomed to Fancy Index style browser listings that offer the ability to sort ascending/descending by column and would find it very helpful if Artifactory also offered that functionality.

column1: Add Cache-Control headers for static resources
column45:
Static UI resources served from {{/webapp/}} already contain the build number to cache break between releases but do not set a {{Cache-Control}} header to allow the browser to cache these files.

That causes revalidations for these resources on initial load or on click paths that cause a reload of the page. Given these are static an indefinite (i.e. 1y) {{max-age}} and an {{immutable}} directive would seem appropriate - https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Cache-Control#Revalidation_and_reloading.

column1: Label and persist the "artifactory_extra_conf" Docker volume even if it is empty
column45:
Currently, the Artifactory Docker image contains a separate volume for the artifactory_extra_conf folder. If a user doesn't explicitly set the volume, the Docker CLI still reserves the space as a Volume:

 

$ docker volume ls

local 38f7c0ba8d2f8dca7c0013306266566f20ed7899695290e5c68a05345f18102f

local 205afe465683cdc02b469129a291c261ab96a8898e15f98277ffde710612aa8e

local 9475de101d2ae6252fb11e5b3bab323193b578b4f8a32e805c01220afa30ae5f

 

Another unlabeled volume is created whenever the container is created or restarted. This volume should be labeled so it is persisted.

27/Sep/19 5:05 PM;dshapiro;Thanks for creating this, [~patrickr].

 

The concern is mostly around the perspective of someone who is managing the host machine or a DevOps engineer doing a `volume ls`.


A large list with GUID's as names presents the following issues:
 * It isn't possible to understand what system the volume associates to by simply looking at the name.
 * It creates so many of these volumes that the noise drowns out the easing of browsing the volume list. For example, if I'm looking for volume "foo" in a huge list of volumes, it becomes much more difficult.

column1: Make the Artifactory user discoverable in HTTP requests
column45:
In order to better support authenticated requests at our caching layer we have in front of Artifactory, we'd like a method for determining which Artifactory user initiated the request.  It would be easiest for us to deal with if this could piggyback in the HTTP request headers.  That way, if the cache would produce a cache-hit, we could serve from cache without involving AF in the request (thus helping us scale better).  Ideally, the user information would be exposed in a consistent way across different repo types.

Also note, we'd need something like https://www.jfrog.com/jira/browse/RTFACT-19753 to use in conjunction with this feature.
