column1: NPM dependency metadata caching
column45:
With npm remote repos, we are finding the following use case with dependencies between packages ending up with an error message during builds. 

Background: 
 * We are publishing multiple packages directly to the public npm registry.
 * We do not want to publish to both the public registry and the local Artifactory instance.
 * We needed to increase the value of the Metadata Retrieval Cache Period because we were making to many requests to the public registry from Artifactory.

Summary of problem:
Development group releases a large volume of packages with new versions that depend on each other at the latest version. As the meta data (package.json) for packages trickles into Artifactory (because of the expiration of Metadata Cache), the dependencies which are pointing to the latest version aren't resolving because Artifactory hasn't updated the dependencies meta data yet.
 
Example:
Package A v1.0.0 depends on Package B v1.0.0
 
Public NPM contains:
Package A v1.0.0
Package B v1.0.0
 
Artifactory contains:
Package A v1.0.0
Package B v1.0.0
 
Package B v1.1.0 is released
Package A is updated to depend on B v1.1.0
Package A v 1.1.0 is released
 
Public NPM contains:
Package A v1.1.0
Package B v1.1.0
 
Package A meta data expires and Artifactory updates metadata for Package A
Package B meta data has not expired and remains the same.
 
Artifactory contains:
Package A v1.1.0
Package B v1.0.0
 
Npm install run using Artifactory and fails when Package B v1.1.0 is not found.
 

It seems like there needs to be an additional query to the remote repo for NPM dependencies that are not found in Artifactory.  We want to avoid decreasing the time for the metadata cache retrieval.  Can Artifactory handle this a different way for these inter dependencies where if a dependency is not found in Artifactory that it can force a lookup to the remote.  Or when caching an artifact, search through and look for these dependencies and if there are any versions missing from the local cache then also cache those packages from the source remote site.

column1: Allow Artifactory to Serve Go Modules Vanity URLs
column45:
When users have a module using a custom module path, they need to create a Vanity URL server to translate the module name to the actual source location.

Artifactory users should be able to use it as a Vanity URL server so they do not need to set up an additional component to resolve their modules.

*+Additional Details+*

When you create a Go module, the path you declare in your go.mod file to identify it is used by the Go client to reach out to the source. That is why most of the Go modules we see out there look like github.com/<ORG>/<REPO_NAME>.

So what if I want to name my module something else, let's say myorg.com/mymodule. Somehow, when the Go client is trying to fetch it, I need to point out where the source content actually is. That is why vanity urls were introduced. Under https://myorg.com?go-get=1 I need to serve some html content with meta tags that have information about where the source code lives. The response for that request could be something like this:

<html>
<meta name="go-import" content="myorg.com/mymodule git https://github.com/myorg/mymodule">
</html>

So for my module to work properly, I need a web server listening for that request under my custom path and serving this content.

I think the ask here is, since customers also want to use Artifactory to proxy and cache those modules, if it is possible to avoid having to setup another webserver just to serve those meta tags and use Artifactory for that as well, by setting up some mapping rules in the format Module Path --> Source Location and pointing the DNS rules for those custom module paths to Artifactory.

One important thing to keep in mind is that vanity urls are ignored by the Go client when you have the GOPROXY environment variable set, since the client will delegate to the proxy to serve the content. However, they are still going to be needed by the proxy so it can find and fetch the content before serving it.

Another important thing is, if all consumers are resolving your modules from Artifactory (GOPROXY set) you don't need vanity urls at all as long as you push your modules to Artifactory directly. Even though this should be the recommended approach, we still see people wanting to proxy their source repositories, which makes vanity urls needed.

Also, I'm not sure if Artifactory knows how to use vanity urls as a client at this moment. I was trying to resolve sigs.k8s.io/yaml@v1.2.0 using a remote pointing to GitHub and it did not work.

Here is some good reading about the vanity urls:
- https://medium.com/@JonNRb/making-a-golang-vanity-url-f56d8eec5f6c
- https://sagikazarmark.hu/blog/vanity-import-paths-in-go/
- https://golang.org/cmd/go/#hdr-Remote_import_paths

column1: Please add include/exclude patterns to the 409 error message response
column45:
Hi Allen,

As for your recommendation to include the 'include'/'exclude' patterns to the body of the error, you are more than welcome to create an improvement request for this.

There is an option to submit a feature request on our [public JIRA|https://www.jfrog.com/jira/secure/Dashboard.jspa].
In order to submit a feature request, you will need a JIRA account.

You can submit a request for a JIRA account [here|https://www.jfrog.com/jira/secure/Signup!default.jspa].
As you may know, our roadmap is tightly scheduled according to community feedback.

Thank you for your cooperation.

Best regards,
David Pinhas
JFrog Support

 
Hey Guys,
 
I'm getting 409's, from artifactory and it would reduce the back and forth between a mere mortal, and the artifactory admins if the error specified what the current settings are.
 
For example:
 
[409] {
  "errors" : [ {
    "status" : 409,
    "message" : "The repository 'release-local' rejected the artifact 'release-local:com/allen/lib/1.0.4/allen-lib-1.0.4.jar' due to its include/exclude pattern settings."
  } ]
 
It would be better to have:
 
[409] {
  "errors" : [ {
    "status" : 409,
    "message" : "The repository 'release-local' rejected the artifact 'release-local:com/allen/lib/1.0.4/allen-lib-1.0.4.jar' due to its include/exclude pattern settings:  include:  'com/allen/**;  exclude: 'com/allen/lib/allen*.jar'"
  } ]
 
 
Right now, I'm going back and forth, and not sure why my jar no longer publishes.   :)

column1: Support Artifactory authentication to Azure MSSQL using Azure Active directory
column45:
Use case:
In order to enhance security, some customers would wish to tell the MSSQL connection that you want to authenticate the user from ActiveDirectory instead of MSSQL Local users.

Flow:
Artifactory requests a token against MSI endpoint with, and authenticate against Azure AD.
Azure AD returns a token and Artifactory will use it in order to get a connection to MSSQL.

The jdbc url looks as follows:
jdbc:sqlserver://<dbsrv>.database.windows.net:1433;database=<dbname>;authentication=*ActiveDirectoryMSI*;encrypt=true;trustServerCertificate=false;hostNameInCertificate=*.database.windows.net;loginTimeout=30;

As you can see we do not pass username+password as part of the JDBC URL.

column1: Simplifying Build Info creation
column45:
As an Artifactory user, I want to create a Build Info based on other Build Infos in Artifactory

 

Use case :
 * Each dev team publishes its own (CI) Build Info
 * The final product is made of several CI Build Info results (generated artifacts)
 * To test the final product, the integration/release team will pick up all the artifacts flagged specific properties and create a "System" Build Info.

 

Right now, you have 2 possibilities to implement this :
 # using the JFrog CLI with or without filespec
 # using the Build Upload Rest API

 

Here are the drawbacks of solution :
 # you have to have all the artifacts on the machine hosting the JFog CLI So first you'll have to do a massive downloads, define the build Info locally and and then only publish it.
 # building the JSON file isn't that trivial

 

The solution would be to have a simpler RestAPI to create a Build Info which could take a list of properties or AQL query for each module of the Artifact section and the same for the dependency section

column1: CRAN rewrite external dependencies
column45:
Currently when a user installs an r package there might be some dependency package downloads triggered by this package if some conditions are not met. Now the dependency package download URLs might be inside this r package and those URLs might point to repository in the internet.

In our environment we have servers that don't have access to public internet so ALL downloads should be through our Artifactory. So I would like to request feature of rewriting these URLs to Artifactory URLs instead so users will be able to install even the dependency packages via Artifactory.

 

Similar feature for NPM:  [https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/npm+Registry#npmRegistry-AutomaticallyRewritingExternalDependencies]

column1: Extend AQL to support regex
column45:
I have need to query the path of an artifact using AQL but to match any number (0 or more) of characters except a certain character. In short, I am looking to use the following regex:
[^\/]* as part of my query. My use case is the following:



I want to store artifacts in the following way inside the repo

dir1/dir2/dir3/\{rest of directory structure}

I want to search items based on their path. I want to use wildcards when matching on the three top-level directories names. So if my items are stored under:
foo/bar/123/
I want to be able to search for:
oo/ar/23
fo/ba/12
foo/bar/123
and get this as a result but I want to also be able to not give it any values and get it as a result like searching for */*/*.
At the same time I may have the following directory structures in the repo:
dir1/dir2/dir3/foo/bar/123
foo/dir2/dir3/bar/123

In these cases I don't want these to show up in my results when I'm searching for foo/bar/123. In other words, I only care about the three top-level folders in the repo but for those three I want to search based on wildcards even if I don't know their exact names.

I've come up with the following regular expression to match path on:

[^\/]*\{dir1-searchvalue}[^\/]*/[^\/]*\{dir2-searchvalue}[^\/]*/[^\/]*\{dir3-searchvalue}[^\/]*

With this bit [^\/]* I am trying to match 0 or more of any character except / since / is a delimiter between the directories in the item path.

column1: prohibit password reuse for a minimum of six (6) generations for internal JFrog user
column45:
Exact description from the customer.

Finding/Business Risk
An insufficiently long password history allows authorized users to reuse old passwords with greater ease and frequency.  This more readily enables brute-force attacks and password predictability, elevating the attacker’s chances to gain account access.



Failed Test/Vulnerability Description
Applications track the password history so that the password setting mechanism ensures users set unique passwords different from the limited history of the user’s previously used passwords.  If prior password history isn’t tracked for comparison, or if the tracked history consists of a consistently small set of prior passwords, then a user will be able to more easily revert to an old password in a short period of time.  For internal users whose password settings are not CMS EUA-managed, the password policy must meet ARS 3.1 guidelines.



Actual Test Results
On the password reset page for an “internal” user (not LDAP-issued) account, the user was able to specify a new password that matched the old password.  The new credentials were accepted by the application.

Multiple internal user accounts were discovered in IMP.   However, the majority of JFrog user accounts in PROD are managed by EUA password policy aside from one internal admin account on PROD, and only other admins have the ability to view the list of user accounts and usernames to determine which users are actually internal accounts.



Recommended Corrective Action
Configure the application to prohibit password reuse for a minimum of six (6) generations for internal JFrog user accounts.

column1: Permissions mechanism around Virtual
column45:
What we are looking for is to have permissions around virtual repositories. 

Similar to how we assign users permissions per repository, it would be beneficial if we are able to assign permissions to virtual repositories for local and remote repositories. 

This way, we can allow users to interact with virtual repositories only, and local and remote can be in the background, managed by admins. 

The flow would be like:
 # Assign users/groups permissions to Virtual (read, annotate, deploy/cache, etc)
 # Assign the virtual repo permissions to affiliated remote/local (read, deploy/cache, etc)

This way, users will not see or interact in any fashion with remote nor local repositories, and only have to interact with the virtual repositories.

The reason for this schema is to ensure least amount of confusion when users interact with the "set me up" section. Currently there is no way to prevent the user from interacting with remote and local because if prevent via permissions, they will then be unable to interact with virtual as well.

column1: Gradle Remote Cache Repository Type
column45:
As an Artifactory Enterprise consumer, I would like to leverage Artifactory for Gradle Remote Cache functionality in the form of a repository.

There are more details on Gradle's site: [https://docs.gradle.com/build-cache-node/]

 

Essentially, gradle (open source and enterprise) has the ability to use a standalone JAR that when executed will listen on tcp port(s) to allow the gradle build agent to get and push a shared cache amongst many desperate build agents.  The performance increases are very well documented and reduce build time by at least half in most cases.  Having an enterprise license does unlock additional features - but just having the ability for this to be housed in artifactory would be amazing for us!

 

[https://docs.gradle.com/build-cache-node/#running]

column1: Support repomd.xml which contains base URL location
column45:
Currently, if the repomd.xml file contains base URL in the location of the files, for example:
{code}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<repomd xmlns="http://linux.duke.edu/metadata/repo" xmlns:rpm="http://linux.duke.edu/metadata/rpm">
 <revision>1561627986</revision>
<data type="filelists">
  <checksum type="sha256">f1f584978d9f219cc2cf874896dc2a089310c7f426c2e2787c69038867c6503e</checksum>
  <open-checksum type="sha256">8b9e69840ee8914bfae0ce1a2bf1f43a6cc660a35b5661e567682520479d9c16</open-checksum>
  <location xml:base="http://myrpmserver.com" href="repodata/f1f584978d9f219cc2cf874896dc2a089310c7f426c2e2787c69038867c6503e-filelists.xml.gz"/>
  <timestamp>1561627986</timestamp>
  <size>339</size>
  <open-size>663</open-size>
</data>
...
{code}
Then, the client gets the repomd.xml file from Artifactory, but the actual packages will be downloaded directly from the base URL, bypassing Artifactory, i.e. the packages will not be cached to Artifactory.

For comparison, the regular repomd.xml (without the base URL) looks like this (from http://mirror.centos.org/centos/6/updates/x86_64/repodata/repomd.xml)
{code}
<repomd xmlns="http://linux.duke.edu/metadata/repo" xmlns:rpm="http://linux.duke.edu/metadata/rpm">
<revision>1561549848</revision>
<data type="filelists">
<checksum type="sha256">
d38f0ffe2d0640f387496cdf92c3d8176dd0de2d239ff9ae5ccbe1cfe1a77922
</checksum>
<open-checksum type="sha256">
8dada2fc86b616248e3c3c178822a718748880c4184102eab3e3eb2bbc8701d5
</open-checksum>
<location href="repodata/d38f0ffe2d0640f387496cdf92c3d8176dd0de2d239ff9ae5ccbe1cfe1a77922-filelists.xml.gz"/>
<timestamp>1561549862</timestamp>
<size>4822157</size>
<open-size>87719739</open-size>
</data>
...
{code}

*Steps to reproduce:*

1. Run 2 Docker Centos images - 1 for the RPM server and  1 for the yum client

2. On the server:
- Create a folder and put an rpm package in it
- Run the following command to create the repomd repository:
{code}
createrepo . -u http://avivcentos
{code}
The -u flag specifies the base URL. More info here: https://linux.die.net/man/8/createrepo

3. Still on the server:
- Install Nginx and put the following in /etc/nginx/conf.d/repos.conf:
{code}
server {
        listen   80;
        server_name  avivcentos;	#change  test.lab to your real domain
        root   /root/aviv;
        location / {
                index  index.php index.html index.htm;
                autoindex on;	#enable listing of directory index
        }
}
{code}
- Reload Nginx, now your server is ready to be used

4. On Artifactory:
- Create an RPM remote repository and point it to http://avivcentos
- Use the set me up to configure the Centos client

5. On the client:
- After configuring the above, run yum update
- Run yum install for the package from step 2
- yum should install the requested package
However, while repodata/repomd.xml file *will be cached to Artifactory*, the *actual package will not*. The client bypassed Artifactory in order to download the package.

column1: Add ability to block download of an artifact in virtual repo if Xray is blocking the download in any of the aggregated repos
column45:
Currently, if you have two repos with the same artifact in a virtual repo, with only 1 repo blocking the artifact, the artifact will be downloaded.

 

There should be a way to have a virtual repo fail the download if it detects that any of its aggregated repositories are blocking the download. Otherwise, the user will need to manually add each repo in the virtual to a Xray watch.

column1: Add REST API endpoint enabling a user to post Artifactory plugin code
column45:
As a developer, I'd like to have an admin-only accessible endpoint allowing a user to call a REST endpoint to modify/update and add new Artifactory plugin code, consuming  text/x-groovy-source. 

 

There should be a POST to add a new plugin file, and a PUT to modify a preexisting file. 

 

This would save a lot of time and complexity regarding SSHing onto the boxes to add a plugin file to the /etc/plugins directory, before calling the REST endpoint to reload plugins.

column1: Provide package metadata calculation metrics, statistics and performance info
column45:
Summary:

This is a request to have Artifactory reporting *package metadata* calculation statistics, metrics and performance info.

Some examples/ideas:

1. E.g. Debian Metadata, how many *metadata artifacts* (Release, Packages..) are being created *right now* for a certain repo
2. Last calculation time, result, new added metadata files
3. How many artifacts have yet to have metadata calculated for
4. Create a performance KPI for metadata artifacts calculation 

Users could potentially gain these insights:

1. See 'what work is being done by Artifactory' currently (for the packages metadata calculation context)
2. Understanding if the system could be capped (insufficient resource, threads allocated) 
3. Measure if and how a system tune up, be it hardware, JVM, or Artifactory system parameters affect the metadata calculation performance

column1: Artifactory Cleanup Policy
column45:
Artifactory currently supports only a ‘Deployment-Based’ Cleanup Policy (Limiting the number of snapshots in Docker repositories for example) along with the AQL and the User-Plugins that can give some solution to Artifactory users' needs. Requesting for Cleanup Policy feature which will allow deleting binaries based on the properties parameters such as: 
 # Last date of usage.
 # Last date of download.
 # The number of times downloaded.
 # The number of packages available.
 # Etc.

column1: Distribution should use the same permissions as Artifactory. It should not be globally read only.
column45:
Current Distribution has global read access to all Artifactory repositories and content.

it allows any Distribution User to create a bundle and push to the Edge any artifacts from any Artifactory repository.

this breaks security model, where Artifactory Permission limits access to one or another repo or folder of the repo to have Enterprise required security.

One team should not access content or another team.

One team or User should be able create bundle from only available artifacts that are  allowed by Artifactory Permission and nothing else.

We need proper enforcement of content protection and current Distribution is security hole with global read access.

 

Please, provide appropriate integration of Distribution to Artifactory to use and enforce the same permissions.

Without this feature we can't Use Distribution and as result Edge Nodes and E+ overall

column1: Replication between Artifactory and GCP
column45:
Currently, live replication between Artifactory on-prem and GCP buckets, is not supported. In this situation, there is no artifactory involved on the GCP side. 

The user in this situation, pulls the artifacts from the registry and then uses them in GCP. Occasionally, the pull fails and as a result, GCP is not up to date.

Whenever an artifact is added,modified, deleted in artifactory, is there a way to replicate in GCP. Almost, like a 'hot' replicate

Basically, we have a need for replicating artifacts to Google cloud.
Ref. Ticket # 103863

column1: Support for PackageCloud.io Public Registry by Using Apt-Get
column45:
Steps to reproduce:

 
 # Create Debian Remote pointing to packagecloud.io (I tried many combinations with the URL to make it work, but no luck.)
 # Select that Debian Repo from Repository Browser and follow the steps under: "Set Me Up"
 # Run sudo apt-get <package_name> 
 # Will not be downloaded and nothing in the request.log.

 

Note: Since packagecloud also serves RPM type packages,the issue also affects resolving RPM packages from the packcloud.io 

 

Workarounds:
 # Create 6 Remote Debian repositories that point to the following URLs:

[https://packagecloud.io/sensu/stable/packages/ubuntu/cosmic]

[https://packagecloud.io/sensu/stable/packages/ubuntu/bionic]

[https://packagecloud.io/sensu/stable/packages/debian/jessie]

[https://packagecloud.io/sensu/stable/packages/debian/stretch]

[https://packagecloud.io/sensu/stable/packages/ubuntu/trusty]

[https://packagecloud.io/sensu/stable/packages/ubuntu/xenial]

 

2. Aggregate all those Remote repositories in one Virtual Debian repository

3. Using either wget or curl download desired packages:

Example:

wget [http://localhost:8081/artifactory/debian-virtual/sensu-go-agent_5.1.1-0ubuntu18.1_amd64.deb]

 

curl -X GET -uadmin:password [http://localhost:8081/artifactory/debian-virtual/sensu-go-agent_5.0.1_amd64.deb]

column1: Access Token CRUD API
column45:
The current API for access tokens doesn't provide CRUD operations.

In particular there is no API for getting information about a specific token and the [creation API|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-CreateToken] doesn't return the IDs used within the [get tokens|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-GetTokens] call. This makes it impossible to query the current state of a token, or even its existence.

For context I am trying to create an addition to the [terraform provider|https://github.com/atlassian/terraform-provider-artifactory] that allows it to create access tokens for use by CI, however, without a proper CRUD API this isn't possible.

column1: Artifactory onboarding solution
column45:
I want to discuss a user story with you:

We want to manage repository configuration and permissions of Artifactory on an advanced level.

Key facts:
 * More than 700 repositories in and growing.
 * More than 10k fluctuating ldap groups.
 * Permissions are granted based on ldap groups.
 * Configuration of repositories and permissions have to be versionized.
 * Changes on repos have to be checked before they get rolled out to artifactory. Checks like:
 * Is the user that requested the changes in a ldap group that has permissions for a repo
 * Are changes valid? E.g. does the repo exist that is added to a virtual repository.

 

Any suggestions about how to handle this?

column1: Limit replication according to exclude/include patterns configured on repository
column45:
When using replication, it would be nice if the include/exclude pattern of the target repository would be taken into account when determining which artifacts shall be replicated.

 

The usage of include patterns for replication tasks is not suitable in case the source repository has more than 200 "trees" and only two or three shall be excluded from replication.

 

Example:

Currently the only way to exclude some artifacts from being transferred into the target Artifactory repository when using push replication is setting exclude patterns on the target repository itself. The replication process indeed still tries to upload all artifacts to the target repository, even in case the target repository has an exclude pattern configured for a complete artifact tree (Maven artifact repository, excluding for example "com/**/*", "org/**/*"). Due to trying to upload those artifacts, excessive bandwidth usage may be the result, causing hundreds of gigabytes of artifacts being transferred before finally being rejected by the receiving Artifactory instance.

 

Suggestion:

Either extend replication tasks to offer exclude patterns, or take the exclude patterns of the receiving Artifactory instance into account for replication (would require publishing/reading of exclude patterns to the source Artifactory server).

 

(I've not yet tested if this issue also appears to pull replication, as pull replication is not an option due to firewall rules.)

column1: Tagging repositories
column45:
Repository configuration has two fields that can carry information important for users (description) and admins (internal notes). Internal notes are good for human readable descriptions. But in case of automations, set of tags (key->value) that admin (and possibly user) could configure for repository would be helpful. 

On an example, let's say we have repository Tiers that have different rules/SLAs specified. As an admin, I would want to tag certain repositories with tier=1. Or, the repository has an owner, so we tag it with owner=user123.

This means, the keys for tags would not be predefined and could be defined by admins themselves, similar to PropertySets.

column1: Allow adding user/group/repo to permissions via REST API
column45:
If I understand your docs correctly, currently the only way to add/delete *user/group/repositories* to/from existing permission target is to GET the data, modify it and send it back. It would be super helpful to have calls that allow performing said operations directly, without processing the data on client's end.

Here's the list of calls:
 * configure user in PT (permission target), e.g.
{noformat}
 POST/PUT /api/security/permissions/{PT}/user/{USER}/grants/{RIGHTS} {noformat}
with POST/PUT for adding/overriding grants

 * delete user from PT
 * the same as two above but for groups
 * add repository (repositories) to PT
 * delete repo/repos from PT

column1: Add scan priority
column45:
Feature request add scan priority

there are scenarios where the scanning que is under high load in some cases you need scanning of certain artifacts to be prioritized 

Prio 1: scan of artifacts with blocked download (including unscanned artifacts) / fail build policy to be prioritized over other artifacts 

Prio 3: scan of new commited / pushed artifacts / pulled/ synchronized artifacts (from remote repo)

Prio 4: scan of existing rescan artifacts  

add feature scan now (any artifact can also be rescan) and should be executed directly 

perhaps even add the ability to configure priorities ourselves based on above

column249:
12/Apr/19 8:47 PM;mai.yang;We only want to enable anonymous access for certain public remote repos and very few namespaces in the local repos. The majority of local repos and namespaces are still protected. Credentials hence authentication challenges are still needed to access the protected files. We have a lot of internally developed python code that expects the authentication challenging behavior. They now break. From our view, the same python code should get the same result when accessing the same protected files, regardless anonymous is enabled or not for other files. Credential based interactions should continue to operate the same way. 

Here is what I propose how to solve this problem: Jfrog can create a system property that enables/disables the credential challenging behavior for protected files after anonymous access is turned on. The default is not challenging (current state). The majority of your customers will not be impacted as a result. But we can change this setting to force a credential challenge for protected files. This way, we only need to change this system setting in artifactory.system.properties, and no need to change any the existing python code.

column1: Restart Artifactory service after update
column45:
Debian-repo-based Artifactory updates (applied by APT in Ubuntu) stop, patch, and opt not-to-restart the Artifactory service. Rather, they advise the administrator to start and check Artifactory from the shell. This manual restart process does not work well with our automated system updates.

Would JFrog please consider an installation option that allows clients to specify whether or not (default might be not) to restart the Artifactory service after update?

column1: Adding the option to monitor repository actions
column45:
It seems that at the moment there is no option to trigger log information for repository actions such as: create, delete, modify etc.

Currently, the access.log only shows the following for repository events: 

{code:java}
2019-03-17 14:17:56,780 [ACCEPTED CONFIGURATION_CHANGE]  for admin/82.81.195.5. 
{code}

This JIRA is to request the support of triggering such information through the logs. 

A good solution for example can be adding the option to User-Plugins. 
From looking at the [PAPI for repsitories|http://repo.jfrog.org/artifactory/libs-releases-local/org/artifactory/artifactory-papi/%5BRELEASE%5D/artifactory-papi-%5BRELEASE%5D-javadoc.jar!/org/artifactory/repo/Repositories.html], there is no option for the above.
column109: Test Template

column1: Regex-like include/exclude patterns
column45:
Request for a more regex-like include/exclude pattern matching engine for Artifactory (or at the very least, support the sed-like plus function (+) of having one or more of a repeating character.  For example:

 

In a fully sed-like fashion:

com/company/*+/\d+\.\d+\.\d+/.*

 

Which would require any upload to this repository to have com/company followed by anything in front of another / followed by a requirement to have three series of numbers of any length separated by periods (ie 2.2.1 or 12.2.1 or 6.12.42 and so on) and then a / followed by anything.

 

Alternatively, we could have the Ant style pattern and just add the + for the repeating matches--

This would solve a lot of efficiency issues with creating and setting patterns for include/exclude where we insist on maintaining a rule to enforce version numbering in a specific field.

 

com/company/*/?+.?+.?+/**

column1: Common Global Locking Infrastructure
Support GELF logging
column45:
It would be nice to be able to log via GELF from Artifactory straight to a central log server possibly with this library: [https://github.com/mp911de/logstash-gelf]

 

It should be as easy as adding these lines to the project pom.xml:
{code:java}
<dependency>
    <groupId>biz.paluch.logging</groupId>
    <artifactId>logstash-gelf</artifactId>
    <version>1.13.0</version>
</dependency>
{code}
column249:
27/Mar/19 8:09 PM;rbjorklin-dw;For anyone else interested in this feature while waiting for JFrog to make a decision you can do the following to make it work:
{code:java}
curl -sLo /opt/jfrog/artifactory/tomcat/webapps/artifactory/WEB-INF/lib/logstash-gelf-1.13.0.jar "https://search.maven.org/remotecontent?filepath=biz/paluch/logging/logstash-gelf/1.13.0/logstash-gelf-1.13.0.jar"
{code}
and then add the required appender:
{code:java}
<appender name="GELF" class="biz.paluch.logging.gelf.logback.GelfLogbackAppender">
    <host>udp:graylog.example.org</host>
    <port>12201</port>
    <version>1.1</version>
    <facility>graylog</facility>
    <extractStackTrace>true</extractStackTrace>
    <additionalFields>service=artifactory</additionalFields>
    <neverBlock>true</neverBlock>
    <queueSize>512</queueSize>
</appender>
{code}
finally add the appender reference like so:
{code:java}
<root>
    <level value="warn"/>
    <appender-ref ref="CONSOLE"/>
    <appender-ref ref="FILE"/>
    <appender-ref ref="GELF"/>
</root>
{code}
column250: 27/Mar/19 8:12 PM;rbjorklin-dw;The appender configuration should go into: /etc/opt/jfrog/artifactory/logback.xml

column1: Issues with the Mission Control Users DSL resource.
Old Eventual Binary Provider
Initialization Process
column45:
*+Agenda+*:

The new init flow has the following advantages over the previous primary-role based HA topology:
 # The new init flow will allow the user to start multiple nodes at the same time (in no particular order), regardless to whether the cluster is being upgraded or not. Note that only one node can perform the most of the initialization flow at once. When the initialization flow is being performed from one node, others will wait for it to finish before continuing their own init.

*+Specification+*:

The new init flow inits the database schema as soon as possible, and then wraps the rest of the init flow inside an HA lock. The following two phases are wrapped inside a lock - 
 # Config - the first phase, where PRE_INIT, HOME and HOME_SYNC converters run, among other procedures such as the init of the master.key, the start of the config manager, etc.
 # App Context - the second phase, where all the ReloadableBean converters are called one by one, and POST_INIT converters are also called.

To allow all nodes in the cluster to be started in parallel, the new init flow will perform the following procedure:
 # Check whether an upgrade is due, and attempt to insert a lock on the init flow.
 # If a lock can be acquired, hold the lock while running the init, and release it when it ends.
 # If a lock cannot be acquired, wait for the lock to be removed, and continue where left off after the lock is released.

Right now, to replace one parameter for replication to one particular site, we need to use GET /api/replications/:repo that returns list of replication dicts that we need to process and POST back to /api/replications/multiple/:repo in different format. This is extremely unhandy. Could you please expose GET /api/replications/multiple/:repo endpoint that serves the data in the same format as is sent with PUT and POST methods there?

column1: API to get Xray Scan Status for an artifact
column45:
Create separate jobs for CI and CD process on TFS.

The CD process gets immediately triggered after CI process.

Since the artifact is still not scanned, CD job fails to download this artifact (Repository has blocking policy for unscanned artifacts) .

 

We can see the scan status for an artifact on UI, using the following URL

*curl -u admin:password "http://<artifactory-url>/artifactory/**ui/artifactxray?**path=<path-to-artifact>&repoKey=<repo-name>"*

 

But, there is no REST API to get the Xray status in build job, using cURL OR TFS Artifactory plugin.
column46:
TFS for CI server (setup build-jobs) and

Artifactory plugin (for publishing/resolving to/from Artifactory).

column1: NPM Special Search Qualifiers Support
column45:
In NPM.JS you can search using keywords, for example:

curl "https://registry.npmjs.org/-/v1/*search?text=keywords:liferay-theme&size=250*"

{"objects":[\{"package":{"name":"sign-in-modal-themelet","scope":"unscoped","version":"1.0.2","description":"Add default Liferay sign in modal behavior to Liferay 7.x themes.","keywords":["liferay-theme","liferay-themelet","liferay","themelet","theme","sign-in","sign"],"date":"2018-09-10T15:19:50.076Z","links":{"npm":"https://www.npmjs.com/package/sign-in-modal-themelet","homepage":"https://github.com/lgdd/sign-in-modal-themelet#readme","repository":"https://github.com/lgdd/sign-in-modal-themelet","bugs":"https://github.com/lgdd/sign-in-modal-themelet/issues"},"publisher":\{"username":"lgdd","email":"louis-guillaume.durand@liferay.com"},"maintainers":[\{"username":"lgdd","email":"louis-guillaume.durand@liferay.com"}]}, ...

*When triggered against Artifactory, the endpoint is not supported and does not return an array of objects.*

column1: MFA with RADIUS
column45: RADIUS is an industry standard for centralized Authentication, Authorization, and Accounting, and is often the backend of choice for 802.1X authentication. The JFrog Artifactory suite would benefit greatly in the enterprise environment from supporting Multi-factor authentication with RADIUS.

column1: Debian packages are partly not up to date

It is replicating [http://ftp.de.debian.org/debian/]
We have set up an standard remote caching debian repository.

The file “sources.xz” is outdated and should be replaced with a version from 07-Feb-2019.

The configuration of the cache is not changed:

I think, this could be a bug on your side. I think the caching should look for a new version after “Metadata time retrieval cache period” ended.

Thanks for your help.

column1: Add the option to specify a DB name when using Helm chart external database
column45:
Add the option to specify a DB name when using Helm chart external database.

For now, if you would like to use an external database, there are two ways to do so:

1 - helm install --name artifactory-ha --set postgresql.enabled=false --set database.type=mssql --set database.url='jdbc:sqlserver://IP:PORT;*databaseName=artifactory*;sendStringParametersAsUnicode=false;applicationName=Artifactory Binary Repository' --set database.user=sa --set database.password=Somepass4u  jfrog/artifactory-ha

*Using the first way, the database name is passed as part of the DB_URL connection string.*

 

2  -helm install --name artifactory-ha --set postgresql.enabled=false --set database.type=mssql --set database.host=\{HOST} --set database.port=\{PORT}- -set database.user=sa --set database.password=Somepass4u  jfrog/artifactory-ha

*Using the second way, there is no parameter that we can specify for example --set database.name . By default, the database name used is "artifactory".*
column249:
14/Jun/19 4:28 PM;rimasm;Option 1) really does that well and I don't really see a point to add any extra parameters to be set there in the chart.
Artifactory-ha chart readme will be updated with example.
column250: 14/Jun/19 8:37 PM;rimasm;PR created https://github.com/jfrog/charts/pull/366
column251: 15/Jun/19 6:01 PM;rimasm;PR merged on June 14, 2019

column1: Ability to adjust the context menu of a folder or artifact
column45: {color:#000000}We are using an artifact(folder) promotion process, implemented by a Gradl plugin. The promotion actually consists of a release of an artifact which means a copy of the artifact to release a repository and a change of the build property to status _released_. This plugin uses  Rest Api calls and commands to set properties and copy the artifact. Now this plugin is called via a post action of a build script or separately on CLI. But to make life easier for most users, it would be awful that a artifact promotion activity could be started from a menu item in the context menu (right mouse click menu) of the concerned artifact.{color}

column1: Get Release Bundle should be returned with no trusted key validation
column45:
Today, if a trusted key is being erased on Artifactory, all release bundles versions that were verified using the erased trusted key will not be returned.

This is important, especially in a key rotation use-case.
column249:
25/Feb/19 2:14 PM;galba;Please explain exactly what you want to be implemented.
There are several options.

The trivial one, is to limit the validation only to the creation of the Release bundle.

Regards,

Disha

column1: Feature request: redirect replication apps to serve via HTTPS only
column45:
Hi Team,
In the last meeting session with our team manager [~yonatanb], we've tried to bond our Artifactory instance and Edge node to promote release artifacts.
Unfortunately we've faced with firewall limitations.

So I wondered, would be great in such cases use service interface only provided by NGINX we already use.

The idea is to use rewriting requests to different ports of applications and hide it into logical locations as described there [https://gist.github.com/tzutalin/4412f50aea1ea864c24134647eca20f8]
and partly there [https://support.jfrog.com/jFrogKnowledgePage].
As we could know, nginx uses epoll event model(for Linux kernel), so replication could load one or more nginx worker process(-es), well it wouldn't take influence to performance of main app but hide listening ports and will give possibility to use REST(e.g.) API.
Also network layer for consumers will require opened one firewall port only.

As limitation I see maximum length of uploaded content client_max_body_size and upload_max_file_size settings used on server and location contexts. It could be set per location.

Thanks,
Sergey

column1: Artifactory should allow creating more than one build info repository
column45:
Use case: When you have two Artifactory clusters the replication of build info can't be done in bi-directional as you only have one build info repository in each Artifactory. If replication is done in bi directional way, then you could overwrite build info.

The additional build info repositories created will only be used as target for build info replication. The default build info repository that comes out of the box in each Artifactory will be used to store all the builds that are deployed to that Artifactory.
column249: 09/Apr/19 3:14 PM;czardis;I have another use case for multiple build info repositories. Currently permissions on the build info repository is set only on a pattern match on the build name. Unless your users are very well disciplined at naming their builds in an orderly manner (and this is very hard bordering on impossible to introduce with lots of users, seeing as before the build repository anyone could upload any named build). So, the current permissions model is essentially unworkable and we will have to continue to allow anyone to upload any build to the build info repository. If each group could be assigned their own build repository (which would require an upgrade to the Jenkins plugin to allow this to be specified), permissions could be assigned to that repository in the normal way - they could then upload and manage their builds however they want without affecting other users.

column1: Feature to disallow upload of large files through REST
column45:
Currently, we have a file size upload limit for the UI only, and we do not have an option to disallow users from uploading a large file to a repository through REST.

It would help to have an option to set a file size limit before the upload and have Artifactory check this limit before the upload.

column1: JDBC URL with multiple host of PostgreSQL in Artifactory doesn't work with docker setup
column45:
Providing multiple hosts in the DB URL as mentioned in (https://jdbc.postgresql.org/documentation/head/connect.html#connection-failover) supports the normal installation of artifactory with postgres database.

However, it doesn't work with docker installation since the entrypoint script in docker container checks for the availability of DB using the following command
{code:java}
</dev/tcp/<host>/<port>{code}
which is expecting a single host

hence the condition is not able to reach the database and the artifactory startup getting failed with the following error.
{code:java}
ERROR: DB postgresql failed to start in the given time{code}

Steps to reproduce

Try to lauch the artifactory docker container with multiple hosts in DB Url

docker run -d \
-e "DB_TYPE=postgresql" \
-e "DB_URL=jdbc:postgresql://<host1-ip>:<port>,<host2-ip>:<port>/artifactory" \
-e "DB_USER=artifactory" \
-e "DB_PASSWORD=password" \
--name art1 docker.bintray.io/jfrog/artifactory-pro:6.6.5
column249:
28/Aug/20 6:30 AM;prakritish;This is not working for artifactory version 7.6.3.

Please provide an ETA for resolution.
column250:
28/Aug/20 10:06 AM;tswain;HI Team,  We are really struck, as I could see it is a single point of failure in DB side.  

DB: Postgress11 

JDBC driver :*postgresql-42.2.14* 

*Artifactory version :7.6.3* 

*All these are the latest version still, it is not working.*    

*Note: To overcome this we have configured pgbouncher, but it is not working with a pgbouncher setting.*  

*Please provide an ETA for this issue.*

column1: Add support for Operator Framework
column45:
An operator is a method of packaging, deploying and managing a Kubernetes application.
The Operator Framework is an open source project that provides developer and runtime Kubernetes tools, enabling you to accelerate the development of an Operator.

The [operator-sdk|https://github.com/operator-framework/operator-sdk] for example, will enable to build operators without Kubernetes API complexities, it can even simplify for example the configuration and installation or an Artifactory standalone and HA on top of Kuberenetes.

The operator-sdk library also supports GO Ansible and Helm.
column249: 07/Jan/20 4:24 PM;tpouyer;I would also like to see the ability to host an Operator Catalog Registry in Artifactory (https://github.com/operator-framework/operator-registry)

column1: Rename users in Artifactory
column45: One of the customers is requesting to get a feature request to be able to rename users in Artifactory. Currently, the only way is to change the users in the database.

column1: New permission for promote
column45:
Would it be possible to broaden the permission scheme by adding a new permission "promote" to the permission targets. 

Our desired workflow is this: 
Every product team has 2 repositories for their product, dev and production. The developers will push their packages (via Jenkins or other) with proper build info to dev repository and then later on the packages can be promoted to production repository (when for example the package is ready for production). No one should be able to directly push their packages to the production repository, only via promotion from dev.

With current permission scheme we would need to give the deploy rights to production repository to allow the users to promote their packages from dev to production repo, but unfortunately this would also allow them to push artifacts directly to the production repository.

I think that this kind of promote permission would make a lot of sense and would be needed to achieve the kind of workflow that I described which I think would be very welcome especially in regulated enterprise environments. So I would be happy to hear your thoughts on this and if you think it would be feasible to implement.

column1: API key for disabled OneLogin users remain active after user has been deleted.
column45:
The API key of SAML provisioned users remain active after the user has been deleted or suspended.

*Steps to reproduce:*
* (As Admin): Setup SAML SSO and use OneLogin as SAML provider.
** Choose to automatically provision users and to automatically associate 
** Enable "Edit Profile" for users so users are able to create API keys.
* (As SAML user): Login to Artifactory and provision an API key.
* (As SAML user): Logout of Artifactory.
* (As SAML user): Test that API key works by making any API call to Artifactory using the provisioned API key.
* Disable the user in OneLogin.
* (As SAML user): Try to log into Artifactory through the web interface - User should not be allowed to log in.
* (As SAML user): Try to use the API key previously provisioned.

Current behaviour:
* The API key is still valid and the user still has access to Artifactory repositories even though the user has been disabled.

Expected behaviour:
* The API key should be revoked and the user should either be disabled and/or removed from Artifactory.


*Additional details:*
The bug my not be within Artifactory itself, but rather with the OneLogin App developed to enable SAML SSO with OneLogin. When configuring the integrations in OneLogin there's no "Provisioning" tab available as with other integrations (i.e. Office365). On the provisioning tab it allows the following options to be set (_Create User_, _Delete User_, _Update user_).
Delete User can be used when a user is removed from or suspended in OneLogin.
column46: Reproduced using Artifactory Cloud hosted on AWS.

column1: Include Golang support for native go commands
column45:
Include support for native go commands. Need ability to resolve dependencies via "go get" natively without needing to use the Jfrog cli. IDEs are assuming the "go" command.

A short term workaround might be providing a mechanism to alias the cli to the "go" command.

column1: Include Go support to walk a modules dependency tree and resolve the packages
column45: Include support in Go repositories to walk a Go module's dependency tree and resolve the packages. We need Artifactory to perform code analysis of Go packages that are retrieved from a remote repo and generate the metadata (the go.mod file) on the fly then retrieve those dependencies.

column1: Include Go support for older package managers: glide, dep and, govendor
column45:
Include support for package managers glide, dep and, govendor. Some third party packages still use those package managers and we have no ability to force those parties to update their code. Having Artifactory support the older package managers would allow us to use those packages.

 

Example package using dep:

[https://github.com/operator-framework/operator-sdk]

column1: Dynamic inclusion of local repos in virtual repos
column45:
Enable support for inclusion of a newly created local repository in an existing virtual repository based on a given criteria (e.g repository name).

Or enable a plugin execution point of "after creation of a local repository" in order to be able to achieve the inclusion with a user plugin (i.e - fire the user plugin after the event of a local repository creation, the plugin's logic will make the necessary calls to include the local repository in a given virtual repository)

column1: Ability to kill/stop a running any job such as replication job or other internal tasks like System Export/Import, Backup jobs

This feature is very useful in cases where the Replication is stuck or the Backup job in Artifactory is stuck after its started.

column1: Conda-local upload doesn't support labels
column45:
Conda packages can be uploaded to Artifactory using Curl. When using Curl we cannot label the packages. 

Please go through the attached screenshot where I deployed a conda-package to the conda-local repository and there is no scope of adding a label in the command. 

By referring  "https://docs.anaconda.com/anaconda-cloud/user-guide/tutorials/" URL, we can confirm that we can also upload packages using "anaconda upload command" which has a feature to add a label. 



Conda labels work for remote-repository while installing a package  using labels and this is how it looks like from request.log: 

20190116184040|749|REQUEST|127.0.0.1|admin|GET|/api/conda/conda-virtual/conda-forge/label/cf201901/noarch/repodata.json|HTTP/1.1|200|2983301

 

 

!Screen Shot 2019-01-16 at 11.32.43 AM.png!!Screen Shot 2019-01-16 at 11.33.00 AM.png!!Screen Shot 2019-01-16 at 11.33.12 AM.png!

column1: Rest API - Distribution repository creation
column45: Provide the ability with the Artifactory rest API to create a distribution repository to work against a bintray account.

column1: Multi-threaded copy, move, and delete operations
column45:
Currently, Artifactory performs copy operations using a single thread. This means that transferring large amounts of files between local repositories takes a very long time at the moment compared to CLI build tools.

This has an impact on artifact promotions as well as move and delete operations.

For example, on a test repository, copying 200,000 empty items from one local repository to another takes over 35 minutes:

*[200k copy operations]*
*2019-01-14 18:46:08,408 [http-nio-8081-exec-241] [DEBUG] (o.a.r.s.m.BaseRepoPathMover:72) - start move/copy single tx on source and target* 
*[...]*
*2019-01-14 19:20:45,804 [http-nio-8081-exec-241] [INFO ] (o.a.u.r.s.a.b.t.a.CopyArtifactService:142) - copying builds: to copy-target: completed successfully, 194970 artifacts and 3 folders were copied*

It would be best if a multi-threaded copy operation could be performed in these cases.

Artifactory is making database table inserts on the backend, and could do more than one write at the same time.

column1: Support AWS IAM Roles for Artifactory authentications

This way, users would be able to log onto Artifactory using their AWS credentials rather than LDAP or SAML SSO.

column1: Need to include path/subfolder to resolve Helm chart
column45:
Currently Helm repo uses the index.yaml file at the root of the repo to resolve Helm chart requests. However, each entry in index.yaml only contains the chart name. This is problematic if two teams publish charts with exactly the same name and version. The chart published first will shadow the chart published later, causing request to  download the 2nd chart always resolving to the first chart. We have reported this issue in ticket [#96204.|https://support.jfrog.com/jFrogCasePage?id=5001r000027YGDG]

I{color:#333333}n our environment we use unique app id to create sub-folder in the Helm repo for each team{color}. The chart name collision issue above can be resolved by using subfolder name plus the chart name. The combination of the two should uniquely identify each chart. 

We request Artifactory to add sub-folder name when resolving chart names. Basically, change from: chart-name to subfolder-name/chart-name.
column249: 08/May/20 4:31 PM;felipecassiors;I can confirm the behavior described in the Issue. Currently, if you push two charts with the same name in different paths of the repository, both will be treated as the same product by the index.

column1: Log to Capture Data for Distribution & Deployment Tool Download Requests
column45:
Downloads of components are not currently treated as 'first class citizen' events and are not logged in a way that is particularly meaningful with respect to compliance reporting.

IDEA:

Anytime an external request is received and a file is downloaded, record the following (in a separate log just for this purpose):

date : time : start : end : request type : repo : namespace : component name : user : target IP

If you have additional questions, please route them through David Xu.

column1: Allow NPM packages to display README without having to download
column45:
Similar to github or npmjs, if you click on a package, the README of that package will be displayed.  This allows users to know what the package does without having to download this package.

 

It would be nice if Artifactory could allow for NPM packages that do contain a README to be displayed within a tab, similar to the npm info tab.  This would allow developers the ability to see what the package does prior to downloading it.

column1: OAuth with Jira

Google, OpenID Connect, GitHub Enterprise, and Cloud Foundry UAA
 
It would be good to support Jira as a new provider like explained [here|https://developer.atlassian.com/server/jira/platform/oauth/] 
 
it's not Atlassian Crowd.

column1: Maven deploy retention policy
column45:
Hello,

I am using the Artifactory plugin 2.6 in TeamCity to deploy Maven artifacts to Artifactory Maven repositories. I have both release (libs-release) and snapshot (libs-snapshot) repositories set up for my project. For build and deploy, everything works fantastically, snapshots and releases are correctly deployed to the appropriate repositories defined in the fields "Target repository" and "Target snapshot repository".

The problem is with the retention section. If I choose "Discard Old Builds:" and use "Max # Of Builds To Keep:", the number entered is a collective total of builds in both release and snapshot repositories.


Example:
I have max # of builds to keep set at 3
Build run 1 release (successfully deploys to libs-release maven repo)
Build run 2 snapshot (successful to libs-snapshot repo)
Build run 3 snapshot (again)
Build run 4 snapshot (again, all successful)

At this point, the release artifacts (from run 1) are deleted, even though they are in a separate repository than the last run. Because we have way more snapshot builds than release builds, using the same Max # as a total of the 2 repositories does not make sense.

Either of these options would be a suitable solution for this issue: 
1) apply the current Max # rule value to each repository separately (max 3 in each repo for example)
2) give each repository its own Max # field (Max # of snapshots to keep & Max # of releases to keep)

column1: Add support for SCIM in Artifactory
column45: The System for Cross-domain Identity Management (SCIM) specification is designed to make managing user identities in cloud-based applications and services easier. The specification suite seeks to build upon experience with existing schemas and deployments, placing specific emphasis on simplicity of development and integration, while applying existing authentication, authorization, and privacy models. Its intent is to reduce the cost and complexity of user management operations by providing a common user schema and extension model, as well as binding documents to provide patterns for exchanging this schema using standard protocols. In essence: make it fast, cheap, and easy to move users in to, out of, and around the cloud.

column1: Remote Mirror for Jenkins Plugins
column45:
Greetings,

it would be a nice feature if Artifactory was able to mirror/proxy Jenkins plugins.

In Jenkins plugin configuration you need to address the update-center.json ([https://updates.jenkins.io/update-center.json]) which contains all the dirct URLs for the Plugin

You need some software that creates the update-center.json for the Artifactory repository URL.

There are some Github projects already
 * [https://github.com/jenkinsci/juseppe]

As of now jenkins official plugins repo(updates.jenkins.io) is pulling most of the plugins from updates.jenkins-ci.org and few other remote locations.
So even if we try to mirror the jenkins plugins repo, it is just grabing the metadata information (from where to download) from it and downloading it from the remote locations and Here the requirement is something like Artifactory should be having some mechanism to cache and store all the plugins which are getting fetched irrespective of the remote location.

column1: Chunked Uploads for Large Files
column45:
Currently the API as well as the UI do only support upload of new artifacts in a single request. For really large artifacts (such as >100 GB archives) this can be pretty painful. Especially if the network connection is intestable it can get impossible to upload such big artifacts.

The introduction of supporting chunked uploaded could solve this issue. Retries would not block the overall process as it would be sufficient to start with the failed chunk which is much smaller than the overall artifact.

column1: AQL/API access to Docker Layer information
column45:
Re: [#92962] AQL searches to get Docker layer information

 

Via the Web interface, I can browse to my docker repo, select an image, and then click on “Docker Info” to get a visualization of each individual layer.

 

Each layer has the docker information, whether it was a RUN, LABEL, COPY, etc.

 

*How can I pull this layer information via AQL? Artifactory has all the information. How can I query against it?*

 

EG: sha256:40e43964f195c9c3d620dc88fc7c001f09a679c17dcee34ad68b87731cbd5c6a

 

Was a RUN command that did :

 

{{RUN /bin/sh -c cp /home/<xxx>/lib/alerts/\{dynconfigAlertsError.yaml,tandemRecoveryTemplate.yaml,tandemRestartDaemon.yaml,tandemSetupFailure.yaml} /home/<xxx>/etc/alerts/}}

 

{{I do not see this information tied as a property against the sha256__40e43964f195c9c3d620dc88fc7c001f09a679c17dcee34ad68b87731cbd5c6a file.}}

 

The only properties/LABEL’s I can see are tied against the manifest.json file. But I want to get individual layer information.

column1: Reduce excessive messages in Artifactory log for virtual repo access
column45:
We have noticed that there were thousands of error messages in Artifactory within 1 or 2 minutes duration. This happened a few times a day. After some investigation, we concluded this was caused by a project accessing a virtual maven repo which consists of several local repos and public remote repos such as jcenter.

 

*Project setup:*
 * User has a maven project with many public dependencies such as org.apache.activemq
 * User resolves these dependencies through an artifactory virtual repository.
 * Virtual repository consists of many local repositories, then remote repositories pointing to different places such as jcenter.
 * Local repositories do not allow the user to read the org folder. User can only access gov/nasa/jpl folder in the local repos.

 

*Current behavior:*

Since most of the dependencies are from remote repos (such as jcenter), when the user performs the maven build, Artifactory logs indicate many [DENIED DOWNLOAD] entries for each dependency for the artifact from local repositories, followed by an [ACCEPTED DOWNLOAD] entry for the artifact from the remote repository. Since there are so many dependencies, the process generates thousands of messages in the log for a very short period of time (such as 7,000 log messages in 2 minutes).

 

*Request improvement:*

Artifactory can just log which artifact is downloaded from which repo within the virtual repo and ignore all false-positive messages about [DENIED DOWNLOAD].

column1: Docker Max unique tag should be removed by last updated layer instead tag version
column45:
The current implementation of the Artifactory's Max Unique tags is to delete the tags based on the version instead of the creation/update date of the image/layer.

 

For example, if we have the Max Unique tags been set for the docker repository and we push images with tag 1,2,3,4 and the max unique tags are set to 4. 

Pushing an image with tag 5, deletes tag 1 which is the expected behavior.

If we could support a feature of deleting by last updated/created layer instead of the tag number.

column1: REST API for Supported Package Types
column45:
We have built some internal automation to create repositories based on YAML configurations stored in a github repo.

 

One problem we've encountered is validating the available package types supported by Artifactory:

 

Every time you add new package types we have to update our code to include the new package types to validate the YAML.

 

Can you add a REST API call that we can use to query Artifactory's supported package types?

 

It could be a simple API call that will just return all available types supported by Artifactory as a JSON payload.

 

Thanks

In order to create repository, we have to fetch list of supported repository type so user can choose and create themselves.

column1: Credential manager
column45:
As an Admin, I would like to store credentials (for configuration) in a vault and then reuse them for different purposes.

For instance when configuring different remote repositories, it would be possible to apply a stored credential to each repo without having to type the same password for each configuration.

It would be the same behaviour as the one to set a proxy on a remote (Admin > Remote > Advanced tab > Network > Proxy)

column1: Prevent duplicate upload artifactory
column45:
When client machine uploads a file that is already stored by Artifactory, based on it's checksum Artifactory will only store it once on disk.
Is it possible to speedup the upload times by (based on checksum) to skip/simulate the upload of files that are already archived?

column1: Custom file HTTP transfer headers
column45:
Given the existence of the artifactory.content-type variable, it would be nice if there was an arbitrary property (or namespace of properties) that would result in data coming down with the file as (e.g.) X-Artifactory- headers when you request an artefact. This would save having to double get files, once for the content, and once for the properties.

I notice you already set X-Artifactory-Filename, X-Artifactory-Id, as well as the XChecksum-… headers.

So maybe setting artifactory.header.executable = true would give "X-Artifactory-executable: true" as an output header when getting the file (which could help act as a workaround for the missing archive meta-data).

column1: New virtual repository artifact resolution strategy request for better support full mesh topoligy
column45:
1. Please implement artifact resolution strategy that takes into account all local and locally cached artifacts and returns freshest one (comparing by last modification timestamp). If artifact is not found neither in local nor local-cache repositories then fallback to querying remotes as it is done right now.

2. Allow admin to select artifact resolution strategy (either per virtual repository or globally per artifactory instance settings is fine).

column1: direct url redirect behavior on not authenticated request
column45:
The expected behavior on our end would be:
 Non authenticated direct URL request -> redirect authentication page 
 On success -> redirect to content if exist or 404 if it does not
 On failed auth -> redirect to failed auth page

If a non-authenticated user clicks a link to an artifact in a repository that's not available to them, they get redirected to a repository that does not require authentication, instead of being redirected to the login page. They use LDAP.

What they want is to:
 * Be redirected to a login page
 * Show a warning/notice that they don't have sufficient permission to access the repository
column249:
18/Oct/18 1:06 PM;sjuhasz;Use case:
User gets a direct link to an artifact on a restricted repository. Let it be a jar.
Wants to check it on the UI because maybe needs to see pom, or other details, also see what repository it is in.
Clicks the link.
Now gets redirected to the main page. Has to log in. Click the link again. See details.
Instead user clicks the link, gets redirected to the login page. On successful auth challenge gets redirected to the url requested and becomes happy.

Don't see the benefit on redirecting the user to the main page ever.
See the drawback of not redirecting the user to the requested URL if it exist.

column1: Backup and recovery of Artifactory S3 data
column45:
We are struggling on preparing a disaster recovery plan for Artifactory with AWS S3 backend. I have a support ticket at https://support.jfrog.com/jFrogCasePage?id=5001r00001pfvxS. I was told in that ticket to create a feature request.

In that ticket, the suggestion to backup AWS S3 backend data is to enable versioning of AWS S3. However, S3 versioning is for individual file rather than the whole bucket. Therefore, we will need to figure out the relationship of each file to its SHA in order to recover data to certain time point. It is not easy (if it is even possible) for this kind of development outside Artifactory code base. Basically there is no way to recover artifacts if there is a disaster in the current system.

This is a request for Artifactory to develop capability to record necessary information when S3 versioning is enabled in order to recover artifacts when there is a disaster. Also, a simple and easy to follow procedure for artifact recovery when S3 versioning is enabled should be documented.

Artifactory has become a popular tool for artifact sharing, storage, and retrieval. Artifact safety is important for enterprise usage and adoption. Thanks.
column249: 11/Feb/19 9:42 PM;seoras-ray@idexx.com;I am in the process of setting up an S3 backend and trying to figure out the best options regarding versioning and lifecycle management. To the point made above, enabling versioning is pretty useless at the moment since there is no way to tie back an S3 file to an Artifactory file. This defeats one of the main reasons for using S3 in the first place.

column1: allow choosing whether to auto-add newly created repositories to Xray
column45:
Allow choosing whether to auto-add newly created repositories to Xray.

Currently you need to go to Admin --> Configurations -->  JFrog Xray press the "+add" to add new repositories.

enable the option to have every new repository created automatically add to Xray.

column1: Current Artifactory S3 authentication methods do not meet enterprise application security requirements
column45:
For Artifactory there are 2 ways to implement S3:
 * IAM user
 ** Needs a static password
 * IAM Role
 ** Can work with refreshable credentials/AWS federation
 ** Artifactory must exist in EC2 instance so the role/authentication is handled within AWS.

In regulated entities an IAM user with a static password is not compliant with application security guidelines (must use federated, temporary credentials that upon expiration do not require an Artifactory application restart) and we obviously operate on premises and not in AWS so an IAM role will not work either. 

This means that Artifactory does not currently provide enterprises operating on premise Artifactory infrastructure an operationally feasible authentication solution.

This issue is holding up our ability to pilot Artifactory using S3 storage for the binarystore.  In turn, this is holding up our ability to deploy our nextgen clustered/mesh topology (which will drive incremental Artifactory Enterprise+ license acquisition).

column1: Have the ability to get file list of the remote repository
column45:
When using a remote repository that points to another Artifactory instance, it should allow getting, by demand, the file list of the remote repository. Currently, the only option is to have a file list of the cached artifacts. 

Scenarios:
 # Art1 remote repository points to Art2 local repository - User sends REST API (either a new rest or add an additional param on the existing one) for file list to Art1 and will get the file list of Art2 local repository. 
 # Art1 remote repository points to Art2 remote repository - User sends REST API (either a new rest or add an additional param on the existing one) for file list to Art1 and will get the file list of Art2 remote cache repository. 

As mentioned above, in order to keep the existing behavior, this can be implemented as a new REST API endpoint or to add a parameter to the existing REST API, i.e:
 {{'/api/storage/remote-repo/}}{{*&listRemote=1*'}}

column1: Allow per-node binarystore.xml property changes
column45:
Currently the entire binarystore.xml file is synchronized between HA nodes. This is inflexible as it means the same settings are applied regardless of the host's configuration.

Take a 2 node HA cluster where one host has 100 GB of disk space while the other has 1 TB. The binarystore.xml can only use 100GB of space as increasing this value will overload one of the nodes.

Most Binary providers are not compatible with each other (E.G. the [S3 configuration|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Configuring+the+Filestore#ConfiguringtheFilestore-S3BinaryProvider] and the [cluster-s3 configuration|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Configuring+the+Filestore#ConfiguringtheFilestore-S3ClusterBinaryProvider]), but the same provider template has variable settings that can change.

For example, there could be a "$cache" variable in the binarystore.xml, and a second "binary-variables.xml" file that specifies the cache-fs size on each node.

The "binary-variables.xml" file would not be synchronized across nodes, much like the logback.xml file is not synchronized.

 

As an alternative solution, there could be an artifactory.system.properties value that disables binarystore.xml syncing on HA nodes. The setting should be labeled as an Advanced feature, as it would further complicate any conflicts.

column1: Remote binary provider should retry
column45:
The remote binary provider in HA mode should either retry on another node or fallback to fetching an artifact from the configured storage backend (e.g. s3) when it fails to fetch an artifact from another node.

Right now, it will return a 503 to the user and a failed download.

This can happen in normal operations when restarting another HA node.

column1: Artifactory is not allowing to connect to S3 bucket when using the FIPS endpoint URL
column45:
Artifactory is not allowing to connect to S3 bucket when using the FIPS endpoint URL. FIPS is a US government standard that specifies the security requirements for cryptographic modules that protect sensitive information. [https://aws.amazon.com/compliance/fips/]

 

We need to support the FIPS endpoint URL as this is used by Government agencies who have to follow security requirements set by US government.

 

Steps to Reproduce:

1.Use a S3 bucket for your Artifactory instance

2.when specifying the endpoint URL in binarystore.xml please use FIPS url "s3-fips.us-west-1.amazonaws.com". The region in url will change depending on where your s3 bucket exists.

3.When starting Artifactory it will be successful, but you will see the below warning:

2018-08-24 11:57:49,056 [art-init] [INFO ] (o.a.a.f.t.j.s.S3JetS3tBinaryProvider:464) - Connecting to S3 endpoint: 's3-fips.us-west-1.amazonaws.com'

2018-08-24 11:57:49,325 [art-init] [WARN ] (o.a.a.f.t.j.s.S3JetS3tBinaryProvider:365) - Failed to check if bucket exist, bucket artifactory-test-arturo. Request Error: s3-fips.us-west-1.amazonaws.com: unknown error

*4.If you try to specify the AWS signature version 4 in the binarystore.xml, then the startup of Artifactory fails when using FIPS endpoint url. Here is that parameter* 

*<s3AwsVersion>AWS4-HMAC-SHA256</s3AwsVersion>*

 

There are two issues here:

1.When using FIPS url without the signature version 4 although the Artifactory startup is successful you see the below warning which is not expected: 

2018-08-24 11:57:49,056 [art-init] [INFO ] (o.a.a.f.t.j.s.S3JetS3tBinaryProvider:464) - Connecting to S3 endpoint: 's3-fips.us-west-1.amazonaws.com'

2018-08-24 11:57:49,325 [art-init] [WARN ] (o.a.a.f.t.j.s.S3JetS3tBinaryProvider:365) - Failed to check if bucket exist, bucket artifactory-test-arturo. Request Error: s3-fips.us-west-1.amazonaws.com: unknown error

*2. The more serious issue is the one where if you specify the AWS signature version 4 in binarystore.xml then the startup of Artifactory fails.*

 

*Workaround if you are using AWS signature version 4 in binarystore.xml is to remove the parameter from binarystore.xml that specifies the signature version:*

*<s3AwsVersion>AWS4-HMAC-SHA256</s3AwsVersion>*
column249:
31/Aug/18 9:46 PM;nihalc@jfrog.com;The customer has a security requirement to encrypt all data and to use FIPS compliant endpoints.

They are using AWS server side encryption and due to this they can't use the workaround where you can remove the AWS signature version parameter from the binarystore.xml to be able to connect to the FIPS URL.

At this point the customer is unable to use FIPS endpoint URL for connecting to S3 bucket and since this is a security requirement for them they won't be able to use Artifactory.

column1: Air Gap solution
column45:
Customers with an air-gapped environment are dealing with complex management of the retrieving artifacts from public resources:
 1. They don't have records for failed requests.
 2. They should manually run the same requests outside (in the DMZ/external instance) + manage the same clients outside.
 3. export the downloaded packages and import them to the specific internal repositories.

The solution includes:
 1. Create a new remote repo type ("protected repo") for each technology
 - This repo will collect all the requests - requests will not go outside but will be gathered into a JSON file with all the info
 - Those repositories should have a specified mapping to the external repo URLs

2. Once we get all those recorded requests we will transfer the JSON file to the external Artifactory and run a CURL that will download all the requested packages using a dedicated handler for each technology.
 3. once we have all the packages in the external instance we can export the repositories needed and out those inside a storage. In the internal instance we will run a CURL that will import the packages back to the internal artifactory into the right repositories.

column1: Support Swift package manager
column45:
+Why a package manager for Swift?+

The Swift is a cross-platform language(MacOS, Ubuntu, Future Platform) so developers would need a cross-platform build system for Swift.

Since this is a cross-platform language, developers would also want to share their code, regardless the platform or where they are - and it has a standard to share libraries(its canonical).

The Swift package manager is an open source project.
Its a tool for managing distribution of source code, aimed at making it easy to share code and reuse others’ code. The tool compiling and linking Swift packages, managing dependencies, versioning, and supporting flexible distribution and collaboration models.

Link to the Github project: [https://github.com/apple/swift-package-manager]

Link to the documentation can be found on [https://swift.org|https://swift.org/]

 

+How to use it?+

It consists with 4 basic operations

$ swift build - to build your package.

$ swift run - to run your package.

$ swift test - to run tests

$ swift package - to perform various none build operations on the package.

The packages are stored in Github and their versions are represented with Git tags.

Swift package consists of 3 main parts - Targets, Products and Dependencies(see attached swift manifest example).

 

There are no customers assign to this feature request.
