Thanks,

Jeff

column1: Enable multi-part upload of large artifacts
column45: When uploading large artifacts through the REST API or CLI, there should be an option for chunked multi-part upload, as is available between artifactory and some binary stores.

column1: REST end point that returns pre-configured files such as settings.xml, npmrc, etc
column45:
When using the upcoming CI/CD tools or scripting, it's extremely handy just to get pre-configured files such as settings.xml (java), .npmrc (npm), etc. 

The idea way is to create a rest end point that returns back a populated version of settings.xml, etc that include user tokens valid for a certain time.

The input payload of this rest end point will be
1. APIKey or user/password
2. Repository name
3. Expiry time
4. Build Technology (Optional)

The output payload should be -
1. Preconfigured file with the right repository and access tokens. 
2. Example - for java it will be settings.xml, etc.

column1: Send users email
column45: We frequently need to notify all Artifactory users about version upgrade or new information about Artifactory. However, it is very difficult to get an email list from Artifactory or send emails directly within Artifactory UI. It has been a major admin issue for us. Please consider implementing the capability to export user emails from Artifactory or implementing an admin email notification scheme inside Artifactory UI. Thanks.

column1: Add option to disable deletion of Permission object
column45:
AS an Artifactory Administrators
WE need to have a way how to disable ability for users to delete Permissions itself
SO THAT WE can be sure permission will exists unless deleted by administrator (and only by administrator).

-----

Currently, users with righ *{{Manage}}* are able to add/remove other users rights to a given "Permission Object" they have the {{Manage}} right to. They also have the right to delete the entire "Permission Object" as such.

----

If we want to delete managing right to users, they are able to delete the whole permission (by accident for example) but not able to re-create it again. Therefore its asymmetric behaviour might render some repositories or subpaths as broken (not write/readable by anyone).

----

Proposed solution: add some other field to {{artifactory.system.properties}} with default to false, something along "permissions deletable only by administrators" that will allow such behaviour when set to true.
column249:
18/Jul/17 7:05 PM;miroslav.hedl;Changed prio to {{Critical}} to get higher in the list in the 500 other new feature requests.
It's not a {{Blocker}} but quite high on our list.
Also should be easy to implement (but I guess everybody claims that about their feature requests :-) ).

- Remote IP - TLS information – version, chosen cipher suite, bits, remote public certificate, client public certificate

column1: Use Certificate Authentication with PostgreSQL
column45:
A secure method of authenticating against the PostgreSQL database is to use [Certificate Authentication|https://docs.jelastic.com/ssl-for-pgsql] to avoid specifying a username / password.

The PostGRESQL database offers cert based authentication support out of the box. The postgres jdbc also supports certificate based auth. However, all Artifactory documentation specifies username/password in the Artifactory DB Config, and currently cannot implement certificate authentication against a PostgreSQL database.

Users should be able to authenticate against the database using this method by specifying in the URL that they want to use a local certificate:
{code}
type=postgresql
driver=org.postgresql.Driver
url=jdbc:postgresql://<ART_URL>:5432/artifactory?ssl=true&sslfactory=org.postgresql.ssl.jdbc4.LibPQFactory&sslmode=verify-full
{code}

column1: NTLM (authenticated) proxy support with Artifactory running on Linux
column45:
Artifactory integrates with NTLM authenticated proxy server but only if Artifactory is running on a Windows box. 

If Artifactory is running on a Linux box, then the credentials that are used to authenticate with the NTLM proxy server are not passed by Artifactory.

+Steps to reproduce:+
# Setup Authenticated NTLM proxy
# Install Artifactory on Linux
# Create a remote repository that points to bintray to pull docker images
# Configure the remote repository to point to the proxy server
# docker pull $artifactory-remote-repo/$docker-image:$docker-tag

column1: Add ability to delete a user plugin while Artifactory is down
column45:
At the moment, when deleting a user-plugin directly from the file system while Artifactory is down, it will redeploy the plugin once it is up again. This is because the database holds the reference to the user plugin and, obviously, when Artifactory is down, the db is not aware that the user plugin was deleted.
 *+Steps to reproduce+:*
1. Install a user plugin in Artifactory
2. Run Artifactory (see that the plugin has been successfully loaded)
3. Stop Artifactory
4. Delete the user plugin from $ARTIFACTORY_HOME/etc/plugins/
5. Run Artifactory
 *{color:#cc0000}+Result+:{color}*
The database redeploys the plugin to $ARTIFACTORY_HOME/etc/plugins/
As a result, Artifactory will load it again.
 *+Note+:*
Same behavior occurs for dependency jars in $ARTIFACTORY_HOME/etc/plugins/lib
 *{color:#0000cc}+2 Workarounds+:{color}*
1. Delete the plugin reference directly from the "configs" table in the database.
2. Add ".force.delete" to the name of the plugin. for example: _artifactCleanup.groovy_ will be renamed to _artifactCleanup.groovy.force.delete_.

column1: Add ability to list all remote repositories URLs via UI
column45:
+Use-case+:
A *non admin* user wants to be able to see all Artifactory proxied URLs.
For example:

{panel}
http://mirror.centos.org/centos/
https://docker.bintray.io
https://jcenter.bintray.com
https://registry.npmjs.org
...
{panel}

At the moment, this can be done by the "Get Repositories" REST API call:
{code}curl -uadmin:password http://localhost:8081/artifactory/api/repositories?type=remote{code}

However, *in the UI*, the only possible way to see the URLs (for non-admin user) is to click on the remote repos one by one and see the "Remote Repository URL" in the General tab.

column1: Encrypt database communications
column45:
Some users have noted that while you can encrypt the Artifactory database credentials using Master Key encryption, they still fear this password being communicated over plaintext.

Artifactory should be able to communicate its access credentials securely to prevent Man in the Middle attacks on its database.

column1: Support multi threaded replication
column45:
Currently Artifactory's push replication strategy is to push one artifact per repository per replication configuration. 

So if one Artifactory repository has been configured with one replication setting, it will push one artifact at a time. For repositories with a large number of small files this will mean that despite having a large amount of network bandwidth available, the replication speed is capped by this single thread. This is the case even for event based replication, as artifacts that are uploaded are added to the replication queue to be pushed one at a time.

A solution to this would be to perform what the [JFrog CLI does|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/CLI/CLI+for+JFrog+Artifactory#CLIforJFrogArtifactory-UploadingFiles] (See the *--threads* option) and do multi-threaded uploads. That is to say more than one file per repository per replication setting. The number of threads could be controlled with an artifactory.system.properties file so users can set the threads limit themselves to maximize bandwidth.
column249:
24/Jul/17 6:24 PM;armandobesa;Hi,

Is there a deployment timeline for this feature request?
column250:
04/Sep/17 2:35 AM;chenwen9;Hi, actually when we are using the Artifactory replication feature, we found that it only create one TCP connection for replicate between local instance and remote instance, no matter how many the current artifacts replicate in parallel.

So the problem is there is a maximum network transfer speed restriction for a single TCP connection which lead to many physical network bandwidth waist if there is only one single TCP connection created when using replication.We have tried to enlarge the artifactory.replication.consumer.queueSize, but it does not work.

So we want to know about the plan for this new feature to help us improve the transfer performance.  Thanks a lot.

column1: Admin Properties That Cannot Be Modified
column45:
We are looking for a way to have properties on artifacts that are added by Admins, plugins, external integrations, etc., but cannot be modified by "normal" users.  For example, being able to create and manage a reserved set of properties for each artifact in local or remote repository.

The use case for this specific need comes from a custom a security scanning plugin we are using, where we set a property on an artifact to indicate whether the artifact passed/failed the security scan.  We would like to have the information available to application users, but do not want application users to be able to modify the property value.

column1: Ability to list deploys made by user
column45:
h1. Use Case: Security Breach
Imagine a user account has been breached, and that the attacker has been able to upload artifacts. In this case, you'd want a list of all artifacts uploaded using this account since the time of the intrusion, so that you can vet them for malicious content.

h1. Notes
Some of this information is available in the log files. Those are rotated however, so this info is only available for a week or so back.

One way of implementing this would be to show this information on the user's web page in the admin UI; https://artifactory/artifactory/webapp/#/admin/security/users/someuser/edit.

This request is related to this support case, where Oriel suggested opening a JIRA ticket, and also provided some implementation ideas: https://support.jfrog.com/jFrogCasePage?id=500w000001bTwADAA0

As a workaround until this has been implemented, it should be possible to make direct queries for this information to the Postgres database.

column1: Artifactory should manage Packages metadata files for remote repositories
column45:
There are a variety of Packages* metadata related issues, but nothing for this specific use case.

My primary use case for having artifactory in place as Debian mirror is to ensure reproducible builds. The apt repository specification is at odds with direct mirroring. This issue comes into play when a package is updated or removed. When a package is updated, the Packages metadata file is updated with the new version of the package. This makes it impossible to retrieve old versions of a package through apt-get.

E.g.
I consume package A=1.0.0
The upstream mirror is updated to A=1.0.1
My mirror updates Packages.gz to reflect the upstream
I can no longer apt-get install A=1.0.0 from artifactory (though it exists on the server).

Artifactory should manage the content of Packages* to avoid discrepancies between what is cached on Artifactory and what is present on a remote mirror.

column1: Artifactory should manage debian package publish location under pool

deb-repo/pool/main/p/package-name/package-name_version.deb
deb-repo/pool/test/p/package-name/package-name_version.deb

Section 2.4 at http://www.ibiblio.org/gferg/ldp/giles/repository/repository-2.html is the typically expected pool structure.

Modifying the original example, given a package "package-name_version.deb" with component "main" and publish path "deb-repo/my_path/" and convenience field set, it would publish to:

column1: Soft or internal redirect links.
column45:
We rolled out Artifctory at my company several months ago, and while I'm a huge fan, there's one specific feature which I would love to see added - symlinks.

Prior to using Artifactory, we used a vanilla Nginx server as a yum repo and generic file store.  We enabled "latest" links by using regular filesystem sym links in our Nginx configuration.

Every time a new version of our yum artifacts was deployed, a new directory would be created and the latest symlink would be updated to point to it.  In other words, you could access the newest artifact path via http://our.yum.server/product_name/version_num/ or http://our.yum.server/product_name/latest/

This worked well in our yum .repo files, a simple "yum install product_name" was all it took to install a new version whenever it became available - this worked particularly well in our CI/CD pipelines.

However, there's no easy way to do this in Artifactory, I was able to replicate the functionality via a User Plugin which leveraged the beforeDownloadRequest execution point.  However, I ran into problems with that hook with virtual repositories and ended up writing a custom handler for the afterDownloadError execution point.  See my StackOverflow post here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/40661376/artifactory-symlink-or-aliasing-an-artifact-url

Please note that in both cases, I was able to implement the download functionality I needed but my "latest" links are not visible in the web or native UIs.

It would be great if the REST API and UIs supported CRUD operations on links which behaved the same way, for both file and directories.

column1: Allow for optional expiration time for artifacts
column45:
Add an optional field that will be populated with a timestamp of when the artifact should be removed from Artifactory.

Artifactory will then clean itself instead of needing to code tools to do this.

When used, make sure it is displayed in the General Info tab (like the creation date is).
column249:
22/Mar/18 10:55 AM;krihelis;Hi Anthony, 

For remote repositories, you can use the *Unused Artifacts Cleanup Period (Hr)* field. From Artifactory User Guide:
*Unused Artifacts Cleanup Period* - Many cached artifacts in Artifactory remote repository storage are actually unused by any current projects in the organization. This parameter specifies how long an unused artifact will be stored before it is removed. Once reaching this period Artifacts will be removed in the next invocation of cleanup. For more details please refer Cleanup Unused Cached Artifacts in Regular Maintenance Operations.
Leaving the field empty (default) means that the artifact is stored indefinitely.

Other than that, you can use Artifactory User Plugins to achieve the deletion of artifacts based on their creation / modification date. 
You can read more about User Plugins [here|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/User+Plugins]. 

Hope that helps.

27/Aug/19 6:54 AM;mb;+1 for this feature for local repositories.

A field on local repositories where an expiry time can be entered would be extremely useful. In reality we only need to keep snapshots for a month and releases for maybe 6 months to a year.

column1: Extend SAML Authentication to protect artifact download links
column45:
Artifactory currently only executes SAML authentication for logon - not for download or other API-based interactions.

Seems inconsistent as Artifactory does NOT prompt for LDAP/local credentials when using a download link in a previously authenticated-via-SAML session.

This would suggest the download context path is being protected (and thereby trusting) SAML authentication.

We need SAML authentication to protect artifact download links, ie. context paths not under /webapp
column250: 16/Nov/17 12:42 AM;ryan.currah;This is something we would like to enable as well. The workaround is to cumbersome. We would like people to use service accounts to download artifacts from AD. But if SAML doesnt work for non-webapp auth it makes it harder to use.

column1: add REST api capability to set watches
column45:
Currently setting watches is available from the UI only.
It should also be available via REST api.
column249: 06/Nov/19 9:01 AM;rvaidhya@visa.com;Just for me to be clear about this request. I am looking for the ability to apply a new watch on existing artifacts via REST Api.  Applying a watch on existing content can only be done via UI and also that the watch shouldnt be created including all repositories.

column1: VCS remote repositories with GitHub as the provider try to query GitHub even when the URL is different
column45:
VCS remote repositories with GitHub as the provider try to query GitHub even when the URL is different.

To reproduce:

1. Create a remote VCS repository
2. Set the provider to GitHub
3. Set the URL to a different (Enterprise) GitHub
4. Try requesting a file
5. Notice that it tries to reach out to GitHub but eventually does try the actual URL


h4. Artifactory.log
{noformat}
2017-03-16 04:22:36,034 [http-nio-8081-exec-9] [DEBUG] (o.a.a.v.r.VcsResource:97) - Using tag name '1.0.0' with internal filepath 'README.md'
2017-03-16 04:22:36,860 [http-nio-8081-exec-9] [INFO ] (o.a.r.HttpRepo      :415) - vcs-remote downloading https://gitent.jfrog.info/andreik/someRepo.git/info/refs?service=git-upload-pack Unknown content length 
2017-03-16 04:22:36,978 [http-nio-8081-exec-9] [INFO ] (o.a.r.HttpRepo      :428) - vcs-remote downloaded  https://gitent.jfrog.info/andreik/someRepo.git/info/refs?service=git-upload-pack 384 bytes at 3.21 KB/sec

2017-03-16 04:22:38,467 [http-nio-8081-exec-9] [INFO ] (o.a.r.HttpRepo      :428) - vcs-remote downloaded  https://gitent.jfrog.info/andreik/someRepo.git/info/refs?service=git-upload-pack 384 bytes at 5.24 KB/sec

column1: Ability to configure Reverse Proxy using configuration yaml file.
column45: As of now with config YAML, we can only setup proxy and create repositories. It will be great to have the way to configure a reverse proxy for docker. This feature will help to automate providing artifactory as docker registry for container orchestration systems like kubernetes, openshift, DC/OS.

column1: Flag empty system exports that have implemented repository replication
column45:
A user almost had their repositories wiped when they imported a systems configuration export that had "exclude content" checked.

The empty Artifactory instance used push replication to delete everything in the other servers until it was stopped. The user would like safe guards in place to prevent other users from having the same thing happen on a production instance.

They also mentioned having a "Disable Replication" checkbox in the exports tab to prevent things like this from happening accidentally.

column1: Add the ability to report why an Artifact is blocked by XRay
column45:
At the moment, an Artifactory user has two ways of knowing an Artifact is blocked:

1. Trying to download it
*  Artifactory returns a 403 with an error stating that the Artifact is blocked with no indication as to why or a "next step"

2. Via the properties
* Either via the UI or some sort of REST call

In both of these cases the user will, at most, know the severity of the issue. The desired information would be:

1. The nature of the issues(s)
2. The versions (if any) of the Artifact that do not suffer from these issues
3. (Optionally) A link to the component in XRay
* This can be in either the properties or the HTTP 403 error

column1: Support retry when downloading artifact from remote instance
column45:
Artifactory remote repository proxy a repo from external remote instance and download artifact from external remote when user requests.
But the remote repo will not retry if downloading failed for the first time,  for some cases, it could be success with retry: for example:

$: wget http://www.soapui.org/repository/maven2/com/smartbear/ready-api-soapui/1.9.0/ready-api-soapui-1.9.0.jar
--2017-02-28 10:49:28--  http://www.soapui.org/repository/maven2/com/smartbear/ready-api-soapui/1.9.0/ready-api-soapui-1.9.0.jar
Resolving www.soapui.org... 50.57.35.134
Connecting to www.soapui.org|50.57.35.134|:80... connected.
HTTP request sent, awaiting response... 301 Moved Permanently
Location: http://smartbearsoftware.com/repository/maven2/com/smartbear/ready-api-soapui/1.9.0/ready-api-soapui-1.9.0.jar [following]
--2017-02-28 10:49:28--  http://smartbearsoftware.com/repository/maven2/com/smartbear/ready-api-soapui/1.9.0/ready-api-soapui-1.9.0.jar
Resolving smartbearsoftware.com... 50.57.35.40
Connecting to smartbearsoftware.com|50.57.35.40|:80... connected.
HTTP request sent, awaiting response... 200 OK
Length: 12696820 (12M) [application/java-archive]
Saving to: `ready-api-soapui-1.9.0.jar.1'

49% [================================================================================>                                                                                   ] 6,324,478   1.25M/s   in 5.1s    

2017-02-28 10:49:33 (1.19 MB/s) - Read error at byte 6324478/12696820 (Connection reset by peer). Retrying.

--2017-02-28 10:49:34--  (try: 2)  http://smartbearsoftware.com/repository/maven2/com/smartbear/ready-api-soapui/1.9.0/ready-api-soapui-1.9.0.jar
Connecting to smartbearsoftware.com|50.57.35.40|:80... connected.

Length: 12696820 (12M), 6372342 (6.1M) remaining [application/java-archive]
Saving to: `ready-api-soapui-1.9.0.jar.1'

100%[+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++==================================================================================>] 12,696,820  2.45M/s   in 2.5s

"wget" supports retry, so I can download the artifacts successfully with it, but using Artifactory, I got error code 404: Failed to read stream: Connection reset

Hope Artifactory could also support retry and resume downloading from some point.

column1: Support for SaltStack SPM
column45:
In the latest version of Artifactory 5.1 there is support for puppet and chef repositories, I am wanting to request that similar support for SaltStack repositories be made as part of a future release


regards

Daniel
column249: 18/Aug/17 2:41 PM;rsemburakkiannan;It would be great if this feature is supported !

column1: Artifactory REST API
column45:
Hello, 
my goal is to navigate via REST through the +complete+ IVY-Repository (virtual) and find all ivy-{version}.xml files. 

*+1. enhancement ("Folder Info" and "File Info")+* I noticed that is not possible with "Folder Info" and "File Info", because they only support local, local-cached and virtual repositories. Even inside the virtual repository only the entries from "local" or "local-cached" repositories will be included at result (JSON).

My favorite approach will be to include also the not cached information from remote repository. Maybe you can add a additional optional query parameter to include also content information of (not cached) remote repositories (because this request will take a little longer). And I think it would be useful to add a flag that shows if it is a local/ cached artifact or not. For example:

"children": [
{
            "uri" : "/child1",
            "folder" : "true"
_            "local" : "false"_
        },{

*+2. bug - File List)+* My second approach is to use the "File List" REST-Interface, the documentation told me: +"2.5.2. Supported by all types of repositories."+. In my opinion this means even the _not_cached_ remote artifacts should be listet into the result of this request. But also at this result only the local and local-cached repositories will be included. In my opinion this is a bug.

*+3. solution - own implementation)+* I prefer to to use a REST-Interface that is already present and only my last resort is to implement a plugin to solve this requirement.

I hope someone can help me very soon.

Thanks in advance, Oli
column249: 08/Aug/19 5:22 PM;mike-j;Is this being considered at all?  Our organization has had to work around this for the past few years by manually querying all of our geo-specific instances.

column1: Ability to specify shards for repository
column45: Users would like to be able to specify which repositories will be in specific shards in their filestore. For example, docker images would be set onto a shard that is a 250GB SSD, while others are on slower filestore systems.
column249: 09/May/18 7:03 PM;Mike.KlusmanIII;This type of behavior would be a nice to have in the event particularly heavy used repositories could be placed onto better storage hardware and less active repositories could be moved to slower spindle hardware.  If the capability of targeting filestores which have differing read/write access (or are not co-located – i.e. network limited) was possible, then high demand repositories could be properly "positioned' to take advantage of appropriate hardware especially if the overall hardware components are of differing sizes.
column250:
05/Apr/19 5:40 PM;pbusque;We are migrating from Nexus to Artifactory.

We kept all our 'old' build into an 'archive' repository on a different disk volume (fewer backup, slower disk, fewer maintenance) while all our active build were keep in a more reliable volume (hourly backup, faster disk, daily maintenance task).

 

We're a bit disappointed that this feature is missing and we would really like to see this feature built in Artifactory too.  Since Artifactory already has a notion of build store, I should be doable to define multiple one and have the choice to pick which one we want during the creation of a repository (and the ability to move between filestore).

column1: BinaryStore - differentiating binaries on the cache according to their size
column45:
Need to add flag on the cache fs binary provider to limit cache of binaries which extends certain size.
This will give users flexibility on binaries which are stored on the cache and those who won't. 

The ability to differentiate binaries will come handy to facilitate the performance as cache is locally compare to the remote filestore

column1: CLI Artifactory command should allow to provide Principal field to build info
column45: In Artifactory CLI there is a command for publishing build info to Artifactory. It is Build Integration - Publish Build (build-publish). Currently, it does not allow to provide build principal - the person who run the build. As a result of this user who is used by CLI to authenticate to artifactory is used to populate build info information - fields  Principal and Artifactory Principal.
column249:
07/Feb/17 8:31 AM;krihelis;Please refer to https://github.com/JFrogDev/jfrog-cli-go/issues/38 to get updates regarding this feature request. 
Closing this issue as this JIRA project is for Artifactory related issues. CLI issues and requests should be opened at https://github.com/JFrogDev/jfrog-cli-go/

column1: Allow for scanning user plugin directory recursivly.
column45:
While writing user plugins for Artifactory, I find that I want to create a directory structure to keep things "lean and mean".  While talking with your support staff (see ticket #54774), I found that all user plugins must be in a single (flat) directory. 

I'd like to suggest that we, the users, be allowed to create a directory structure within the user plugins directory and have Artifactory load all plugins recursively.

column1: When delete permission is missing for a user return a more meaningful error message
column45:
We don't allow release version to be overwritten, since that would impact the integrity of the releases. This implies the users do not have the DELETE permission. When a user tries to deploy a release artifact for the second time he now gets a error message like:
Caused by: org.apache.maven.artifact.deployer.ArtifactDeploymentException: Error deploying
artifact: Authorization failed: Access denied to:

The error message could be more meaningful since the fact that the user is missing the DELETE permission is logged in catalina.out. Instead of returning the above message, stating that the delete permission is required to deploy a released artifact would be very beneficial.

column1: Feature Request: Support for Rust
column45:
Rust is collecting quite a following and currently has no solution to the local package management + cache problem that artifactory solves.

This feature request would provide a way to mirror & cache crates.io whilst allowing for local publish of company specific packages.

The crates.io repository is [here|https://github.com/rust-lang/crates.io] and specifically includes this warning:
"DISCLAIMER: The process of setting up a mirror is a work-in-progress and is likely to change. It is not currently recommended for mission-critical production use. It also requires a version of cargo newer than 0.13.0-nightly (f09ef68 2016-08-02); the version of cargo currently on rustc's beta channel fulfils this requirement and will be shipped with rustc 1.12.0 scheduled to be released on 2016-09-29."

so some work would probably be required to achieve this.

If you do decide to proceed with it then it's likely that you can get significant support from the rust community if you're willing to push changes back upstream to the crates.io project. Equally, my company will likely need to solve this problem ourselves and so it's possible that we could liaise with your engineers to speed things up or providing testing resource.
column249:
09/May/17 11:21 PM;alexlaverty;Hi jFrog,

We would also like Rust/Cargo support from Artifactory. Can you please let us know the timeline of when this functionality will be available?

Regards Alex
column250:
03/Jan/18 1:26 AM;yao;Having this support in JFrog would clear a blocker toward using Rust in an official capacity at Twitter. Would really appreciate if this issue sees some traction.

Thanks,
Yao
column251:
18/Jan/18 6:56 AM;psubramanian;+1. Add this please

Thanks,
Prathap
column253: 10/Feb/19 9:06 PM;maxime.legault-venne@elementai.com;+1
column254: 20/Feb/19 8:54 PM;chrish;FYI, the pull request for supporting alternate package registries for Rust crates in Cargo landed on master 8 days ago. So it should be on the next beta (1.33) February 28th (i.e. next week!), and would be stable with Rust 1.34 on April 11th, if everything goes well.
column258: 06/Apr/19 3:59 PM;andygrove;+1 here too. It's hard to adopt Rust for closed-source projects without this.
column259: 02/May/19 11:52 PM;mamoreau;+1 this is a feature we are very eager to use!
column260:
03/May/19 12:19 AM;nbigaouette-eai;Rust v1.34 (stable) was released on April 11th 2019 with support for alternative registries. See [https://blog.rust-lang.org/2019/04/11/Rust-1.34.0.html]

 

Also, cloudsmith added support for being an alternative cargo registry. See announcing post: [https://blog.cloudsmith.io/2019/05/01/worlds-first-private-cargo-registry/] and discussion on reddit: [https://www.reddit.com/r/rust/comments/bjk1qu/worlds_first_private_cargo_registry_rust_134/]
column261: 14/May/19 7:11 PM;jtrepanier;+1 this feature is a must have
column274:
25/Jan/20 10:50 PM;bhipple;I think it makes sense to implement and ship this issue in two phases:
 # Implement functionality for providing a read-only mirror of crates.io for cargo. 
 # Implement functionality for providing an internal read-write crate endpoint for proprietary package publishing.

For a large number of users, (1) is sufficient for their needs, and much simpler to implement.  This allows an enterprise environment to build against open source Rust dependency libraries and tools, while still using their own source control / package management systems for their own proprietary packages.
column275: 12/Feb/20 12:37 AM;jwright;I am good with this as long as number 2 isn't too distant. At the moment we are making due using git urls for private repos, but I would prefer to have everything versioned and in artifactory.
column278:
28/Mar/20 2:20 PM;dell.green;In the meantime, I have been taking the following project for a spin that satisfies (1):

[https://github.com/ChrisMacNaughton/cargo-cacher]
column279:
21/Apr/20 3:26 AM;unional;Also need this in my company.

And for the time being, here is an OSS: [https://github.com/Hirevo/alexandrie]
column282: 28/Sep/20 3:41 PM;jainishshah17;+1 Workday is also looking for ETA on this one.
column285: 15/Oct/20 9:13 AM;vimselva;This issue has been open since long. It would be great if this can be expedited. The rust lang is one of the most voted language in stack overflow survey and most of the enterprises would definitely willing to bet on this language. I definitely recommend to provide a support for rust lang. Please do the needful.
column287: 18/Dec/20 4:19 PM;bgard6977;If these guys can do it, can you just copy what they did? https://cloudsmith.com/blog/worlds-first-private-cargo-registry-w-cloudsmith-rust/
column289: 21/Jan/21 10:29 AM;evgenyka;We are working on it and hopefully there will be an update and announce soon - stay tuned!

column1: Support package format - Function Mockup Unit
column45:
Tesla is interested in deploying a package format called Function Mockup Unit on their Artifactory server.

This package is an open industry standard (https://www.fmi-standard.org), and is essentially a zip file containing binaries, sources, and an XML metadata. 

They are very interested in having automatic support for this metadata in their Artifactory server so that it will display and query these deployed packages.

column1: Remote repo health check
column45:
Feature request for a health check of remote repositories. 

Scenario:
Sometimes a remote site will go offline/out of business or its URL endpoint may change. Example codehaus which moved onto maven central. Sometimes the old site will return a HTML page with a HTTP code of 200, sometimes the endpoint will return a 404. In either case the issue is difficult to track down and administrators are only made aware after working with support. 

Improvement:
Have a health check process that will attempt to use each remote repo in a way that verifies their health. Per-repo this can be incorporated into the "Test" button. Per Artifactory instance this could either be a background check that displays the status in the admin alert bar or a manual check done from the maintenance page.

We need to think of what can be done to verify the repo is really accessible while there might be a reverse proxy in front of it that might return a 200 response with an empty HTML page.

column1: Allow administrators to set the default repos for "Set Me Up"
column45: For administrators it's not possible to set the default repos. For example when a user generates the maven settings file he will get the repos ordered by name. This seems quite random to us and we'd like to be able to specify the default repos. For example we'd like to set libs-releases as the default for releases. If there would be a alibs-releases repo, it will be the default at the moment.

column1: Enrich data in Artifactory for Docker, RPM artifacts
column45:
Artifactory is capable of storing artifacts like Docker images, rpm files etc. There is little metadata available for the end user to understand what is in the image or rpm. If Artifactory want to be the hub for deployments, it needs to provide more information to the end user about things like:
* description
* how to use the artifact
* the dockerfile

My thinking would be that the exiting Docker tab can be used for this. Right now the layers that make up the docker image are visible. It would be great if we can get more information in there as well. For example similar to what Docker Hub is providing.

For RPM files the same is true. As a user you'd want to know which files are installed, have a description etc.

column1: 'Compress the internal database' path is hardcoded
column45: When using the derby database and a custom db.home location, Artifactory works however you cannot compress the internal database, Artifactory will use the old db.home($ARTIFACTORY/data/derby) path, and say that it does not exist

column1: Cascading delete of (sub)folders
column45:
Hello team,
given a repo "repo" containing the following structure of subfolders: a>b>c, in the Repo Browser, I'd like to have the option to directly delete the whole structure starting with "a" i.e. opening a context menu on "a" naming "Recursively Delete", the entire structure is removed comprising "a>b>c". At the moment, I have to delete all its parts sequential step by step. That can be annoying and unnecessary speeds down the workflow.
Thank you.

column1: Deleting 'Server Path For Backup' from backup job backs up to '$ARTIFACTORY_HOME/bin'
column45:
If you change the 'Server Path For Backup' on a backup job and save, it will backup up correctly to this folder.
However, if you remove this from the job and leave the filed empty (as it was to begin with) and save, Artifactory backs up the job to the '$ARYIFACTORY_HOME/bin' folder.
If you enter the backup job configuration again, you will see this path in the field.

column1: Make export/import more configurable
column45:
Currently, you can only export/import the entire system or one repo at a time. Instead, please give more options for the import, including
- multiple repositories
- private keys
- master keys
- configs
- build

The backup mechanism has some of these features, but it would be nice to have them in the import/export page as well.

column1: Allow properties to be added to virtual repositories
column45:
Allow properties to be added to virtual repositories.

At the moment, properties can only be added to local and remote cache repositories. Under some circumstances, it would be helpful to be able to add/retrieve properties from the virtual repository itself (not the artifacts under it).

Use case: End-users want to be able to set properties on files aggregated in the local repositories without knowing what those local repositories are.
column249: 09/Mar/18 1:51 PM;mrichar2;This is needed when using a full-mesh multi-push replication scheme. Virtual repositories are created to hide the local repository shards on each instance. Users interact with the virtual repositories instead of the local ones.
column250: 30/Jul/19 7:49 AM;luc.stroobant@wdc.com;Please implement this, it's a usability feature. By not supporting to set properties on a virtual repo, you're making life much more complicated for users of replication.
column251: 05/Aug/19 12:11 PM;krihelis;You can add properties to artifacts as part of the deployment to the virtual repository using matrix params. See [https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Using+Properties+in+Deployment+and+Resolution].
column252: 07/Oct/20 2:40 PM;soberoi@tableau.com;Please prioritize this feature. This would be a really helpful feature, specially for full-mesh replication setup as clients interact with virtual repositories.

column1: add REST api to remove a node from an HA cluster
Optimize System Storage (or other) API should balance artifacts to newly added shards
column45:
{color:#d04437}colored text{color}When the "PercentageFreeSpace" write behavior strategy is used - one shard (in example the original NFS mount/filestore) can have considerably more disk space utilized then newly added shards (NFS mounts) which could even be empty. 

The Optimize System Storage API should move existing artifacts from the primary volume to any newly added shard volumes to balance the occupied disk space percentage to be more even. Simply put: In this use case, sharding was not initially setup, so the primary volume is much larger than the newly added volumes.

column1: Touch REST API call
column45: Request to add a "touch" REST API call that can be used to update the "last downloaded" date in order to cause cleanup mechanisms to skip the touched file.

column1: Allow differentiation between LDAP login and user name
column45: Some LDAP users use their email address as a login. When doing so, the address is displayed as the user name in Artifactory ("Welcome mikem..."). Users would like to be able to differentiate the two. i.e., login with an email address, but use some other value as the display name.

column1: Allow customizing which package types to display in the home page
column45:
Currently, Artifactory displays all available package types. 

This is a feature request to allow displaying only the packages that an admin wants its users to see, so they will know which repository types that the admin has setup.

column1: Provide a way to change background color for the top area surrounding custom logo
column45:
Currently, Artifactory provides a way to add a custom logo, but it does not provide a way to customize colors around the logo.

This is a feature request to add a feature that allows this.

column1: Add email address to user created by HTTP SSO
column45:
HTTP-SSO - when configuring the login with “auto create user” the user is created without an e-mail address.
Create a user with an e-mail address (when an e-mail address is included in the HTTP Header)

column1: Docker cleaning
column45:
Hi,
We store in our docker repository a few types of tags, an example below:
# <artifactory_docker_registry>/abc:latest uploaded at 1 PM
# <artifactory_docker_registry>/abc:1.0 uploaded at 2 PM
# <artifactory_docker_registry>/abc:1.1-SNAPSHOT uploaded at 3 PM

*What is a problem?*
When I add value 1 to the fileld "Max Unique Tags" in docker repository preferences a auto clean process will delete all tag except the newest "abc:1.1-SNAPSHOT".

It is possible to add a feature that user can define which docker tag is exluded from the cleaning? For example I want to define "latest" and "cache-latest" tag as a unremovable for the cleaning process.

Another thing. When I have in my repository a few images and some images was tagged SNAPSHOT I need to clean only tags with SNAPSHOT in name.

If any of this is possible to be added in a future versions of Artifactory?
column249: 25/Apr/18 9:46 AM;czardis;If Max Unique Tags will happily delete special tags such as 'latest', this functionality is not yet useful for us. Could anyone from JFrog confirm this is the case?

column1: Support the new Gradle resolution convention
Support for Ansible Galaxy Repos
column45:
Provide the ability to use Artifactory as an [Ansible Galaxy|https://galaxy.ansible.com/intro] repository, both as a remote caching proxy repo (e.g. through to [https://galaxy.ansible.com|https://galaxy.ansible.com/]) and as a local repo.

 

Based on the documentation, it looks like the ansible-galaxy cli can point to a different server (e.g. Artifactory) via the -s, --server flag (it defaults to [https://galaxy.ansible.com|https://galaxy.ansible.com/]).

 

*References:*
 * [Other useful cli documentation|https://www.mankier.com/1/ansible-galaxy]
 * [Galaxy source code|https://github.com/ansible/galaxy]
column249:
01/Mar/17 5:22 PM;darknerd;We (goBalto) are highly interested in this, as we need to version our roles (Ansible term for module or cookbook).  We are single-tenant shop, with customers on different versions, so there needs to be change-config code that matches the correct code base.  Having a local repository would grant us the ability to version our roles in a privately Galaxy repo, which corresponds to version of the code. This would be tremendous value-add for our organization, and almost certainly allows us standardize on Artifactory as the defacto solution for repos.

Also, we heavily use containers (docker) with immutable production patterns.  Ansible is very popular light-weight deploy and change-config tool for these solutions.  Unlike chef/puppet that are heavy weights for runtime change config, in the immutable production world, you don't need heavy robust change config, and so Ansible is incredibly popular in docker crowds for this reason.  We use it for deploy time change-config, e.g. templated environment variables or watch/wrapper scripts, and also for orchestration of containers and AWS cloud resources.
column250:
02/Mar/17 6:22 AM;alexlaverty;Hi Support,

Is this feature on the roadmap for development? Has any progress been made. 
We would also like to pull ansible galaxy roles through artifactory.

Regards Alex

Consider a *vcs-remote-github* VCS Artifactory repository, sample with [bbaassssiiee.artifactory|https://galaxy.ansible.com/bbaassssiiee/artifactory/] role, having a dependency on [bbaassssiiee.base_java8|https://galaxy.ansible.com/bbaassssiiee/base_java8/] ... _requirements.yml_ file looks like:
{code}
# Declare manually the dependencies of role to use 
- src: http://artifactory.company.com/api/vcs/downloadBranch/vcs-remote-github/bbaassssiiee/base_java8/master
  name: bbaassssiiee.base_java8
     
# Refer to role, here not the master but a specific tag
- src: http://artifactory.company.com/api/vcs/downloadTag/vcs-remote-github/bbaassssiiee/artifactory/v1.1.0
  name: bbaassssiiee.artifactory
{code}

Now this command works:
{code}
ansible-galaxy install -r requirements.yml
{code}

.... perhaps some limitations ... this usage is experimental ^^

column1: Allow for better security control and auditing features
column45:
Many Defense & Finance companies require thorough security controls and auditing abilities. For example:

* Certain customers would like to disable REST API access for Administrator users for security and auditing reasons. 
* more fine grained logging for copy & move operations in addition to being able to control them(currently no logging is done for copy&move operations)
* Ability to remove Artifactory Administrator access to selected repositories
* Ability remove API access to Administrator functions 
* When allowing the Artifactory Administrator export of repositories, only allow those repositories they have access to
* Ability to keep the record of any given/applied permissions for auditing purposes

Activiites with the secure repository should be auditable

column1: Logout link does nothing with HTTP SSO
column45:
We have the Artifactory HTTP SSO plugin installed and working. The UI still shows a Logout link that is useless, since the SSO user is automatically logged back in.

Preferably we could use the Logout link to set a cookie saying the user logged out. The HTTP SSO plugin could then look for that cookie and if set pass authentication processing on to the next method in the chain; effectively disabling the plugin on a per-session basis.

This would allow us to use a single Admin user in conjunction with regular user accounts.

Failing that, the Logout link should be hidden as it is useless.
column249:
27/Feb/17 12:08 PM;johannes.langer;As this issue is still open, we used a workaround in the meantime to redirect to a custom URL when clicking the logout link in Artifactory.
We are using Apache in front of Artifactory which allows to modify responses, Following locationmatch injects a custom URL (tested with apache 2.4 /artifactory 5):

<LocationMatch "^/artifactory/webapp/artifactory_services.*">
  AddOutputFilterByType SUBSTITUTE application/javascript
  Substitute "s|User.logout().then(function () {|User.logout().then(function () { 	User.$window.location.href = '${ARTIFACTORY_LOGOUT_URL}';|in"

  ProxyPass "${REMOTE_BASE_URL}"
  ProxyPassReverse "${REMOTE_BASE_URL}"
</LocationMatch>

Nevertheless I suggest to fix this issue and add the ability to provide a custom logout link for HTTP SSO, which can be used to also logout at the Authentication provider!

column1: Add support for GitLFS file locking
column45:
Currently when a user attempts to lock a git LFS repository, they get a 404 Not Found error. Since the command is currently not supported by Artifactory, this error can lead to users believing there is a configuration problem.

Git has built-in tools for resolving merge conflicts in text files (such as source code, documentation, etc). The git lfs track command includes a --lockable flag. Users can then lock the file on the LFS repository by using the following command:
$ git lfs lock images/foo.jpg

Artifactory should limit read access on locked LFS files once it receives the following API endpoints:

POST /api/lfs/<LFS_REPO>/locks/verify
POST /api/lfs/<LFS_REPO>/locks

A more verbose description of the Locking API endpoint can be found [on the Git LFS wiki. |https://github.com/git-lfs/git-lfs/wiki/File-Locking]


[Ariel K] :  https://github.com/git-lfs/git-lfs/wiki/File-Locking

column1: Masking of artifacts
column45: The issue (http://forums.jfrog.org/Filtering­a­package­out­of­a­PyPI­remote­repo­td7581099.html) is that we have a custom binary for a Python package in an Artifactory­hosted PyPI repo that is merged with the public PyPI repo in a virtual repository. The standard Python package installer (pip) is preferring a binary hosted in the public repo over the one that we published. I expected that I could use exclude­ patterns in the repo definitions (either the remote or the virtual repo) to exclude the public version of the package. When I do this, it does prevent clients from downloading the binary. However, it doesn't prevent Artifactory from advertising the presence of the package in the repo index. As a result, our installer thinks that the file is there and requests a download, but then errors out when the file is not found.

column1: New function to lock/unlock the HA Artifactory system for maintaining underlying systems
column45:
In enterprise Artifactory HA systems we need to be able to maintain the underlying systems, like external Database and external Storage, separately. 

In order to be able to keep a consistent state in Artifactory between DB and Storage when a maintenance of one of these systems is required, we need a functionality, which enables to set Artifactory generally into a locked state. 

- Each lock should use a unique token, which can be used for unlocking the application again by the administrator.
- If an Artifactory lock was initiated, the users are not allowed to start new operations, which require the availability of both DB and Storage (a maintenance window appears on the Web UI). If a drained state is reached, the underlying system's (DB and/or the Storage) maintenance can be processed.

If the Database and Storage is available unlock of  can be processed using the token.
column46: Example: RHEL 7 servers with load balancer, Oracle 12c DB, NFS NetApp File Share

column1: Federated Model to support AWS, Azure, etc
column45:
The overarching requirement, is to have a central ON PREMISE Artifactory Service that can shard information out to AWS, Azure, etc WITHOUT incurring significant download charges.       

Background 

While the initial focus of what we are doing is to establish an on-premise Artifactory repository for Open Source, we want the same group maintaining this new service to extend the capabilities to allow teams to their binary application deployment artifacts.   Having to maintain multiple Artifactory  installations (On Premise, AWS, Azure)  is not ideal in any scenario. 

While I don’t know the specifics of Artifactory, I wanted to describe how I could see this happening.   As part of the sharding setup for a given subdirectory, there would be an option for  specifying which Cloud Service (AWS, Azure, etc) is providing the storage – and requiring some type of  Artifactory “agent” running on that Cloud instance.  

The role of that agent would be to handle both reads/writes to that subdirectory –

1.	 Allowing teams to “Read”/access files the subdirectory without having to be downloaded

2.	Abstracting the write process – where the file gets written to the Cloud Storage WITHOUT having to be “downloaded” in any format.   Yes, there would be some information sent down specific to Metadata, but that would be acceptable

NOTE:  In a sense this could be considered  a Federated model.  But the goal is to maximize the usage of the service we are standing up, so we avoid having to install full Artifactory installations in other locations

In addition to the duplicated storage count, we should display the storage usage of files that only exist in that repository. (We could also have a separate dialog that lists the files in an AQL).

This would feature would be for administrators who want to tell certain teams to clean certain repositories in order to free up storage.

column1: Allow plugins to react to security descriptor changes
column45:
We have a requirement to replicate security settings between our Artifactory clusters. We are not using Mission Control to duplicate the setting of permissions, as we want users in teams to have the ability to manage their project permissions. MC's permissions structure does not allow for this. At the moment we restrict administrative actions to one cluster and periodically run a process to export the security descriptor, and load it into the other cluster. This works but is cumbersome and would not work with Mission Control.

Ideally we would write a plugin that would react to permission target update events; a similar set of triggers to those available for builds or artefact replication would be ideal. It would also allow us to enforce restrictions on the granting of certain permissions, e.g. disallowing the addition of individual users to targets in favour of groups.
column249: 02/Aug/16 3:44 PM;brad.macpherson@fmr.com;Allowing plugins to react to and veto security changes could remove the need for RTFACT-9965 as its functionality could then be implemented in a plugin.

column1: Add support for dnf packages
column45: https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Dnf
column249: 05/Mar/20 8:52 PM;cindycelata;yes pls do
column250:
10/Apr/20 9:53 PM;johnw;This should work with all versions of Artifactory and DNF, as DNF is an updated version of YUM (DNF stands for Dandified YUM).

However, I tested this with version 7.3.2 of Artifactory and DNF 4.2.7.

DNF utilizes three methods of adding repositories:
 # Adding a <repo>.repo to /etc/yum.repos.d/ per YUM standards.
 # Modifying the /etc/dnf/dnf.conf to add additional repos, following the same convention as a .repo file.
 # Running dnf config-manager --add-repo <repo-url>

I've tested with all three methods. My steps for each method will be below.

Before you begin:
 Artifactory with "Quick Setup" RPM repository.

*yum.repos.d:*

Move the files in /etc/yum.repos.d/ to another folder or rename to not end in .repo (mv *.repo ../old_repos/)

Create an artifactory.repo with the following text:
{code:java}
[Artifactory.repo]
name=Artifactory
baseurl=http://admin:password@artifactory:8081/artifactory/rpm/8/BaseOS/x86_64/os
enabled=1
gpgcheck=0{code}
dnf install tree

Note: Repository in the dnf install will show Artifactory.repo and after installing, the package will exist in rpm-remote-cache.

*dnf.conf:*

Move the files in /etc/yum.repos.d/ to another folder or rename to not end in .repo (mv *.repo ../old_repos/)

Add the following text to your dnf.conf:
{code:java}
[Artifactory.conf]
name=Artifactory
baseurl=http://admin:password@artifactory:8081/artifactory/rpm/8/BaseOS/x86_64/os
enabled=1
gpgcheck=0
{code}
dnf install zip

Note: Repository in the dnf install will show Artifactory.conf and after installing, the package will exist in rpm-remote-cache.

*config-manager:*

Move the files in /etc/yum.repos.d/ to another folder or rename to note end in .repo (mv *.repo ../old_repos/)

dnf config-manager --add-repo [http://admin:password@artifactory:8081/artifactory/rpm/8/BaseOS/x86_64/os]

dnf install nano

Note: Repository in the dnf install will show the above URL and after installing, the package will exist in rpm-remote-cache.

See [this comment|https://www.jfrog.com/jira/browse/RTFACT-9945?focusedCommentId=41539&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-41539] and [the that follows it|https://www.jfrog.com/jira/browse/RTFACT-9945?focusedCommentId=41540&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-41540].
column251:
07/Sep/16 5:53 PM;markg;So this is actually functioning as designed.
That is to say that as things stand right now, artifactory intentionally does not preserve layers that are not part of a defined tag.  So if you only ever pushed a layer to 'latest' and then you overwrite the 'latest' tag, the previous layers that are now no longer part of a defined tag are marked for cleanup.   Generally this is very much a desired behavior, although I can understand some use cases where it might not be.  In general our recommended behavior is that you push to a defined-version (or build number or whatever) tag, and then use the promote API to copy that tag to latest, rather than pushing directly to latest, so you have a defined human-readable tag to retrieve an earlier version.
column252: 07/Sep/16 9:01 PM;elyscape;I understand that, but my point is that it would be very useful to be able to access a certain number of old versions of a tag, like with Maven snapshots. This is something that is done by the Docker Hub and Docker's Registry, as well as [Quay|https://docs.quay.io/guides/tag-operations.html#viewing-tag-history-and-going-back-in-time] (both hosted and enterprise) and basically every other Docker registry project out there. The whole point of Docker image digests is that they're immutable and generally accessible even once the tag has moved on, with different projects offering different ways to clean up old images once they become unused.
column253: 21/Apr/17 8:46 PM;elyscape;This is actually worse now. Uploading a Docker image with the same name and tag will send the old layers into the trash and overwrite the manifest entirely, making it impossible to retrieve even the most recent old image.
column254: 02/Aug/18 7:42 PM;dhopkins;This is still an issue for me and my company. It would be great if the option to not trash old layers was exposed to operators. Instead, we'll have to write our own stuff to get around this issue by re-tagging every image with the sha256 just to keep it around. It's not going to be pretty. Developers would love to just use the traditional Docker and Dockerfile syntax like they do with every other registry out there (docker pull pkg_name@sha256:abcd... & FROM name@sha256:abcd...).
column255:
10/Aug/18 3:16 PM;cdenneen;Most registries give you the ability to cleanup untagged images older than X days.

I see this is discussing cleaning up old tags but should also include cleaning up untagged images as well.

column1: Internal RPM signing management
column45:
Artifactory can allow adding, replacing internal RPM signatures management abilities. This can be useful for having the option to change signing after a packages was already built and deployed. Moreover, should a key needs to be revoked - having this ability will assist with resigning with a new signature.

Examples by the RPM command line tool (packages can have or not have signatures already):

1. rpm --resign mycustomrpm-7.9-1.i386.rpm

It'll generate and append internal package signatures for the listed package(s) while preserving the existing ones. 

2. rpm --addsign mycustomrpm-7.9-1.i386.rpm

The --addsign option generates and inserts new signatures for each package. Any existing signatures will be discarded.

3. rpm --delsign mycustomrpm-7.9-1.i386.rpm

Removes any existing signatures

column1: Allow users/groups to Manage a subset of permissions on a permission target
column45:
See also https://support.jfrog.com/support/tickets/39438.

I have a permission target set up, giving Manage, Delete, Write, Annotate, and Read permission to group 'owner'. I want the 'owner' group’s members to be able to add or remove groups/users to/from the permission target, and to give any groups/users any combination of permissions.
 
Example two: I have a permission target with the group 'owner' having Manage, Deploy/Cache, Annotate, and Read permissions. In this case, I still want the 'owner' group’s members to be able to add or remove groups/users to/from the permission target, but I want them to only be able to grant any combination of manage, deploy/cache, annotate, and read permissions to other groups/users. The permission target in question is one for a Release repository, where in the specific case we want to remove ‘Delete’ permissions from all but the system administrator user; but the more general case, of AND-ing a management group’s permissions with any permissions modified by the management group, would allow us to be even more fine-grained in the future if needed.

column1: To enable read only mode during maintenance
column45:
There should be an option to make the system into "read only" mode for users to avoid any uploads, delete and annotating of artifacts during maintenance activity.
This is required to maintain the data consistency between filestore and DB.
This would be useful during version upgrade, DB upgrade, configuration changes.
Similar feature is available in most of the enterprise tools which we are using in our company.

ADDITIONAL OPTION:
in addition to making it read-only, there should be an option to be completely 'blacked out' globally (no uploads or downloads). We have that option at a per repo basis, but not globally.

column1: Checksum policy for different type of repositories
column45:
Checksum policy is currently only available for Maven, Gradle, Ivy and SBT Repositories.
Mainly because client by default perform checksum deploy on upload.

For other clients, checksum deploy is not the default (so implicitly, you can say the checksum policy is 'Trust server generated checksums' without the ability to change it)

Need to Implement same mechanism for other type of repositories when it is possible to perform checksum deploy from the client.
This will give the user to change the checksum policy for this repository to be more restrictive.

This would come in handy when creating multiple users that store their passwords internally.

Mainly concerning the Generic type repository, its structure may look like this: http://i.imgur.com/uAm2fAu.png - a tree of varying depth and branching. Artifactory is not able to correctly index multiple projects at once that have different structure.

column1: Support for SSH Resolver in Ivy
column45:
Add support for SSH Resolvers in Ivy. http://ant.apache.org/ivy/history/2.2.0/resolver/ssh.html . Currently it is able to attempt connecting and successfully connect via SSH, but fails to retrieve any artifacts despite the Artifact Pattern used. 

Example ivysettings.xml:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<ivy-settings>
  <settings defaultResolver="main" />
  <!--Authentication required for publishing (deployment). 'Artifactory Realm' is the realm used by Artifactory so don't change it.-->
  <credentials host="192.168.44.141:8081" realm="Artifactory Realm" username="admin" passwd="<encrypted pass>"/>
  <resolvers>
    <chain name="main">

      <ssh        name="3rdParty"
                  m2compatible="true"
                  user="admin"
                  host="l92.168.44.141"
                  port="1339"
                  keyFile="/Users/user/.ssh/id_rsa">
        <artifact pattern="/artifactory/my-maven-remote/[organization]/[module]/[revision]/[artifact]-[revision](-[classifier]).[ext]"/>
      </ssh>
      <ssh        name="Local"
                  m2compatible="true"
                  user="admin"
                  host="192.168.44.141"
                  port="1339"
                  keyFile="/Users/augustined/.ssh/id_rsa">
        <artifact pattern="/artifactory/my-maven-local/[organization]/[module]/[revision]/[artifact]-[revision](-[classifier]).[ext]"/>
      </ssh>
    </chain>
  </resolvers>
</ivy-settings>

And current relevant output:

[ivy:retrieve] :: SSH :: connecting to l92.168.44.141...
[ivy:retrieve] 	fb3rdPartyResolver: no ivy file nor artifact found for log4j#log4j;1.2.16
[ivy:retrieve] 		tried /artifactory/my-maven-local/log4j/log4j/1.2.16/log4j-1.2.16.jar
[ivy:retrieve] :: SSH :: connecting to 192.168.44.141...
[ivy:retrieve] :: SSH :: connected to 192.168.44.141!
[ivy:retrieve] 	fbReleaseResolver: no ivy file nor artifact found for log4j#log4j;1.2.16
[ivy:retrieve] WARN: 	module not found: log4j#log4j;1.2.16
[ivy:retrieve] WARN: ==== fb3rdPartyResolver: tried
[ivy:retrieve] WARN:   -- artifact log4j#log4j;1.2.16!log4j.jar:
[ivy:retrieve] WARN:   /artifactory/my-maven-remote/log4j/log4j/1.2.16/log4j-1.2.16.jar
[ivy:retrieve] WARN: ==== fbReleaseResolver: tried
[ivy:retrieve] WARN:   -- artifact log4j#log4j;1.2.16!log4j.jar:
[ivy:retrieve] WARN:   /artifactory/my-maven-local/log4j/log4j/1.2.16/log4j-1.2.16.jar

column1: Sencha Packages Repository Type
column45: Host and distribute Sencha packages in Artifactory and proxy remote Sencha repositories

column1: REST API: Deploy set of new artifacts
column45:
It would be helpful to have an API for pushing a set of new artifacts to Artifactory. where:
- *set* means to reference a local directory where all subdirectories and files are deployed (keeping the structure in Artifactory repo)
- *new* means that hash codes of those artifacts are generated and compared with the existing ones in the Artifactory target repo, and only if the checksum is different, the specific artifact is deployed.

column1: Ability to retrieve latest snapshot in latest base revision
column45:
Similar to the REST API currently available for pulling latest release version of a given artifact using [RELEASE] tag, we need a way to effectively pull the latest snapshot of the latest artifact version.
This should be made possible directly without providing a base revision number for the snapshot manually.

Main advantage of having this is to improve automation in a simple manner.

Would be good to have this for both maven and non-maven type artifacts.
column249:
14/Jan/19 4:57 PM;payoon;Is there any update on this?

We are using Artifactory as a replace of our Nexus service. However it seems there does not appear to be Nexus' equivalent of returning the latest version of a snapshot.
column250:
15/Jan/19 12:51 PM;awoodhead;Here is some more detail on the issue. When using Nexus we could fetch the latest SNAPSHOT version of an artifact (in the below example an RPM) with a single URL like this:

[https://nexushost/service/local/artifact/maven/redirect?r=repo-name&g=my.group.idp&a=my-artifact&v=LATEST&e=rpm]

This allows us to have a one liner with curl which effectively does "download the latest SNAPSHOT of my artifact". As described above Artifactory doesn't seem to provide anything like this for SNAPSHOTS which means we have to go through a multi-step process in order to download the latest SNAPSHOT. There are various different ways of doing this but we have ended up with the following:

 
{code:java}
BASE_ARTIFACTORY_URL=https://artyhost/
ARTIFACTORY_REPOSITORY=my-maven-snapshot-local
# first get _all_ files for this artifact from the SNAPSHOT repo
RESULT=$(curl $BASE_ARTIFACTORY_URL/api/search/pattern?pattern=$ARTIFACTORY_REPOSITORY:my/group/id/my-artifact/*/*.rpm)
# now sort the results to ensure we get the latest one
LATEST_FILE=$(echo $RESULT |  jq -r '.files | sort [-1]')
#now finally we can build up the download URL to pass to curl
DOWNLOAD_URL=$BASE_ARTIFACTORY_URL$ARTIFACTORY_REPOSITORY/$LATEST_FILE


{code}
This feels error prone and far from ideal, it would be great if Artifactory could perform the above logic for us so we could get a direct download URL to the latest SNAPSHOT the same way you can for the latest RELEASE.
column251: 01/Apr/19 4:16 PM;payoon;Any update on this feature request?

column1: addition features
column45:
hi,
i have an artifactory server, I would like to make an addition features. 
-download: i want to get all the packages of remote repository, and download them.
-synchronize: automatic sync caching for packages that where already downloaded.

for example:
I have a yum repository,  i want to download all the packages to my local disk and automatically sync if any changes. 
In sync feature, I wish to download only the delta, instead re-download the full package.

column1: Uploader of artifacts should be able to delete them
column45: As the uploader of an artifact I should be able to delete it without having admin or delete permissions.

column1: Ability to inhibit redeployment of artifacts
column45:
There is a feature that our group has grown accustomed to having in our previous binary storage server. The ability to not allow redeployment of release artifacts with the same GAV coordinates for maven artifacts.

We have some builds that allow users to type/choose a version, and inclusive GAV information. If that artifact already exists we want that to fail the action of storing that artifact. To circumvent that, one would have remove the artifact from AP or allow temporary ability to redeploy artifacts.

I would imagine a simple check box on a local repository's 'Basic' setting just below the 'Suppress POM Consistency Checks' a similar looking 'Prohibit redeployment of same artifacts'.

Thank you for your consideration,
Dave Oilar
EMC Inc.

column1: REST API to retrieve builds on individual status
column45:
This feature should allow us to retrieve build info and a list of builds based on a specific status.

Recommended API would be to add a ?status=<build status> to the APIs
so we would have:

/api/build/<build-name>?status=<build-status>  which would retrieve a list of all builds that are at a specific status in the release history  (?status=null should be an option to retrieve only unpromoted builds)
/api/build/<build-name>/#?status=<build-status> should return 404 if the specified build does not have the specified status
/api/build/<build-name>/latest should return the latest build irrespective of status
/api/build/<build-name>/latest?status=<build-status> should return the latest build to have retrieved a specfic build status.

column1: Add ability to track which user downloaded what

column1: Request to allow admin users to generate multiple API keys with varied permissions
column45:
In some scenarios it is common to create a "dummy" user which is used for various parts of the CI pipeline (CI server, git, etc.).

This request is to allow generation of several API keys by the same user (Admin) each with its own permissions.
This is in order to allow integration with CI servers and other "users" through the REST API without actually creating a new user.

column1: Remove SNAPSHOT version once the corresponding release artifact was deployed
column45:
Request: Ability to automatically delete the snapshot version of the artifact as soon as a release version is published.

eg:- 
Dev starts working on 1.0-SNAPSHOT in preparation to release version 1.0

Dev publishes their SNAPSHOTS to artifactory for other teams to consume as a dependency.

Its time to release 1.0 and dev updates the version in the pom.xml and kicks off the release job which publishes the artifact as 1.0.

Now that 1.0 has been released we don't need to maintain 1.0-SNAPSHOT anymore and artifactory identifies & deletes all the snapshot versions.

column1: Add a privilege: repository creation
column45:
As an administrative user on Artifactory, I want non-admin users in an authorized group to be able to create repositories, so that they can do work without waiting for my intervention.

As an administrative user on Artifactory, I also want this feature so that I don't have to give full admin privileges to a large group of users.

The specific context is git lfs repositories - we want a large group of trusted developers to be able to self-service the creation of Artifactory repositories of type 'git lfs'. Since there are many git repositories that would like to start leveraging git lfs, and we want to stick to the principle of least privilege, developers currently have to wait for an administrative Artifactory user to manually create an Artifactory repository of type 'git lfs' for each git repository. Creating finer-grained administrative privileges including repository creation would permit trusted users to self-service this common task while continuing to abide by the principle of least privilege.

column1: Limit OAuth to existing users only
column45:
OAuth is a great SSO solution. It would be useful however to permit access for already created users, so that one can bind its OAuth id with their account, but no accounts were created if the user was not found. Currently when option for autocreating users in OAuth SSO is disabled, a transient user is created and thus granted access, without even checking if a user exists in configured LDAP security.

Please make it possible to accept OAuth only for users that already exist.

column1: Provide guidance where to store license *text* associated with a third-party artifact
column45:
Our company makes shrink-wrapped software that we sell to customers, and our software includes third-party libraries.  We have a legal obligation to include specific license text to acknowledge each third-party dependency that ships with our product.  Let's call this document a TPLP ("third-party licenses page"), and here's one example for one of Amazon's products:  http://www.amazon.com/gp/help/customer/display.html?nodeId=201420340

When I ship my product, I have to include a TPLP, and I would like Artifactory to store the license *text* for artifacts (and not just the license *type*) so that I can generate my TPLP programmatically at build time.

Currently, I can't do this in Artifactory...I can tell Artifactory what *type* of license is associated with a third-party dependency, but that doesn't tell me the *text* of the license that should be included in my TPLP.  For example, if the author of a gem indicated an MIT license without actually supplying the text, I don't know which version of MIT to use, or what the copyright line should be for that license (for example, is it "(c) 2016 Jane Doe" or is it "(c) 2012-2014 John Smith"?)

This can't be done programmatically...it's not sufficient to search inside an artifact for a LICENSE file, since some artifacts don't have a LICENSE file, or have multiple files (for example, both LICENSE.MIT and LICENSE.LGPL).  Sometimes, the license text is embedded in another file (like COPYING or COPYRIGHT or README), or the license text is indicated by a URL to a website that requires navigation (or that may have moved from sourceforge to github, requiring human effort to track down its new home), or the author has neglected to indicate a license, requiring effort to contact them.

Since (non-trivial) human effort is involved in tracking down the license text for each open-source third-party dependency, once we've expended that effort, we'd like guidance as to the best place to store that information in Artifactory so we can later extract that text programmatically when building our TPLP.
column249:
17/Jan/16 8:28 AM;drorb;You can store the license text as a [property|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Properties] of the relevant artifact.
This way you can make sure that this information is not lost during promotions/copies/moves etc.
In addition this approach has other benefits like the ability to perform [searches|https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+Query+Language] based on properties.

column1: AQL to search builds by issue
column45:
The integration between build info, artifactory jenkins plugin, and Jenkins JIRA plugin allows artifactory to identify what build or snapshot is associated with a specific JIRA.  However, to search artifactory to determine what build is associated with a JIRA is currently quite difficult, involving pulling all of a specific build and then parsing the JSON to search it.  We could add a build.issues domain to AQL to make it possible to do this.

Objective Use Case:  Search for the snapshot of a WAR file in which a specific JIRA has been resolved, by searching for the build where it was resolved and seeing what snapshot version it outputted.

column1: Support mirroring a remote repository
column45:
Similar to pull replication, when proxying an external repository, which is not an Artifactory repository, user will be able to mirror a complete repository.

Mirroring should be based on the external repository index (no site scrapping should be done).
Synchronizing the external repository content with Artifactory can be manual/scheduled.
For Scheduled synchronization the user should be able to:
 * Schedule the task using a cron expression
 * Set the rate/concurrency of download requests
Only one synch process can run at a time per repository.

Mirroring configuration should consider the repository include / exclude patterns.

This should also support configuration of receiving notification, in UI and REST when trying to download a artifact which was deleted of remote repository, or removing it completely.

column1: add the option to see which local/cache repositories contain a specific artifact when browsing the virtual repository containing it

column1: Support responding 404 instead of 403 for non-existing artifacts
column45:

If there's at least one accessible repository, Artifactory should return a 404 instead. Only if there's not at least one accessible repository, Artifactory should return 403.

Make this configurable, so the current behaviour would still be the default.

column1: Smart Remote Repository does not sync any changes that are made in the source repository unless you download the artifacts again.
column45:
Smart Remote Repository does not sync any changes that are made in the source repository unless you download the artifacts again.

Currently the Smart Remote Repository only updates the changes in the Properties of the cached artifacts when they are downloaded again. The sync for Properties and file content of the cached artifacts in the Smart Remote repo should not just happen with a download request but also on every access to the metadata or Properties of the cached artifacts.
column249:
23/Nov/15 1:31 PM;kfoersch;Our ide of how "smart remote repo" should work is the following:
- on every access (not just download) to an artifact of a remote repository
   * verify if the cached binary is changed on the source server (by checksum compare)
   * verify if artifact's properties have been updated in the source server (introduction of a property checksum might help here as well)
   * if either the binary or the properties changed, trigger a synchronization
In any case the cache validity check (Retrieval Cache Period) shall be kept.
Since the requested/additional checks are maybe to costly, we suggest to make also this feature configurable as part of the smart remote repo configuration.
Maybe it also makes sense, to distinguish between a necessary sync of the binary and it's properties. Means to only sync the part necessary for the current request.
