column1: Filtered permissions
column45:
One of our challenges right now is that we need to be able to dynamically build per-customer things in artifactory.

I've already opened a ticket for our use case around encrypted passwords and removing the "encrypted password required" for getEncryptedPassword().

Another thing that would be handy is if the concept of filtered resources could be applied to permissions.

- I programatically create a new artifactory user 
- I create a new set of permissions for that user alone which give them access to a subpath in a specific repo (probably generic in this case)

Said repo will have a lot of folders in it named after each customer/end-user. Instead of having to create per-user permissions, I would love to get able to create a SINGLE permission target:

**/{getCurrentUser()}/*

and have it automatically applied/filtered. For now I can create per-user permission groups if need be but it'll quickly get hard to navigate/out of hand.

column1: Remote Docker Registry that points to a Artifactory Docker V2 should not enforce reverse proxy URL
column45: When the remote docker registry is an Artifactory server, the actual Artifactory repository URL should be used, and the Smart Remote Repo feature activated.

column1: Add ability to filter logs by repository type
column45: Some repositories, such as Docker repositories create many requests per command, this can make looking for other issues in logs difficult. A user is requesting that we allow log filtering per repository type.

column1: A status info / admin page for the currently running backups and syncs.
column45:
It's a very valuable feature to have a status page or REST, where we can see if there are currently active backups, restores and repository syncs.

Additionally there isn't currently a way to stop them even if you know they are active.

Currently we log in to the server, grep in the logs.. and if we need to stop a backup or sync we have to manually change the filesystem permissions recursively so that the backup fails. Stopping the Artifactory isn't an option for a production system.

Previously we were able to stop a scheduled backup by changing it's schedule in the configuration, but this is no longer working.

It's really awkward to not have this info in the UI - and having to read the logs at least for the status. 

Even if it's not part of the UI, a REST calls would also do the job so this is another option that will be eventually easier to implement.

column1: Support rsync to access public repositories
column45:
I'm currently leveraging artifactory pro for part of one of our development project where I just store arbitrary binaries in it (third party sources/etc.) I can currently easily reference those just via the URL path for the browse artifacts screen - but would really like to be able to retrieve/sync them (as part of the build environment scripts) using rsync.

Implementing the ability to retrieve an artifact using rsync would be very helpful.

A simple implementation of this could just be to have a mode where the filestore had a separate "link tree" that would match the appearance of the repository browse, but populated with hardlinks to the actual files. This would allow serving up that directory using any standard file service mechanism like rsync/ftp/cifs/etc.

I have been told about the webdav approach, and I believe that if I loopback mount that on the artifactory server itself - it would probably be sufficient to implement this - but seems like this would be good functionality to have within artifactory itself.
column249:
24/Nov/15 9:17 AM;ssbarnea;I do support this feature but my impression is that jFrog is trying to avoid anything related to exporting the repository on SMB or NFS.

The lack of this feature is the number one reason for preventing Artifactory from replacing old methods of keeping artifacts on file shares.

If this would be implemented it would allow people to start loading artifacts into Artifactory without losing their old way of consuming them (assuming that the file shares are read-only most of the time).

There are also some other use case where the export on a NFS/SMB file share is mandatory: like PXE boot, installation kits and ISO images but all these have to be on a file share in order to be able to use them, nobody is able to *run* things from HTTP and downloading them is killing the network.

Who wants to download a 6GB DVD image of Visual Studio in order to install a 30MB missing requirement? If these are on network mounts you do not have to copy them in order to run them.
column250: 24/Nov/15 9:22 AM;ssbarnea;If Artifactory would be able to create hardlinks/symlinks trees that do match the exports of the repositories, it would be very easy for sysadmin to export them as read-only file-shares, ones that would not even have to be synced as they will always remain synced.

column1: Support for IntellJ IDEA Enterprise Plugin Repository
column45:
My organization is looking at adopting IntelliJ IDEA as an IDE.

It would be great if Artifactory can support an IntelliJ Plugin Repository -- similar to Eclipse/P2?

http://blog.jetbrains.com/idea/2008/03/enterprise-plugin-repository/
column249:
26/Mar/20 10:57 PM;mick.killianey;This would still be super-helpful...+1 to this feature request.  If JFrog doesn't have the bandwidth to implement/maintain, could someone provide guidance as to whether or not it would be reasonable to implement this via a user plugin, as per [https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/JFROG/User+Plugins] ? 

If so, perhaps JetBrains or someone in the open-source community would be willing to contribute?  And if not, would JFrog be willing to make the necessary APIs available so that it *could* be provided by a user plugin?  If so, this could be useful for hosting other IDE extension repos (for example, a Visual Studio marketplace for extensions).

column1: Support easy_install for PyPi

column1: Make use of NuGet Friendly License Name
column45:
When pulling NuGet packages from a remote source, you could pass through the Friendly License Name, or fill that with the license information from Artifactory.

It would also be nice if there was an easier way to pre-fill the license information without having to use the Scan button.

column1: Add all new repositories to permission target
column45: In a Permission target, using “All remote” or “All local” is the only way to automatically add new repositories to the target. There should be an option to “Add all new repositories to permission target” in the case that specific repositories need to be excluded but new ones should be included by default. Currently there seems to be no way to do this with any combination of permission targets.

column1: REST API call to import LDAP groups
column45:
I'm working on creating an integrated CI environment and in that I've included an administration interface to create projects and repositories.

This entails having an LDAP server for external group and user management.
What I do in LDAP is to first setup a set of groups for the project, a global group shared between all services provided (not just Artifactory) and then these group are to be assigned to the projects repositories.

Currently everything can be done automatically in Artifactory (create repo, create permission and assign repo/group to the permission) except the import of the LDAP group... That has to be done manually.

It would be a great and useful feature if I could via REST import a specific group, by providing the full DN for it.
column249:
21/Sep/15 9:44 AM;felested;I managed to actually do this. Although it is not documented at all.

What I did was:
* List an imported group using REST API
* Change properties returned to the new group to import
* "Create" that group as a local group.

After those steps, it recognized the group as an imported group.
This issue can be "solved" by updating the API documentation to let users know that this is possible to do this way.
column250:
25/Aug/16 10:48 AM;Maras;@felested Please provide more details how your solution is working. We are interested in the same issue and want to implement
Regards
column251: 25/Aug/16 1:35 PM;felested;@maras Basically the entire request looks like the ones in the documentation - but the realm is changed to reflect that the group is a LDAP group. You can get what the realm parameter should look like by listing a group via the REST API which has been imported from LDAP.

column1: Cope with HTTP HEAD requests failing against remote repositories
column45: When trying to configure a remote repository against https://conda.binstar.org/cgat/, attempts to fetch from the remote site fail.  This is because an HTTP HEAD request fails with an HTTP 403 Forbidden.  I understand why artifactory tries to use the HEAD, but either allowing a manual override to use GET (and accepting the slowdown in response) or automatically falling back to GET would be better than a fail I think

column1: Checksum download
column45:
Add the ability to skip download if the file is already exists locally.

Usage:
It should be the same as Checksum upload.
X-Checksum-[Deploy|Resolve]: true
X-Checksum-Sha1: sha1Value

The user will provide the sha1 value of its existing artifact.
If the requested artifact sha1 equals to the provided sha1, than 204 (No Content) will be returned, otherwise, the artifact will be streamed with 200 at the end.

column1: Add site specific CSS and JS

Even just being able to supply a URL to an external stylesheet would be helpful.

column1: Feature to disable addons
column45: It would be nice to selectively disable addons you don't use or don't want your users to access. Specifically, we would like to disable the Bintray-addon, so we don't offer our users to upload private artifacts to Bintray.

column1: Add an option to use query params to build the relevant path to deploy according to the required tokens for the relevant repo layout
column45:
User will be able to add the relevant tokens via query params when uploading a file via REST API so that the layout will be constructed accordingly.
e.g. 
Configure a repo with general package type and some layout
An example of the layout can be (with only mandatory fields but can combine any number of additional custom tokens):
[orgPath]/[module]/[baseRev]/[customeToken1].[ext]

User should be to construct the layout using query params when uploading an item to that repository, and those tokens should be indexed as properties for that file.
e.g.:
curl -i -u<USERNAME>:<API_KEY> -T <PATH_TO_FILE> "http://localhost:8080/artifactory/my-local-generic;orgPath=org.jfrog;module=multi1;baseRev=1.0;customeToken1=filename;ext=txt"

column1: Download artifacts under each version
column45:
There should be an option in Web client to download the artifacts stored in each version. 

This is required because if there are multiple artifacts in each version and if it is required to download using GUI then it  has to be done by downloading each artifact inside it
column249: 18/Jan/16 3:51 PM;HughG;Is this effectively fixed by the new feature in 4.1 which allows you to download a whole folder hierarchy in the web UI?

column1: Show current progress or transfer messages for the copy item REST API
column45: Show current progress or transfer rate for the copy item REST API. Currently when we copy repository content using the copy item REST API, we only show the completion successful message after the task is completed.

column1: Account creation time
column45: Similar to the lastLoggedIn field, we request that you also log an account's creation time. We use both the creation time and last access time in our monthly reports to project growth.

column1: Allow readonly access to the metadata of a repository to non admin users
column45:
We are building tools for automating Artifactory tasks. In our code we have a need for accessing repository metadata by non admin users. Essentially within the script we would like to know if the user is interacting with a release repo or a snapshot repo and based on this info we would like to do different things. This script will be run by developers with no admin and no manage permissions.

Currently any access to repository metadata is only available to users with admin level permissions. This forces us to use workarounds which is unnecessary. Instead it should be possible for authenticated users without admin and manage permissions to be able to access repository metadata in READONLY form.

we (company with ~1500 employees and yearly over 2000 projects for different customers) like to request a feature to be able to set the allowed/approved licenses each repository.

Currently you're only able to approve globally allowed Licences. As we manage different projects for different customers there are different contracts containing different requirements on licenses. So the current approach does not match our companies needs. :)

Although we more or less like to be able to cluster repos and permissions "project"-like this feature request asks for a tradeoff having licence management on repository-side. (I think about the project-thingy we have to talk about)

column1: Yum remote repository index not updated correctly
column45:
When downloading Yum packages, the primary.xml.gz is sometimes not updated when other files in repodata are, which causes inconsistent database information.

Artifactory should consider all the repodata files as a block. It cannot have different files from different times because they won't match. Artifactory should update ALL the files, or NONE of the files, never one and not the other.
column249: 15/May/15 9:22 PM;freds;The goal is that all files under repodata folder are refreshing their "dirty" state based on the primary file state.
column250: 18/May/15 6:49 PM;gmartinez;Perhaps an additional safety mechanism could be to ensure that the checksum in repomd.xml matches the actual checksum for primary.xml.gz? In addition to updating them all as a group.
column251:
25/Sep/15 2:06 PM;krische;I've been seeing this issue as well on 4.1.2. When the YUM repo I'm caching gets updated on the remote server, I find I have to zap and delete the repodata folder in Artifactory. I've tried setting {{Retrieval Cache Period}} and {{Missed Retrieval Cache Period}} to 0, but that doesn't make a difference.

Are there plans to fix this bug anytime soon?
column252: 18/May/16 6:52 AM;dsmorse;I'm not sure if the problem I'm seeing is the same as this or if I should open up another issue.. but if artifacts are cached from the remote yum repo and subsequently removed from the remote, they exist in my cache, but because the cache's repodata is not re-created correctly those cached versions do not appear in the available versions.  It seems to me the repodata files need to be recreated at together and they should represent the union of the remote and cache repos.  Currently to work around this I have to move rpm's from the cache repo to a local yum repo, where artifactory does create the repodata correctly.
column253:
09/Dec/16 3:06 PM;phemmer;Also in a very similar situation to David. Upstream committed a sin and replaced a package, so the checksum changed. So artifactory is serving up the cached package which doesn't match the metadata.

To me it seems like we essentially need a virtual repo of the artifactory remote cache, and the remote repo. Unfortunately artifactory doesn't let you use cache repos in a virtual repo.
column254:
16/May/17 7:45 PM;cdenneen;Running 4.16.1 and have a virtual yum repo 'epel' setup with remote yum repo 'epel-remote'.
EPEL has a tendency because of storage to delete old versions of packages when new packages get deployed.
So for example:
nodejs-6.10.1-2 is no longer available because nodejs-6.10.2-1 is now available.
Therefore the package metadata has been updated as well.
Our Artifactory however has the nodejs-6.9.1-4, 6.10.1-2, 6.10.2-1 packages but because these aren't available in a repomd.xml they are no longer searchable through yum client pointing at Artifactory. So I think it would be useful for virtual repositories to create their own repomd.xml based on everything it has cached as well as that's available. 

Has anyone found a different workaround for downloading a particular version of a package through Artifactory that has since been removed from the upstream repo? I guess the only other option I could propose is creating some sort of "epel-backup" local repo and if remote repositories could have option to move any packages that have been removed upstream, this would allow for a repomd.xml to be generated on the local repo and the package would become available. But this would need to be some sort of automatic process.

column1: Add Visual Studio private gallery repositories (for hosting VS extensions)
column45:
It'd be nice to have an ability to host Visual Studio extensions in Artifcatory. So Artifcatory would be able to create repositories for hosting VS extensions - private VS galleries. See https://inmetavsgallery.codeplex.com/ as an example of VS gallery servic implementation.

It'd nice addition to Nuget support.
column249: 20/May/15 12:12 PM;Shrike;Hi. I just wanna ask is there any chance that the feature to be implemented? Or any other ideas. thanks
column250:
28/Oct/15 12:32 PM;royz;[~Shrike] Hi, There is a way to implement a private VS gallery in Artifactory using a generic private repo.

You will need to:
1. Create a local generic repo and set the repository key, e.g. "vs-private-gallery".
2. Upload your gallery.xml to the repository root (make sure that you will set the path to each entry to the relative path under that repository).
3. Upload your vsix files to the repo under desired path (you can also upload the related icons and previews png files)
4. In your VisualStudio open Tools -> Options -> Environment -> Extensions and Update -> Add 
define a name for your gallery and set the URL to the XML file ex : http://<artifacotry url>/vs-private-gallery/gallery.xml and click on apply.
5. In your VS open Tools -> Extensions and Updates -> Select "Online", you will see the configured Artifactory gallery and the related extensions.

NOTE:
1. You will need to update the gallery.xml every time you want to upload a new extension.
Hope this helps.
2. Since VS doesn't support authenticated request you MUST enable anonymous access with the relevant permission on the relevant repository.
column251: 29/Oct/15 10:22 AM;Shrike;@royz Hi, thanks for the suggestion. It's an option for sure. But manually changing gallery.xml on each push is awkward and make it hard to automate publishing from CI builds.
column252:
04/May/17 10:46 AM;patrick.finnegan;I was actually going to request the same feature as my team has already tried the suggested solution but it is too manual, it would be a really nice addition to have in Artifactory.
At the moment it is too manual for us to implement on a large scale, yes it can be easily done as a one time job but the only use case for this would be say, hosting legacy extensions.

Using this for extensions that continually receive approved version updates could basically be ruled out as an option due to having to update gallery .xml and each extensions attributes. (and CI builds as Sergei mentioned.)

*This is my first post so I thought I would register my companies interest in the feature should JFrog consider adding support for this. _(I didn't want to open a duplicate request to generate interest, I presume this is the best option)_
As for auth, that is completely out of JFrog's hands here though I may lodge a feature request with MS for this if JFrog hasn't already.

Hi,

We do releases every week and create a local repository for a new release scheduled for next week.
We want to blacked out the obsolete released repositories which is 2 weeks old.

Is there a REST API exposed, to automate this blacked out process?

Please let us know.

Thanks,
-Saif

column1: NPM: ability to publish to virtual repo
column45:
We miss the ability to be able to specify one registry URL for both publishing and consuming NPM packages. As it is this forces us to either always use the --registry option when publishing, or to specify a packageConfig in our package.json files, which is not really very flexible/accurate considering we actually have three local repositories we could publish to.

This is a feature request to implement a "default publishing" repository for virtual repositories, so that for instance if I configure NPM in my .npmrc file to use the "staging" virtual repository, I can also run "npm publish" without any additional arguments and the Artifactory will know to publish to staging-local. This would make our jobs as developers easier and would be more in-line with what the NPM client is expecting. Aside from that the "--registry" option is not really well-documented on the NPM website and the NPM developers don't seem very interested in supporting the Artifactory-style workflow into the future  ... (see this discussion when I posted a pull request for better "npm publish" documentation: https://github.com/npm/npm/pull/8212 

I'm excited to hear feedback as to whether this feature might be feasible! :)
Otherwise we're pretty happy with the Artifactory support for NPM thus far.

column1: artifactory-client-java: support REST API call Get User Encrypted Password
column45:
https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-GetUserEncryptedPassword

Motivation: I would like to automate maven settings.xml configuration for developer machines. Developers should be able to start the tool, provide their username and password, hit a button, and watch the tool configure everything.

column1: Artifactory should have the ability to trim spaces in a package filename(if present) before storing it in the repository
column45:
Consider a package with a filename "MyPackage 1.0.3.nupkg", Artifactory interprets the version number as " 1.0.3" instead of "1.0.3". When this package is deployed to the local repository you will see that the filename has a space.

The customer is asking that Artifactory should have the ability to trim the spaces in the package filename before it is stored in a repository.

column1: Create "frozen" repository mirror
column45:
I would like to be able to create a remote repository, but the behavior differs as follows:

1)  When the repository is created, the entire repository (or a subset) is synced.  The sync can happen in a throttled manner, but should be complete.

2)  The repository can be set to not sync to the remote repository unless requested.

3)  The remote repository can be another artifactory repository, but doesn't have to be.

I have yum in mind as a use case, but it could be any kind of binary repository.

column1: Support validation to Debian packages
column45: To add the support validation on the control file before indexing the file inside Artifactory

column1: Java jar dependency tree in WebUI
column45:
Artifactory should provide a Dependency Tree of a jar stored within the WebUI? 
Similar to: http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-dependency-plugin/dependencies.html#Dependency_Tree 

Today , Artifactory gives a dependency list for a jar. But it is unclear what dependencies from the parent jar or if the dependency is pulled in from another source.

column1: Custom repository Views for Webpage UI
column45:
We have A LOT of repos. But certain users only care about some of them. When they navigate to the WebUI it is hard for users to find the repos they care about without scrolling through all the repos. 

It would be great to give WebUI logged in users a customized view of repos they only care about. And this is fully controllable from by the logged in user.

column1: docker should keep track of layer changes
column45:
Each docker layer contains the files that have changed since the previous layer.  It would be nice to keep a list of added/changed/deleted files for each layer so you could search which commit changed what file.  For instance:

1) joe penguin pushes base centos version
2) jay frog pushes centos + /usr/bin/hello

The list for 2 would contain the new /usr/bin/hello file.  Even better would be which build made it assuming we're doing this with a jenkins job.

column1: control the number of "Integration" versions (Snapshots) in the Debian repository
column45: I want to be able to control the number of snapshots in a Debian repository

column1: Docker private registry mirroring
column45: Similar to RTFACT-7186 except for private repositories, It'd be nice to have our private repositories replicated / mirrored across multiple artifactory instances.

column1: Docker Hub mirroring (public)
column45:
I'd like a feature to provide the same type of public "Docker Hub" mirroring that the default docker registry provides:

https://github.com/docker/docker-registry#mirroring-options

More information about their mirroring can be obtained from these official docker, inc slides: http://www.slideshare.net/Docker/https-dldropboxusercontentcomu20637798docker-meetup-freiburg
column249: 09/Sep/20 8:43 AM;tarnschaf;This would be a great feature since Docker Hub announced to introduce rate limiting.

23/Mar/15 8:12 PM;jacek.hrominski;Customization must be done in: 
org.artifactory.webapp.wicket.page.browse.treebrowser.tabs.stats.StatsTabPanel

column1: Add regex filter to repository import
column45: Our process for recovery of individual files is to prune a backup and import it, but this is laborious. We should have an include/exclude for repository backups so specific files can be recovered from an existing backup using only our UI.

column1: The ability to deploy a Debian package with a "priority" property
column45: The ability to deploy a Debian package with a "priority" property so when Artifactory calculates the indexing (and generates the Packages.gz file) of the Debian package it will set the "priority" in the Packages.gz file according to the property that was delivered in deployment by the user and not necessarily according to the "priority" that was defined in the "control" file.

column1: Allow automatic deletion of SNAPSHOTS upon promotion
column45: When a release version of an artifact is deployed, the corresponding SNAPSHOT versions should be deleted so that consumers of this artifacts are not able anymore to use it, and must upgrade to the release version.

column1: Add the ability to list the remote repository non-cached content
column45:
When using the simple browsing and list browsing of a remote repository content, Artifactory display the cached and non-cached content (as long as the remote server allow remote listing)
Currently, is is not possible to list the remote repository content with a user plugin. 
Artifactory should have an api call to allow listing the remote repository content.

column1: Provide REST Resource for License Control CSV Export
column45:
Currently the CSV export that is available for License control page in Build browser is not available from REST API.

Utilising the current REST API support has an performance issue as I will need to:
1. Hit Build info API and get the list of dependencies from there
2. Use Checksum Search API for each of the dependencies
3. Search Item with item API to get each of the artifactory.licenses property field

The license details such as Long name, URL, and Notes are also not available as a REST resource hence it can't be automated further (unless we hit the server and grab the license xml at $ARTIFACTORY_HOME/backup/backup-daily/current/licenses/licenses.xml which is pretty cumbersome.

column1: Generate sqlite databases for use with yum
column45:
Generate sqlite databses is now a part of the default behavior of create repo
see --database: http://linux.die.net/man/8/createrepo

05/Jan/15 5:31 PM;bobbym;This has been default behavior for 5+ years.  
Once your repositories get big enough this becomes a serious bottleneck.

column1: Add support to audit and manage long running tasks in Artifacotry
column45:
Artifactory will add UI and REST support to view/ get all running tasks.
Feature should include
- Indication of when task started
- Elapsed time since started
- Ability to stop/ restart task
- Get notification if a task fails/ stops unexpectedly

column1: Add an afterCreate method that will work after the file uploaded to Artifactory
column45: the afterCreate that under Storage works in the same transaction with uploading the artifact. We should have another method that will work as the file finished uploading.

column1: Grunt Artifactory Plugin
column45: It would be great to have a Grunt Artifactory Plugin in the same way you have ones for Maven, Gradle and MSBuild to automatically produce and deploy Artifactory build-info for JS builds

column1: Add 'getAllUsers' method to the 'Security' class in the Public API
column45: When writing a user plugin, in order to perform a change in all of the existing Artifactory users, it is required to have a method that return the entire users (list of User objects).

column1: REST API: Support property based resolution for gavc search
column45:
For our continuous integration / testing environment I need to be able to search and download artifacts based on ivy/maven coordinates and a set of custom properties that we set on each artifact that is deployed.

Currently there is no rest api that supports this in 1 go, so my best shot is to use the gavc search in combination with manually filtering the result based on their properties.

1 rest api call that supports a generic search using coordinates, properties and other searchable items would be a very useful addition.

column1: REST API: Support gavc-like search for ivy coordinates
column45:
For ivy repositories a coordinate based rest search would be very useful. This can be similar to the gavc search api, except that it should not be limited to group (organization), artifact (module), version (revision), ... but also support  status, branch, etc. ...

http://ant.apache.org/ivy/history/2.0.0/use/info.html

Even better would be a generic gavc-like search api that supports any type of repository.

column1: Support multiple dashboard admin users in Artifactory Online
column45: Currently only the user that registered for the Artifactory online server is the dashboard admin, and there is no option to create another dashboard admin user

column45: Simplify MSSQL DB creation and filegroups for blobs

column1: Remote repository won't appear in the repository browser after disabling cache
column45:
If the "Do not store artifacts locally" option on a remote repository is checked you will not be able to browse in the repository, in the UI it appears in the Simple browser and not in the Tree browser

If  "Do not store artifacts locally" option is checked , the option to browse the repository with the simple browser is lost, we need to fix this so the customer will still be able to browse the remote repository in the simple browser even if "Do not store artifacts locally" is checked

Hey.

For example in Artifctory already exist support of npm. So we can use only Artifactory.
I have issue to integrate Artifactory instead of satis. That means - we should have possibility to generage packages.json on server side and recursively download dependency as satis (include git dependency). Also Artifactory should have interfaces to work with composer.

 same as what you can do with nexus

I'm about to switch back to nexus because of that

column250:
21/Nov/14 3:26 PM;noa;I believe this can be arranged by granting "deploy" rights to the anonymous user for remote repositories. 
Logged in as user admin user:
* click the admin tab in the top navigation
* click Permissions under the Security header in the navigation menu to the left
* hover over the "Any remote" permission target and click the "Edit" button that appears
* Select the Users tab and make sure that the user "Anonymous" has the Deploy checkbox ticked.

2) Create new virtual repository, include repos as needed.

I can access the virtual repository anonymously in browser and download anonymously using Maven. 

Seeing as this issue is rather old, maybe it's time to check if it's still an issue at all?

If at least one of the included repositories does not allow anonymous access, anonymous access will be prohibited for the whole virtual repository. Or is there a way to allow partly anonymous access on a single virtual repository?

column1: Add SLES to the supported platforms list
column45: Currently, only RedHat is supported Linux platform (see http://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Installing+on+Linux+Solaris+or+Mac+OS#InstallingonLinuxSolarisorMacOS-RPMInstallation). Can you please add SuSE Linux Enterprise Server (SLES) to the list of supported platforms, including for rpm package installation?

column1: Enable per repository storage quotas
column45:
We run a centralized Artifactory instance for multiple teams in our company and it would be nice to have a way of enforcing storage quotas per repository or groups of repositories. Artifactory would be configured to send out email alerts to specific users when they came close to exceeding their storage limits for their repository. Once the limit was exceeded, Artifactory should be able to either allow additional uploads to occur (non-enforced quotas with just warnings) or prevent any additional uploads from occurring (enforced quotas).

A similar request can be found on the jfrog forums: http://forums.jfrog.org/Storage-Quotas-per-Repository-td7579906.html
column249:
28/Jan/15 8:15 PM;asylvia;This sounds like a really good feature to add.

I have just encountered this here at EMC and I have the same use case:  We would like to control quota by repository because we will have multiple customers using the same servers and we would like to not have them affect each other by breaching overall file system thresholds.

-Aaron
column250: 08/Dec/17 12:55 PM;sbreitbach;Just like to give my +1 so it won't get forgotten ;)
column251: 15/Dec/17 12:24 PM;martinm;Interesting as well for us. We are seeing that teams just push push and push and right now there is not much we can do apart from defining strict retention policies.
column252: 05/Sep/18 6:40 AM;gmichaud;+1
column253: 16/Mar/19 6:55 PM;mikek753;any hope to get this feature?
column254: 12/Dec/19 8:36 AM;Yann Mornet;This feature has also been requested by our customer which is expecting to reach more than 10Tb of data in his centralized artifactory instance.
column255: 01/Apr/20 2:41 AM;kleinen;My company's instance is also having the same.  As an enterprise customer, it would be nice to have these controls.

column1: Change Permission Management
column45:
In Our Company we host one Central Artifactory for all Projects. As we are a full service IT Company and no it-product company all projects are way different with different people...
Each Project we have in our company get’s it’s own set of LOCAL repositories (usually a release repo, one snapshot repo and one 3rd-partylibs-repo for libs that are not on remot erepos.)
These Repos get own permission targets where only special  directory-groups get permission to. 

Each Project gets one or two virtual repositories containing the local repositories and the set of remote/cache repositories they need for successful builds :)

Sadly the current Permission Management does not fit to this scenario because ( "+" means: good behaviour; "-" means: bad behaviour):
+ Users can only download from repositories they have permission to
+ Users can only deploy to repositories they have permission to
+ users only see local repositories they have permission to
+ users can only see remote/cache repos they have permission to
- Users see ALL Virtual Repositories by name although they have no permission to certain local repositories that are boudn to the virtual one
- user see ALL Builds in the Builds-Browser if they have at least one "deployer"-permission on one local/remote repository (that's worst)
- adminsitrator must pay good attention by setting up permission target
- adding a LDAP-Group into Artifactory is harmful (import-button etc...)

I'd like to see a permission management system that covers our usage scenario:
permisions for: Build Browser-View-parts (e.G. also "only license tab for certain users", permissions for virtual repos (see or not to see), NO IMPORTING of LDAP-Groups (just search them), ...

If you like I can go more in detail but at first I like to hear your opinion if this is a case that may be implemented in future versions or what plans you have.

Thanks,
for us it's more ore less important: As if we want to open a certain instance for customer-access detailed permissions is needed.

column1: Be able to set Bintray version attributes via Artifactory properties
Support metadata only tycho eclipse repository
column45: Adding support for metadata only tycho eclipse repository
column249: 26/Sep/14 2:34 PM;jgeorgeson;Thanks for filing this Shay. To fill in a little extra background on this, the desired use case is to deploy all the eclipse-* maven project artifacts from a Tycho build to an M2 repo with a standard 'mvn deploy'. The eclipse-repository project would be configured to produce a metadata-only archive, and Artifactory would serve a P2 repo from that archive, serving the artifact path requests from the corresponding M2 artifact. This would allow non-OSGi project to build against the artifacts with standard maven without duplicating storage.
column250: 16/Feb/15 2:46 PM;jgeorgeson;I found in Sonatype Nexus OSS there is the 'P2 Metadata Generator' capacity that allows doing a standard 'mvn deploy' of eclipse-feature and eclipse-plugin projects, and the server will publish the jar files to a P2 repo within the M2 repo's storage. It doesn't support all the P2 features we need at the moment though.

column1: Hiding sensitive information from anonymous users (when anonymous access is allowed)
column45:
Hiding sensitive information from anonymous users(when anonymous access is allowed):

 1) Build information 
 2) Available addons
 3) Number of artifacts served by Artifactory

Also, if the “anonymous” user has READ access to a given repo, then build information for artifacts stored in this repo should be visible.

Right now the user can see all build information when accessing anonymously, even if the anonymous user has no permissions for any of the repos.
If the user anonymous will have read permission on a repository he should be able to retrieve data from there and read file properties/build info.
column249:
19/Sep/14 5:32 PM;jmcapps;One possible difficulty to this feature may be build-info is not always associated with a repository, as a build may be publishing build-info but only using dependencies.
In this case, the build-info json (produced by a TeamCity plugin) simply does not include a "modules" top-level property.

So it may be possible to require authentication for build-info (probably jFrog would need to keep this anonymous access option for other customers), but not sure how you would check whether the build-info was associated with a repository and the user requesting access in the scenario of someone publishing build-info, but not publishing artifacts.

Perhaps we could handle this with a plugin that checks if build.json is  missing a modules and decide what we want to do.

jFrog, how might you suggest a plugin would work to filter a build-info request?  Would we be able to force authentication from a plugin using PAPI?

column1: Leiningen Client Settings
column45:
Artifactory currently has a "client settings" generator for Ivy, Gradle, and Maven. It would be fantastic if Artifactory could also generate "client settings" for Leiningen. A Leiningen project.clj contains information that is similar to Maven. Namely there are places to specify mirrors,  release repos, and snapshot repos.

Documented here is an example of specifying release and snapshot repos for deployment: https://github.com/technomancy/leiningen/blob/master/doc/DEPLOY.md#deploying-to-maven-central

Documented here is an example of specifying mirrors:
https://github.com/technomancy/leiningen/blob/master/sample.project.clj#L110

column1: Allow an option for Artifactory to send an email when replication fails
column45: When a backup fails we can receive an email. I propose that a similar option be given on the replication tab for when a replication job fails.

column1: It is difficult to determine which jobs are queued to run, currently running, or ran
column45:
It would be beneficial to have a tab under the Admin UI which shows which jobs (backup, indexing, plugins, etc...) are currently queued up, are currently running, or have finished running (with their success or failure info).

Right now all we have is the log file, which is very noisy, and some jobs do not show when they are complete (just just fall off).

column1: Zip up email attachments
column45:
When sending out backup failure notification emails it would be very helpful to include logs as zipped attachments and not bare text in the body of the email.

Currently we have a problem where the log files are huge, and its causing loading issues with outlook.

column1: Expose layout information in API
column45:
Layout information should be available in repository configuration JSON and groovy bindings, eg as

layoutName
layoutArtifacts
layoutDescriptors

That would allow for eg simultaneous/atomic operations on artifacts and their descriptors (deploy, move, delete, etc).

It might be practical to provide layout information for non-JCR repositories, eg by reserving names "p2", "rpm", "gem", "npm" etc.

column1: Enable to limit artifacts search to virtual repository
column45:
It would be nice to have an option to set a virtual repository as repo parameter in search via Rest API and Artifactory GUI.

We want to limit the search via REST API to virtual repository which contains a long list of allowed repositories and might be changed through the time. This condition refrains us from using explicit set of repos as parameter in the search.

column1: Expose list of all Property Sets and their Properties through the REST API
column45: As an Intel customer, for automation purposes I would like to be able to get the list of all Property Sets and their Properties from an Artifactory instance.
column249:
17/Aug/14 3:12 PM;royz;Hi Wojciech,

I would like to suggest a workaround for your request.
The property sets are managed in Artifactory configuration xml, which is accessible via REST API (http://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-GeneralConfiguration), you can then parse the XML and CRUD property sets, and also manage which repos use those property sets.
Hope this helps your use case.

column1: Allow to set a size limit for remote repos
column45: When proxying remote repos such as repo1 or jcenter it'll help to be able to specify "Only host 4Gb of artifacts" with several eviction policies (least frequently used, last access time, etc). This will help to ensure no account limits (like 10Gb of data hosted) are violated. Otherwise, I end up cleaning remote repo caches manually from time to time.

column1: Have a UI part for the plugins
column45:
Hello,

Having a customizable UI (in a new tab for example) for plugins would be a great thing.

Thanks,
Regards,

Guillaume

column1: Add a specific base URL for tool access
column45:
In settings generation (Gradle, Maven, Ivy, Ruby), and in snippet help for distribution the UI context URL is used (current servlet context base URL).
Now, for tools the URL to access may be different (forced HTTP instead of HTTPS, going through load-balancer, ...).
Adding a new optional global "toolUrlBase" field in the configuration will provide a solution for this use case.

column1: Get feedback on whether deployed RPM's are available in YUM
column45:
We currently have this requirement as part of our build process:

->Build Code
->Deploy RPM's to Artifactory YUM repo:
->Install RPM's from Artifactory YUM repo on to a Test server.
->Start application and run the tests against installed application.

Artifactory does not have a way to give feedback to the CI server or a script to let it know that the newly deployed artifacts are now available to be installed via YUM. 

With createrepo in a plain non-Artifactory YUM repo, we deploy Artifacts to this repo, run createrepo in our build and are now certain that the artifacts are available in YUM, so that we can install them as the next step in the process. 

It would be great if Artifactory can provide this feedback.
column249:
19/Sep/14 1:43 PM;kleinen;Sounds like something cool to have integrated into Artifactory.  Maybe have the indexer attach a property to each file that is contained in the index.

We had a similiar problem.  We solved it by creating a very simple python script that slurped through the yum index (within the repodata folder) looking for the package and version we just deployed.
column250:
19/Dec/16 5:33 PM;dougm;We would also very much like something like this.  We have teams that push RPMs up, but then they have no idea when those packages will be available for the next tests in the pipeline.

Ideally, we'd have a REST endpoint that we could query that would return the last indexing time as well as the current state (is it indexing or not).  This way, they could trivially wait until this endpoint said that everything was okay.

column1: Bittorrent plugin
column45:
We place some large files inside our Artifactory. We do have a fast network. But to scale out the distribution of our files, it would be great if Artifactory could support the Seeding, Torrents and Tracker for certain files/repos we designate. 

This does deviate from the largely http style of delivery Artifactory does. But the benefits would be substantial.

There is even, ttorrent, an open-source, pure-Java implementation of the BitTorrent protocol :-) http://turn.github.io/ttorrent/
column249: 29/Jan/14 10:32 PM;tpowell-rms;Also please see: http://www.bittorrent.com/sync
column250:
02/Dec/15 6:19 PM;rkiefer@salesforce.com;Added a vote to this issue.

Use Case:
- highly parallel, fully automated CI system
- builds an asset and upload it to artifactory
- split N ways (up to 25 in our case), download large binary and test against it

We have several minutes of variability in the download of a ~200mb file across even a local network. If CI job executions line up poorly, the transfers can take in excess of 3 to 4 minutes a piece. 

This doesn't even touch our potential issues w/ deployment, which scale to an order of magnitude higher. We'll likely need to make a service that serves artifacts to a torrent based distribution system, but it'd be awesome to be able to cut that out.
column251: 03/Jun/16 6:08 PM;adb;We deploy hundreds of hosts via Artifactory and are finding it a bottleneck. We're going to throw up some cache servers for the time being, but using BitTorrent for distribution would mean we could scale out smoothly with the number of clients. It works very well at Facebook.
column252: 06/Apr/18 5:11 PM;shaun;I'd love to see this too.  It would be really helpful to be able to seed straight from artifactory.

column1: Support for Artifact Entry Search ("Class Search") by checksum
column45:
Artifactory indexes archive contents and allows searching them. This is currently implemented for the names of contained files as Artifact Entry Search / Class Search.

It would be great if Artifactory supported search for artifact entries by checksum, as extension to either Artifact Entry search or Checksum Search.

Examples:

{code}/api/search/archive?md5=27d3a160f8ad14f975bf4ba0290b04d4
/api/search/archive?md5=27d3a160f8ad14f975bf4ba0290b04d4&name=README.txt
/api/search/checksum?md5=27d3a160f8ad14f975bf4ba0290b04d4&inarchives=true{code}
column249: 18/Feb/15 6:28 PM;gilescope;It would be really useful to find a file with a specific hash for migration purposes. Especially if you've a bank-load of files to migrate to nuget. :-)

column1: Support for NuGet Symbol server
column45:
Microsoft Symbol Server is a Windows technology used to obtain symbol debugging information.

In order to debug an application with various Microsoft tools you must have symbol information. Symbol files provide a footprint of the functions that are contained in executable files and dynamic-link libraries (DLLs). Additionally, symbol files can present a roadmap of the function calls that lead to the point of failure. For example, you must have the symbols when you dump call stacks inside a debugger.

It's disappointing that this has been open for so long.

column268:
25/Feb/20 1:17 PM;JosephDHolman;I appreciate this is an older request, but has there been any movement on it at all? We're currently trying to use Artifactory to serve-up internal NuGet packages and I'm having to jump through a lot of hoops to get any kind of solution for debugging said packages set-up, so if Artifactory provided this feature it would be hugely useful. 

At the moment the only thing I can do in a 'pure' Artifactory world is to publish the legacy _.symbols.nupkg_ packages to a separate feed, configure that as the NuGet source when debugging, then point the Visual Studio debugger at the local NuGet cache to find the PDBs and source from the resolved symbols package. Proper support for _.symbols.nupkg_ and/or the newer _.snupkg_ formats in Artifactory would save a lot of faffing around.
column269:
12/Sep/20 2:28 AM;ryan_sealy;The lack of .snupkg and/or symbol support could be a deal breaker for a lot of potential customers.

The most common case for hosting an internal nuget feed is so you can distribute your own private libraries within a software development team and larger product code base. Having symbols is critical for debugging.

This ticket is 7 years old. Could we please get a commitment on this feature to a roadmap, or an explanation, justification, and/or workaround if you will not implement.

_Note: I do see that you do offer some sort of symbol support if using TFS and IIS. I see this as some recognition of the value of this request. However, much of your user base is likely not able to or not willing to use TFS. Ideally I just want to push a .snupkg to my local feed and have JFrog take care of the rest._
column270: 10/Dec/20 3:42 PM;evgenyka;It is on our list for roadmap, but right now we cannot share any timeline for that. It is being reviewed on quarterly basis, so we will update once we have firm confirmation of including this one in the delivery plan for 2021.

column1: Request audit log per artifact
column45: Request that any activity for an artifact be logged at the artifact level. Recommend having a tab in the artifact viewer (General, Properties, Builds, Governance, Stats and a new tab for Log). Also recommend date, time, user and action be included. We require a full audit trail of modifications/changes to binary bundles for our PCI certifications. The system log is functional but difficult to work with during an audit.

column1: Eclipse Marketplace Integration
column45:
I've been trying to use the P2 feature to provide access to eclipse plug-ins as many of our developers do not have internet download privileges.  Its seems that a P2 repo needs to be added for every plug-in that we use as there does not seem to be a single p2 repository that lists all available plug-ins in the way the eclipse marketplace catalogue does so maintenance of these is quite hard.

It would be great if artifactory could act as a proxy for the eclipse market place and that we could use the market place tool to search for and install the plug-ins but all access was via artifactory rather than directly over the net.
column249:
05/Jul/16 9:50 PM;aaronr;Clarification on this use-case. The Eclipse Marketplace is an aggregation of individual URLs which can be read by a REST API call:

https://wiki.eclipse.org/Marketplace/REST#Retrieving_a_listing_of_all_catalogs

This is generally used by the Eclipse Marketplace Client (or MPC) http://www.eclipse.org/mpc/ which is now a default part of the base Eclipse install.

The use case is for P2 virtual repositories to automatically pull catalogs from the MPC catalog and add them to the virtual repo as remote repositories. 

The workaround is to use a combination of the MPC REST API and our REST API: https://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-UpdateRepositoryConfiguration to update the virtual repository on a time interval.

column1: Add repository count to REST API
column45:
We try to track the count of every repository over time. We currently use Jenkins and some groovy scripts calling the REST API to download a list of every artifact in each repo, this is slow and intensive. We would like access to the count via the REST API.

The Web UI exposes a "count" for a repository, which seems to be calculated asynchronously. This is what we would be looking for to be exposed. Since we experience a delay clicking this button and given that it has nothing to do with configuration, I wouldn't expect it to be added to the current repository configuration API.

This would be for Netflix.

column1: non-admin View for included repositories in virtual repository
column45:
We have a lot of remote repositories and a ot of specific local repositories on one Artifactory.
If we have a new developing projekt we set up a bunch of project specific local repositories. 
Then we mostly set up one virtual repository for that project and include all projectspecific local repos as well of SOME remote repositories.

Now these Projects ask us what remote repos are included to make changes. Maybe they need one more or one less. They do not have the view Sysadmins have on Artiofactory at virtual repository configuration screen.

I ask you to implement a way/view to see what repositories are included for all people or maybe a special group of people.

At least you may implement it into the API first.

A more complex solution would be (the ideal one for us...)
- Add possibility to set "view" permission on virtual Repositories (if you do not have this view permission on that virtual repository you neither see it in any search view nor you can see the requested "inclusions" list above)
- in "Browse" ad a "virtual repo browse" where you can see who has that "view" permisssion as well what repos are included

:)

I'd like to see it in one of RTF 3.x :P

column1: Provide a way to change XML metadata in a safe way as an atomic change
column45:
The Artifactory (Pro) API allows reading (Single Metadata) and writing (Set Single Metadata, Delete Single Metadata) on XML metadata attached to artifacts. Modifications of these metadata are performed on the client, leading to the following cycle when modifying existing metadata:

* Download existing XML
* Modify XML locally
* Upload new XML

Unfortunately, there is no way to request that writing only succeed if the XML metadata has not been modified in the mean time, e.g. through a header providing the minimum age of the metadata, or the checksum of the expected old XML:

* "Delete/Set the XML metadata attached to this artifact only if the MD5/SHA-1 checksum of the current value is (still) [...]"
* "Delete/Set the XML metadata attached to this artifact only if it hasn't been modified since [....] (when I last downloaded it)"

Concurrent modifications to XML metadata can therefore lead to unexpected data loss.

column1: Standalone tool to check artifactory data integrity
column45:
It would be nice some sort of stand alone "check_integrity" program which will say if the index is out of date and needs fixing (and even give an idea of how out of date how much time it would take to re-index).

Then we can use this before bringing up artifactory in a crash case to see how long the recovery time will be and also to check the sanity of our backups on a secondary machine.

column1: Provide 'Used By' information for Ivy artifacts
column45:
Provide a 'Used By' list for Ivy artifacts, similar to the information mvnrepository shows for some of it's artifats.

See example:
http://mvnrepository.com/artifact/com.sun.xml.ws/jaxws-rt/2.1.7

Ideally, Artifactory could also track 'dependents' for Maven and others that declare dependencies at time of publishing.

column1: Add parameter to /api/storage to only list folders
column45: While writing some cleanup scripts, I routinely deal with folders only. The current solution is to a deep listing of everything with listFolders=1, then filtering on the client side, this works fine except that it's slow.  We have tens of thousands of artifacts, so the API call takes ~10 seconds. If /api/storage had a listFiles=0|1 feature, I could be downloading a few hundred folder entries instead of tens of thousands entries. Adding a listFiles parameter makes the API more consistent given that there's a listFolders=0|1 parameter.

column1: Support OR in Property Search
column45:
Property search API supports AND search via:

GET /api/search/prop?p1=v1&p1=v2[&repos=x[,y]]

Please provide a way to specify p1=v1 OR p1=v2.  Ideally, it should be possible to specify nested ANDs and ORs.
column249:
23/May/13 6:24 PM;daniel.beck;FWIW the API docs have contained the following for a long time:

http://wiki.jfrog.org/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-PropertySearch

Usage: GET /api/search/prop?[p1=v1,v2][&p2=v3][&repos=x[,y]]

/api/search/prop?p1=foo,bar has NEVER worked (at least in 2.6.x). It doesn't find artifacts that are p1=foo, p1=bar, or p1=foo;bar (for multivalue properties). It is just not possible to get the same results as in the property search UI via API.
column250:
19/Nov/20 12:07 PM;stefanga;I'm going to bump this ticket since this is a very irritating issue and I get a lot of questions from confused users that read the documentation.

This feature will probably never see the light so I would propose that you should fix the documentation. Update it so that users understand that trying to match multiple values for the same property is impossible, except for the "repos" parameter where it uses OR.

But I will say this. Having the ability to use the property search API to match properties mentioned multiple times as an OR query would probably be very useful.
Or maybe let the user decide if it should be an AND or OR by supporting "myprop=foo+OR+bar+AND+baz"

column1: RFE: Allow to add a HTML banner (e.g. for maintenance announcements or support requests)
column45:
Right now Artifactory only allows to add text to the footer (and only in plain text). In a company it would be very practical to:
* Add a banner occurring on all pages ideally even allowing HTML.
* JIRA, e.g., has this feature and we could use this to:
** announce maintenance periods at the "proper location" (maybe even with a link to JIRA ticket, we use JIRA for change management).
** add a link to e.g. a JIRA queue where developers may add a request for e.g. adding third-party artifacts or additional repositories.

I monkey-patched Artifactory by extracting the org/artifactory/webapp/wicket/page/home/HomePage.html from artifactory-web-application-2.6.5.jar to the jetty work-dir, however I then have to restart Artifactory so modifications are effective.

column1: RFE: Allow linkable searches in UI
column45:
Given I am on http://localhost:8081/artifactory/webapp/gavcsearch.html
When I enter a groupId (com.foo), an artifactId (bar), a version (1.7), a classifier (site) and chose one or more repositories
And click the "Search" Button
Then I expect the URL to reflect my search
And look like http://localhost:8081/artifactory/webapp/gavcsearch.html?repos=libs-release-local&g=com.foo&a=bar&r=1.7&c=site

When I enter http://localhost:8081/artifactory/webapp/gavcsearch.html?repos=libs-release-local&g=com.foo&a=bar&r=1.7&c=site
Then I expect the Web UI to pick up my values and include them in the inputs.
