column1: Artifactory license management by projects
column45:
Hi,

Actually, we would like to handle licenses by project, but it seems that Artifactory is not implemeting such a feature, here is a simple use case of what we need to achieve :

??"For example, an artifact with license L_1 used by 2 projects (P_1 & P_2) : P_1 can approve L_1 which means that after deployment, the project administrator won't receive it as unapproved license, but P_2, who didn't approve it, should still get notifications"??


For your information, for each project we are creating a virtual which contains 4 local repos in addition to a list of remote repos used or shared by all the projects virtual repos :

* PROJECT-release-local
* PROJECT-staging-local
* PROJECT-snapshot-local
* PROJECT-thirdParty-local : where third party libraries are uploaded

So, i'm wondering if this could be planned for the next release, thank you 


Regards
Mehdi

column1: Notification mechanism for incorrect path pattern
column45:
We need notification mechanism to notify admins if an artifact is published in a different pattern than the repositories layout pattern and module Id is not generated. I think this will be useful to make sure module Id is being generated for all artifacts. This should be available for a per repository basis so that we can enable it for single repository.

Regards,
Kranthi

column1: Allow to "lock" repository so that it doesn't accept any new deployments
column45: Specific repos may contain released artifacts updated once per product release and are never modified otherwise. It would be nice to "lock" these repositories so that nobody (even admin) could  ever deploy there anything unless they're "unlocked".
column249: 31/Jul/12 7:53 PM;evgenygoldin;This can be another checkbox in repo settings.

column1: add user permission to a virtual repository
column45:
In Artifactory 2.6.1 I can create virtual repositories. But I can't assign user permission.
I things that it would be interesting assign permission.

 On the other hand  it would be interesting that the user could view the virtual repository in the Repository Browser like a normal repository.

Change the repositories assigned to a virtual repository are performed transparently to the user.

column1: Notification/Alert Message on Artifactory Web UI
column45:
It would be nice to have live setable alert or notification messages on Artifactorys Web UI.
If you run a centralized Artifactory for a company, you as administrator can't always reach all participants via Email if you plan a maintenance

So if you could set up a notifcation on the gui you can reach more people.

Maybe this can be placed between the admin-tab and the search- bar or at the bottom where also the licence-notice pops up... if it reaches it's end, you know? :) like... the notification for jira ;)

A 2nd nice-to-have gimmick would be to add such a notice at the tomcat's http-x-header like "X-RTF-MAINTENANCE: $message" ;)

Thanks.

column1: Provide a REST API to access RPM metadata info
column45: Provide a way to access the information visible in the "RPM Info" tab via the REST API.
column249: 10/Dec/13 12:08 AM;ted.sheibar;Any progress on this, or is this a duplicate?
column250:
10/Dec/13 5:29 PM;ted.sheibar;With Bamboo, the workaround I have is as follows:
- At end of build, set an "rpm.version" property on the artifact right after it deploys to Artifactory [using the API|http://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-SetItemProperties] 
- On deploy, use the CI artifact sharing system to get the final artifact filename
- Use that filename to search Artifactory for its location using the API
- Get "rpm.version" property on that artifact [using the API|http://www.jfrog.com/confluence/display/RTF/Artifactory+REST+API#ArtifactoryRESTAPI-ItemProperties]

It would be much easier if JFrog could combine the artifact and property searches into one call, like {{http://my-artifactory-instance.com/artifactory/api/rpm-meta-search?file=myfile.rpm&properties=rpm.version,vcs.revision}}
column251: 11/Dec/13 7:36 AM;yluft;Will the related issue solve this one as well?
column252:
11/Dec/13 6:39 PM;ted.sheibar;Hi Yoav,

The related issue won't solve this, since we still need a way to access the RPM metadata through the REST API, even if those properties are added during the metadata calculation.

Thanks
column253: 12/Dec/13 7:35 AM;yluft;What metadata fields do you require? Or do you need the complete metadata (including dependencies and description)?
column254:
12/Dec/13 8:09 AM;ted.sheibar;Everything in the "RPM Info" tab, if it exists. This could be implemented by adding logic to handle something like "?expand=rpm.info", or just return it all by default if it exists.

Right now, I have to set artifact properties that duplicate information already available through the UI.

For example, to get an RPM's version, I must first set a "rpm.version" property on the artifact after deploying just so I can access it later through the api/search/prop endpoint. Without setting that, I can still get the version through the RPM Info tab, but not through the API.

This ticket is requesting the direct exposure of all of that information through the API.

Thanks
column255:
16/Dec/13 9:27 PM;ted.sheibar;Same issue with the "Builds" tab that is populated through the Generic Deploy Plugin in Bamboo.

If I want to find the artifact associated with a given build name from Bamboo, I have to set a 'build.name' property at build time in order for that to be queried later. However, I shouldn't have to do that, as the build name is already available through the Builds tab, as well as when viewing the build json.

This further illustrates what I mean. I have to duplicate information that's already available through the UI, when I should be able to access the information Artifactory already has through the API. Does this make sense?

Thanks again

column1: Add Repository Export option to Backups
column45:
Adding Repository Export (preferably incremental) to the cron driven Admin -> Services -> Backups menu would be helpful.  This would simplify, for example, writing a yum repository to disk to make it accessible without having to go through Artifactory without getting all the artifactory metadata dumped in.

This would somewhat obviate the need to add an API to the repository export functionality (RTFACT-4198).
column249: 11/Sep/12 4:16 AM;jascha;Also, if using the Backups functionality to workaround the lack of repository export, new repositories get added to each backup automatically.  This unnecessarily consumes disk space and muddies the "exported" repositories.

column1: Warn or block deployment that do not match the repo layout declared
column45:
Since repository layout are a very important control piece of a local repository, enforcing their respect is a good idea.
It should be configurable to enforce (refuse deploy if repo-layout do not match), or warn/report/query the file not respecting the layout.
column249: 24/Jun/14 11:19 AM;alanm;Any update on this?

column1: Repo only backup + explicit Include Policy for Backup
column45:
Currently the Artifactory backup:
* always does a system backup
* only allows to explicitely exclude repositories from Backup.

In our environment this has many disadvantages:
* If one of our projects asks for a half day backup we have to add a new backup cron, exclude all repositiroes except the local ones the project needs
* and continously have to add new exclusions if new repositories are added to artifactory after the cron was added...
* also we just like to have backups of the repositories but the backup always backups the system-informations,too but there is nio need and... it stores cleartext passwords where so much redundancy is not needed.

So everything would be much nicer if you can implement following features in future versions:
* Backup Repository Contents only
* Choose Repositories to be backed up in the job

This would reduce administrative workload as well could make it possible to start some jobs in parallel to use the entire power of the machine where we host. :)

column1: Support for deleting SNAPSHOT version when the corresponding release is made
column45:
When a release has been made it would be useful if Artifactory could remove the related snapshots. I.e. if there exists a release version com/foo/artifact-3.2.1, com/foo/artifact-3.2.1-SNAPSHOT should be deleted. Both Nexus and Archiva support this (not necessarily immediately, but by repository scanning).

This would allow enforcing that projects are not depending on snapshots which are already released.

column1: Plugin extension point for mapping external groups
column45:
Adding a new PAPI extension point in the security part to extend a user groups and permission after a successful authentication from a specific Realm.
This will allow:
# Importing LDAP groups into Artifactory from an external resource.
# Dynamically make user super admin based on dynamic policies.
# Add or remove groups based on other policies.
column249:
18/Jun/12 3:14 PM;draymond;This feature request has been submitted by Shay Yaakov following an email exchange between my company and JFrog's support. Here is more information about our use case for this feature.

We will be using LDAP authentication and authorization with Artifactory.

Many users will be able to access de various repositories with varying access rights. Given that we will be using LDAP, we should control these access using LDAP groups and access définitions within Artifactory defined against these groups. But given the potentially large number of users, we want to take advantage of the organisationnal structure of our company (divisions, directions, services, etc.) and the "membership" of the different users within these various organisational units. Unfortunately, this information is not in our LDAP directory. It is available in some other global user database that is unrelated to LDAP. And I do not want to replicate these data within our LDAP repository.

So during the authentication and authorization process, we want Artifactory to consider the LDAP groupes as it does now, but also consider user-group mapping that would be provided by some plugin or plugin hook so that from Artifactory's point of view, the users are part of the groups as defined by the plugin, even though these groups are not real LDAP groups.

column1: Provide possibilites to get cached artefacts of the virtual repo via REST API
column45:
In order to provide examination if the import of repositories success there should be a possibilities to get list of artefacts which exists as cached artefacts of the virtual repository.

The functionality could be also used to tracked which artefact has been get in context of the particular build (just by wrapping local repo by virtual one)

column1: Feat.Request: Authentication via https, session via http
column45:
As http has much better (traffic) performance and Artifactory loves traffic, we decided to serve "Artifactory" via http. But our companies policies more likely like to have authentication data via https.

It would be very nice if you can provide automatic https redirects and vice versa to make sure that all authentication (on Web UI as well as on API/REPO layer) is done via https but the rest of the session can be done via http.
It would be nice to have this configurable (to choose between e.g.: http only, https only, authentication via https)

For now we use the "force encryption policy" but login via WebUI is just via http.

Thanks

column1: Support enforcing a max retries for login attempts
Consider support password encyption for externally authenticated users that are not automatically created inside Artifactory users database
Enable properties filtering for repository replication
Replication failure notification
column45:
When replication fails, it is logged but there is no notification to administrators. A problem could go unnoticed for days.

It would be useful to add a failure notification email option to the replication feature.

column1: Provide ability to diff versions of a file in the Web UI
column45: Provide the ability to select two versions of a file from within the Web UI and perform a diff on them. My first thought was for being able to diff pom files but this is useful for all text files. I'm not sure of it's usefulness on binary files.

column1: It would be really useful if the artifact restore-from-backup process was easier
column45:
We have cases where we accidentally delete artifacts, or where there is a corruption, and we need to restore one artifact or one module. We currently have to hand-copy the subtree from the backup to stage it for a restore.

Not sure how the UI would look for this, but maybe having a kind of restore that allows a glob pattern to be entered would work.
column249: 16/Jan/12 9:21 PM;cquinn;Another additional or alternative approach would be if we could 'restore' the broken/missing artifact from a replica that we had successfully pushed to earlier.
column250:
16/Jan/12 11:06 PM;elig;Hi Carl,

Thank you for the suggestions, we will debate it internally for the best approach.
As you probably know, the import repository is an additive process, only undeployed artifacts will be imported back into the repository, I also find webdav to be extremely helpful in this scenario, once you mount the repository it is a mater of drag and drop the subtree from your backup.

Thanks,

Eli
column251: 16/Jan/12 11:31 PM;cquinn;Is there documentation on using webdav for this? Maybe that is all we need.
column252:
16/Jan/12 11:45 PM;elig;Any local or cache repository may be mounted as a secure WebDAV share, and made browsable from any WebDAV-supporting file manager, simply by referencing the URL of the target repository.
For example: http://host:port/artifactory/repo-path.

HTH,

Eli
column253:
17/Jan/12 2:38 AM;cquinn;Nice idea. Should this also support PUTing files into the repo, and not just GET?

I have tried it now with the OS X Finder's WebDav support and a few problems arise:
 * I can only navigate down two levels into the repo's folder structure. So not very useful at all.
 * For every folder that Finder navigates to, Artifactory dumps a couple WARN lines in the log about some hidden files not being present:

2012-01-17 00:26:33,403 [TP-Processor7] [WARN ] (o.a.r.w.WebdavServiceImpl:202) - Item 'libs-releases-local:netflix/l10nclient/._.DS_Store' not found.
2012-01-17 00:26:33,415 [TP-Processor7] [WARN ] (o.a.r.w.WebdavServiceImpl:202) - Item 'libs-releases-local:netflix/l10ncommon/.DS_Store' not found.

This floods the log quite severely.
column254:
17/Jan/12 10:57 AM;elig;Hi Carl,

Indeed the OS X Finder don't seems to work as expected and the warnings are him trying to look for the mac DS_Stor files which obviously don't exists on the repository, we are examining if it is somehow Artifactory's fault.
I just verified that GET/PUT/DELETE artifacts and complete drill down works good with different webdav clients (Cyberduck on mac, Bitkinex on Windows) so please give it another go using a different client.
column255:
18/Jan/12 3:48 AM;cquinn;Very nice, that worked pretty well for me. 

I did run into one bit of oddness: I started out with Cyberduck 4.0.2 and was able to copy artifacts between repos. But then I updated it to 4.2.1, and suddenly it couldn't talk to our newer Artifactory instances that we have running under Tomcat. (the old one is on the default Jetty and works fine). Maybe we just have something wrong with our Tomcat setup that we need to tweak, but let me know if that rings a bell.
column256:
18/Jan/12 8:04 AM;elig;Hi Carl,
No bells, 4.2.1 and Tomcat works for me.
1. Do you see anything related in the artifactory.log, request.log?
2. If you are running behind apache check the log there as well maybe something there blocks the connection.

column1: Support Backup to S3 bucket
column45: Ability to do incremental backups against an S3 bucket destination.

column1: Make it possible to lower the priority or limit the bandwith of the backup
column45: It should be possible to lower the priority or limit the bandwith of the backup.
column249: 30/Nov/11 11:11 AM;dennis benzinger | hybris;Thread in the forum regarding this issue: http://forums.jfrog.org/Lower-backup-priority-or-limit-bandwith-td7042475.html

column1: The association between jar and source should use repo layout
column45: Today the sources association is working for maven2 layout, but using the sources classifier should help provide the association between jar and sources for all layout.

column1: Copy from archive entry to path should be supported
column45:
Since we can download from an archive entry, we should be able to copy (internal Artifactory copy) from archive entry to path.
Should be supported for the copy rest api.

column1: Allow ordering of repositories list in Tree and Simple browse pages
column45:
When using many repositories, it gets hard to find a specific repository based on the resolution order.
Having a button that will order the list of repositories on the Simple and Tree browser pages can help.

column1: Provide an "Edit" link when browsing a remote repository cache
column45: It would be nice to have an "Edit" link when browsing a remote repository. This way one can easily review or update remote repo settings without going to Administration settings screen and searching for this repo.

column1: dependency declaration string form for gradle
column45:
Currently there is a nice feature to let a user copy the gradle dependency from the UI such as:


compile(group: 'net.sf.pmd', name: 'pmd', version: '4.2.5')


This is good, but we'd like to get the pure string form such as:
net.sf.pmd:pmd:4.2.5

this is easier to search on in artifactory

column1: Provide a way to download Artifactory logs in one archive
column45: It is not comfortable to download Artifactory logs one-by-one today, it would be better to have one link to get them all in one convenient archive. Or probably with an option to choose what exactly this archive should contain, which logs and of what period.

column1: Distributed cloud of Artifactory nodes
column45: Today Artifactory storage is limited by disk capacity where server is running. For a Pro version it would be nice to have an option to run a "cloud" of Artifactory servers talking to each other and spreading the load, making the storage basically infinite, similar to GoogleFS.

column1: Provide a repository option to delete artifacts older than N last versions or older than version N (older than N days)
column45:
Today, I think there's no way to let Artifactory clean itself up automatically except sending DELETE request from external client. It can only aggregate data but never get rid of it if artifacts are versioned and are not snapshots. It would be nice to have a repository configuration option that tells: "Delete artifacts that are older than N last versions" (with an optional Groovy snippet to convert an artifact version to integer in order to compare them when it is not obvious) or "Delete artifacts that are older than version N or older than N days".

This way one would be able to configure an automatic self-cleanup of Artifactory if needed. In our case, we keep some binaries in Artifactory that are created periodically and automatically, there's no need to have more than 3 or 4 last versions and we deal with cleanup by letting the client that downloads those binaries to issue a DELETE request from time to time. But it would be better to have it managed by Artifactory itself.

column1: Name and ID configuration of the generated distribution management snippet for every repository
column45: Please add a possibility to configure the name/id of the generated distribution management snippet for every repository.

column1: Allow to perform tree actions like "Delete" from GAVC search
column45: When I'm looking old snapshots to delete, I find them with GAVC search, then go to tree and perform a "Delete" or "Delete Versions" operation from there. It would be very nice to have same options as in tree available in GAVC search results.
column249: 03/Feb/11 8:34 PM;yoavl;Why not simply save the (GAVC) search results and then run the 'Delete' action on the saved results?
column250: 05/Feb/11 11:19 PM;evgenygoldin;I guess it only works for Pro version. But for free version, it would be still nice to have a checkboxes on search results and then operations could be performed on selected artifacts. "Select All" checkbox can select all search results, even those not displayed on the current page - same way it happens in GMail when it suggest to select all results matching the search.

column1: "Cancel" option for "Loading" dialog
column45: Many times an operation performed starts taking time, like GAVC search that is too broad, or trying to view a content of a very large ZIP file. When it happens, a "Loading" progress is displayed and nothing can be done in order to cancel it. It could be nice to have an option to cancel long-performing operations (today, I just browse away and open Artifactory tab again).
column249: 13/Mar/12 8:09 PM;evgenygoldin;Another scenario that can't be canceled today is "Export". If one decides to stop it to modify its settings or cleanup some repos - it can't be done. One has to take whole Artifactory down to stop the operation.

column1: "Back to Search Results" link
column45: Many times I perform a GAVC search, then view items in the tree (may be delete them), then perform the same search again and view some more items. It would be nice to have a "Back to Search Result" link when browsing the tree.

column1: Provide a way to "refresh" repository tree browser
column45:
When I browse a repo through the tree browser and I know its content was just updated by some build, there's no easy way to "refresh" the tree. I need to click "Tree Browser" link and start browsing to my node again.

Some kind of "Refresh" button would be really nice.

column1: Make Artifactory backups (if ZIP) downloadable from the Web
column45: If Artifactory is backed up to a ZIP archive, it would be nice to have a download link to add. YouTrack and TeamCity have such a link and I can get a backup archive downloaded without logging in to remote server.

column1: Add report to show all artifacts with invalid checksums
column45: A nice feature would be able to generate a report that shows all artifacts that currently have invalid checksums. Today's solution does not really scale beyond a few artifacts. An add-on to this report would be to fix the checksums in one go, i.e. one click.

column1: Search by hash / checksum / MD5 / SHA1
column45:
Hello,

When a project migrates from a legacy build system to a system with dependency management (Maven/Ivy) one of the first tasks is to migrate the dependencies committed to source control to dependencies in Artifactory. Many of the dependencies in source control do not have version information, so they need to be searched in Artifactory (or on the Internet).

This is a huge manual task, and it would be a great idea to provide a search by hash page, so that an user could upload a file or a checksum and Artifactory could return the groupId:artifactId:classifier:version of the artifact found.

In my opinion this would be a great selling point for migrating projects ;)

About the feature - both search by file and search by hash should be implemented, since sometimes the Artifactory server is in a distant location, and only providing a file upload method would be very slow (even though it is more direct and intuitive). The search by hash would be much faster.
column249: 20/Oct/10 2:34 PM;costin;A mockup of a checksum search interface.
column250: 14/Nov/11 7:24 PM;ttres;This issue is broader than RTFACT-2436.

column1: Check needs to sign based on checksum instead of lastModified
column45: Since during promotion, artifacts lastModified value is actually changed (even if the jar is identical), to avoid unnecessary signing we should use the SHA1 checksum as an indicator for "up-to-date" test in the virtual repository cache.

column1: Display Maven-resolved <name> in artifact's "General" tab
column45:
My POM *{{"<name>"}}* is set to *{{"<name>[${project.groupId}:${project.artifactId}:${project.version}]</name>"}}* which resolves to *{{"[com.goldin.plugins:maven-common:0.1-SNAPSHOT]"}}* when Maven is running.
It could be nice to have this Maven-resolved *{{"<name>"}}* as part of artifact's "General" tab, below *GroupId*, *ArtifactId*, and *Version*

column1: Deploy remote artifacts from a URL
column45:
Many times I need to download something in order to deploy it to my own Artifactory instance. 
For example, *{{"http://github.com/downloads/KentBeck/junit/junit-4.8.2.jar"}}* isn't yet available in *{{"http://repo2.maven.org/maven2/junit/junit/"}}*

It would be nice if there was a way to deploy artifacts manually not only from one's computer but from a URL as well.
column249: 21/Nov/10 5:38 PM;evgenygoldin;Ping

column1: "Show in Simple Browser" link in addition to "Show in Tree"
column45:
Hi,

Would it be more comfortable if search results provided "Show in Simple Browser" link in addition to "Show in Tree"?
This way one could jump to a simple artifacts listing, something I usually prefer to a tree-based browsing.

Thank you!

column1: Ability to change the http.useragent when starting Artifactory so as to bypass proxy issues.
Eagerly prefetching newly released versions in advance
column45:
Hi,

What if Artifactory could be instructed to periodically monitor a specified third-party versions and download it in advance when a new one is ready?
For example, we use *{{"org.jvnet.hudson.main:hudson-war"}}* in our builds and each time a new version is released, I update a POM with Hudson version and then wait quite a lot while Artifactory downloads it from remote repos, war size is ~30Mb. 

Instead, I could specify this *{{"<gId><aId>"}}* combination to be monitored for updates and eagerly downloaded the moment a new version becomes available. This way, when I come to the office, I already have new Hudson war in our internal Artifactiory repo. Optionally, an e-mail with a download link and <dependency> snippet can be sent.

Could be really cool :)

column1: Provide REST Java model
View Source for "*.class" files
column45: I think it would be very nice if Artifactory would be able to decompile the *.class files and display their source, see the image attached
column249: 30/Jun/10 9:04 AM;yossis;There are some legal issues with decompilation which we'll need to check

column1: When creating new remote repo - suggest to make it a part of virtual repo
column45:
We have a hierarchy of virtual repos in Artifactory: 
* all = libs-all + plugins-all
* libs-all = libs-releases + libs-snapshots
* libs-releases = .. 
* libs-snapshots = ...

So when adding a new *remote* repo to Artifactory - it should be added to one of those *virtual* repos as well. 
Otherwise, it's not seen by anybody.

How about suggesting to do so when remote repo is added?
Or warning something like *_"You've just created a new remote repo Xyz but didn't make it a part of any virtual repo. Do you want to do so now?"_*
column249: 23/Feb/10 8:59 PM;evgenygoldin;Or even better - I would mark some virtual repo as *"Add all new remote repositories to this one"*

column1: Full mirroring between local and remote repositories
column45:
Hello,

A very useful feature of Artifactory would be full mirroring between a specified local repository and a remote repository. This should work like this:
1. create a local repository
2. check a box saying "Mirror a remote repository"
3. check a box for "Full mirroring (upload locally deployed artifacts and delete locally deployed artifacts)"
4. activate a textbox for the url
5. if the "full mirroring" checkbox is on, activate textboxes for user and password

On the initial setup copy everything from the remote repository. A deploy to the local repo should trigger a deploy to the remote repository. A local deletion or move should trigger the same thing remotely. For move to another repo, probably this should be treated as a deletion from the remote repository - unless the full mirroring is activated, in which case the artifact should be moved remotely too, if the equivalent repository is found (if not, put a warning in the server logs).

For conflicts - SNAPSHOTs - just take the newest version. For releases - same (I'm not sure Artifactory holds timestamps for these). 
There are probably lots of issues related to timeouts and other types of conflicts which need to be treated...

This would be a big development, I agree, that's why I present it more as wishlist item.

This would be very useful for multi-site deployment - i.e. corporations or organizations with multiple headquarters.

It would definitely be very-very useful for us.

Thank you for your attention :)
column249: 15/Jul/10 9:37 AM;elig;Similar functionality is already feasible using the REST API (rsync like folder or repository replication).

column1: Create indexes for remote repos based on include/exclude patterns
column45: Instead create index only for already deployed artifacts, allow index remote repositories based on include/exclude patterns, for artifacts that have not been deployed.

column1: Support publish and consume from Eclipse "P2" repositories
column45: We are building OSGi based systems and will be using the Eclipse P2 components as part of our provisioning implementation. It would be very helpful if Artifactory could publish artifacts to a P2 repository and consume artifacts from a P2 repository as well.  Nexus has this feature already (via a plugin) and I am getting questions from my teams about whether we should be considering a switch.
column249: 20/Oct/11 5:53 PM;rpomeroy;Jason Van Zyl has offered an "experimental" plugin at allows a Nexus repository to act as a composite P2 repository for P2 repositories contained within.  That's going to lead to a LOT of top level repositories in your Nexus.  I hope (if Artifactory decides to add P2 support) you can do something a) with more of a commitment and b) something more sensible
column250: 20/Oct/11 6:03 PM;rpomeroy;It would also be nice to cleanly handle proxying of P2 repos.  Also, OSGi has published early drafts that will standardize the way in which bundle repositories work (OBR).  You may wish to adopt a spec standard approach instead of an Eclipse specific one (P2). Both are welcome though

column1: Downloading entire repositories for populating local maven repos.
column45:
It would be very nice to have the ability to download an entire repository as a ZIP file so that developers can easily populate their local repository with all available artifacts.

This would save a lot of time for developers getting set-up on a new workstation or in a new workplace. 

It's only applicable when artifactory runs on the local network of course and it definitely needs to be optional; so that random users can't bring the server down to it's knees by requesting a few of these.

column1: Allow more search capabilities
column45:
It would be nice to be able to search artifacts by database fields such as date, size, version, user, etc. For example, I would like to list all artifacts that were deployed yesterday by a certain user.

Of course this would become a non-issue if the following tickets were implemented:

http://www.jfrog.org/jira/browse/RTFACT-375?page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:all-tabpanel
http://www.jfrog.org/jira/browse/RTFACT-348?page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:all-tabpanel

column1: Implement virtual repository provider for JNLP versioning protocol URL format
column45:
I am using Artifactory as codebase server for Java Webstart applications. It is already useful as it is, but would be even better if it supported the JNLP Versioning URL format (JNLP spec 6.3). 

Here is a non-official link: http://esteban.guruz.org/JNLP/download.html

column1: Request statistics
column45:
Add statistics on artifacts requests, e.g.:
- Top-10-Missing-Artifacts list
- Top-10-Served-Artifacts list
- Number of network timeout/network error events

This should be bound to a physical repository level

column1: Provide report on updated artifacts that have become available within the public Maven repositories
column45:
We have a canonical set of dependencies which we attempt to keep current.

It would be useful if we could indicate (within the UI) the dependencies we would like to be notified of should their version be updated.

column1: Add an RSS feature to report in recent activity (uploads?)
column45:
Where ever there is system activity I promote the addition of RSS feeds to expose that activity to other systems in the environment. 

In the case of maven and ALM in general it is especially power - to demonstrate here is how we are using them to support distrubuted s/w development:

All our s/w dev projects have a dedicated project portal or 'project home' (think sourceforge's project homes, but enhanced) and one this project home page is a funky RSS feed display (think a nice table with tabs) that  displays the unified activity being reported from the main development support systems via their RSS feeds into one combined chronoligical view. Thus to what's been going on with your project over the last few days (say 5) one simply looks at this table. Aswell as showing the RSS feeds in combined view ordered by time, we also expose each specific system's activity (RSS feed) in its own dedicated activity tab.

We currently have feeds coming from the following tools:

Task activity (JIRA) - Project progress, new bugs etc
Wiki activity (confluence) - Design and general collaboration
Version control activity (Subversion) - commits et al
Build activity (QuickBuild) - CI builds, etc
Forum activity (JiveForums) - Team as well as public threads

So guess what i want to add to this list? Yep, deployments to maven repository and as I am considering changing from Proximity to Artifactory I would very much like this kind of web 2.0 (plse excuse this unadltered use of a stupid marketing misnomer) feature.

Thanks! Will probably feed more features to you as I evaluate your system in more detail over the next week or so.
column249:
03/Mar/11 1:32 PM;pnyheim;I agree.
This is a feature I used all the time in another project/organization where they used Sonatype Nexus.
Look at Nexus' System feeds for inspiration on what kind of feeds can be useful.

Thanks,
Paul

column1: automatically generate pom if not present on repo1
column45:
Even though repo1 is being carefully monitored now, there are still artifacts out there that don't have a pom, e.g.

http://repo1.maven.org/maven2/org/codehaus/xfire/bcprov-jdk15/133/bcprov-jdk15-133.pom
http://repo1.maven.org/maven2/xml-security/xmlsec/1.3.0/xmlsec-1.3.0.pom
http://repo1.maven.org/maven2/wss4j/wss4j/1.5.1/wss4j-1.5.1.pom
http://repo1.maven.org/maven2/xfire/saaj-impl/1.3/saaj-impl-1.3.pom

It would be great if Artifactory would include an option somewhere in the repo browser that allows the admin to have a default pom generated (much like the install-file plugin does with -DgeneratePom=true). Perhaps an option that appears on right-click on the artifact ?
column249: 10/Jul/07 11:51 PM;yoavl;Can be done automatically for jars without pom (pom is always resolved by Maven before the jar, so having this situation is inherently a problem) upon failing to resolve a POM for which a deployed jar exists. Maybe as a general config option (<generateMissingPoms>true</generateMissingPoms>).
column250:
11/Jul/07 10:28 AM;heymjo;Sounds good. IMO this behaviour could even be enabled by default, missing poms slow down the build quite a lot.

What would happen if the "real" pom was added to repo1 afterwards ? I guess there is not much artifactory can do there as the generated pom is installed in the local repo and maven won't bother to query for it again.
column251:
03/Apr/12 5:07 PM;hsn;This option would be also useful if POM in repository is broken. 

Currently if POM file is broken, artifactory ignores it and build can still continue.
